73661338,Yekl:_A_Tale_of_the_New_York_Ghetto,"= ''Yekl: A Tale of the New York Ghetto'' =

column2: name              = Yekl: A Tale of the New York Ghetto

column1: ''Yekl: A Tale of the New York Ghetto'' is [[Abraham Cahan
column2: Abraham Cahan’s]] first book and was published in 1896. It depicts the life of Jewish immigrants living in a [[New York City]] [[ghetto]]. The plot follows Yekl, Russian-Jewish immigrant [[sweatshop]] worker, as he attempts to [[Jewish assimilation
column3: assimilate]] into American culture. His attempts are complicated by the arrival of his wife and son, which force him to decide between his Jewish identity and a new American one.

column1: The [[novella]] uses an interesting blend of [[Literary realism
column3: regionalism]] to depict what life was like for newly arrived immigrants in the United States. Realism author [[William Dean Howells]] played a large part in getting the story published, as he discovered and encouraged Cahan to write a more serious story about life in the Jewish ghetto.<ref name="":0"">{{Cite book
column5: title=Jewish American literature: A Norton Anthology
column13: oclc=44426733}}</ref> While ''Yekl: A Tale of the New York Ghetto'' did not sell well, it would later serve as the basis for [[Joan Micklin Silver

column1: ''Yekl'' would likely not have existed were it not for the influence of realism author [[William Dean Howells]], who played a major ""role in its inception, publication, and reception.""<ref name="":2"">{{Cite book
column5: title=From the ghetto : the fiction of Abraham Cahan
column11: oclc=2346154}}</ref> Howells and Abraham Cahan first met in 1892, while Howells was doing research for ''[[A Traveler from Altruria]].''<ref name="":2"" /> The two would meet again in 1895 after Howells' wife gave him a copy of Cahan's short story ""A Providential Match."" While Howells was not particularly taken by this story, he encouraged Cahan ""to work up a more substantial piece on ghetto life.""<ref name="":2"" /> This prompted Cahan to immediately begin on the [[manuscript]] for ''Yekl.''<ref name="":2"" />

column1: Upon its completion, Cahan sent the manuscript to Howells, praised the work saying ""an important force had been added to American literature.""<ref name="":2"" /> Howells' only suggestion was to change the title from ''Yankele the Yankee'' to ''Yekl: A Tale of the New York Ghetto.''<ref name="":2"" />

The story starts with Jake, three years after he first stepped foot in America. In that time, he has embraced American culture as much as possible, so much so that he no longer goes by his given name, Yekl. When he’s not working in the sweatshop, he spends much of his time at Joe Peltner’s dance hall, where he becomes close with Mamie and Fanny.

One day, he receives a letter from home informing him of his father’s death. While he has enjoyed his time pretending to be a bachelor, the news prompts him to make good on his promise to buy a ticket for his wife (Gitl) and son (Yossele) to join him in New York.

Upon their arrival, Jake is embarrassed by his wife’s appearance and ignorance of the English language. He tries to correct this behavior and even gets Mrs. Kavarsky (his neighbor) to help turn Gitl into a more American woman. Gitl tries, but struggles to throw away her traditional beliefs and customs.

Mamie, one of Jake's dance partners, then pays a visit to Jake and he starts to fall for her. Mamie, unlike Gitl, has changed herself to become a proper American woman, at least in the context of the Jewish ghetto they inhabit. Jake pays her a visit, which Fanny (one of Jake's dance partners and coworkers) witnesses and reports back to Gitl.

Gitl runs to Mrs. Kavarsky with the news and Mrs. Kavarsky removes Gitl’s handkerchief from her head and cuts her hair in order to make her more appealing to Jake. However, this is not enough for Jake, so he leaves and runs to Mamie. Finding her, he declares his love and they conceive a plan to get him and Gitl a divorce, so the two can get married.

The divorce gets finalized, allowing Gitl to marry Mr. Bernstein (their neighbor and Jake's coworker) and Jake to marry Mamie. Jake then leaves with Mamie and they head to the mayor's office to get married. On their way, Jake begins to feel that he has made a mistake and wishes that he didn’t have to get married again.<ref name="":1"">{{Cite book
column4: title=Yekl: A Tale of the New York Ghetto

column1: * Yekl (Jake) Podkovnik – a Jewish immigrant from Russia who works in a sweatshop. He loves to dance and embraces American culture, choosing to go by Jake and using English phrases as much as he can. He struggles when faced with his past life in Russia, which he ultimately abandons in favor of living an American lifestyle.
* Gitl Podkovnik – Yekl’s wife, who moves to New York City three years after Yekl arrives. She has a major culture shock on arrival, but is reluctant to change.
* Yossele Podkovinik – Yekl and Gitl’s young son.
* Mamie – A Polish immigrant, who is one of Yekl’s dance partners that he eventually falls for because she represents the ideal, assimilated woman.
* Fanny – Yekl’s coworker, who likes Yekl until she finds out he’s married and tells Gitl about Yekl’s inappropriate behavior with Mamie.
* Mrs. Kavarsky – an older lady, who tries to help Gitl become more American so that Yekl will love her again.
* Mr. Bernstein – a well read coworker of Yekl’s, who marries Gitl when Yekl leaves her for Mamie.
* Joe Peltner – owner of the dance hall Yekl spends much of his time at.<ref name="":1"" />

This story is ultimately about immigrants, immigration, and assimilation. The narrative takes place in the New York ghetto and there is not a single ""American"" character present. Jake's (Yekl's) desire for assimilation clear from the very beginning of the novella. He has Americanized his name to Jake, he talks about American sports, and seems overall uninterested in practicing his Jewish faith. While he tries to push his old Russian life behind him, the arrival of his wife and son prevent that. Gitl, unlike Jake, is unwilling to throw away her [[Old World]] morals and behavior for the sake of being an American. These two characters go down to completely different paths at the end of the novel, leaving Gitl happy with a man who respects the Old World as she does and Jake with dreading the future he chose.<ref name="":1"" />
All of the dialogue in ''Yekl'' is a mix of English translated [[Yiddish]] and [[English language
column2: English]] spoken with a Yiddish accent. By exposing readers to Yiddish, Cahan more concretely roots the story in the Jewish [[ghetto]] its set it. In many ways, the inclusion of this type of language helps preserve the culture existing at the time, which is what characterizes ''Yekl'' as an example of [[Regionalism (literature)

column1: Within the narrative, language plays a critical role. Jake (Yekl) uses it to show how much he has embraced American culture, by using English words as much as possible. He also uses his knowledge of the English language to both impress and ridicule Gitl for his knowledge and her ignorance. Mamie is another character who knows English quite well, which is a sign of her Americanization. Additionally, Mamie uses English to alienate Gitl during their first meeting.<ref name="":1"" /> In many ways, knowledge of English operates as a symbol of power in this story.

Throughout the novella Jake (Yekl) repeats the phrase ""Dot'sh a' kin' a man ''I'' am!,"" however, it's never clear what kind of man he actually is. Jake presents himself as a bachelor before his wife and son's arrival to New York and then can't seem to decide if he has enough love to stay with them or not. In the end, he decides to leave them for the Americanized Mamie and finds himself dreading that decision.<ref name="":1"" /> Given the contrast between Jake's declaration and his actions, Cahan seems to imply that Jake's presentation of masculinity is far different from his understanding of it. Literary critic Clay Motley explains that ""Jake defines American manhood in terms of intense personal freedom, aggression, materialism, and success in attracting many different women.""<ref name="":3"">{{Cite journal
column5: title=“Dot’ sh a’ Kin’ a man I am!”: Abraham Cahan, Masculinity, and Jewish Assimilation in Nineteenth-Century America.
column10: via=Project MUSE}}</ref> This is supported by Jake changing his name from Yekl, creating a new ""identity as an American man.""<ref name="":3"" /> As a result, Jake must overcompensate in order to conceal his Jewish identity as Yekl. The problem is, he will always be Yekl, which results in him making choices that are inconsistent with his internal morals.

column1: The issue of education is raised early on in the novella. Jake (Yekl) is an uneducated man, whose English is derived from his desire to become an American. Mr. Bernstein, on the other hand, spends his time reading newspapers with an English dictionary in order to get a proper understanding of the language. Literary critic Lori Jirousek-Falls describes Yekl's education style as ""incidental"" and Mr. Bernstein's as ""intentional.""<ref name="":4"">{{Cite journal
column5: title=Abraham Cahan and Jewish Immigrant Education: For Men and Women
column10: via=JSTOR}}</ref> As a result, the two characters embark on different trajectories as the story develops. In the end, Mr. Bernstein and Gitl end up happily married, while Jake hopes that the ride to the court house will last indefinitely so he can remain a bachelor forever.<ref name="":1"" /> Jirousek-Falls concludes that ""Berstein represents the immigrant who prizes scholarship highly and discovers ways to incorporate Old World traditions with New World success,"" whereas Jake casts his Old World traditions aside, in favor of embracing American culture in an impulsive, unproductive way.<ref name="":4"" /> Both characters have authority over their choices, but it's clear that Cahan suggests that ""intentional"" education is more rewarding path.<ref name="":4"" />

column1: After completing the manuscript, [[Abraham Cahan]] and [[William Dean Howells]] worked to find a publisher, which would be a difficult task.<ref name="":2"" /> Much of this was to do with the literary market of the time that had not fully embraced [[Literary realism
column3: anti-Semitism]] present in the publishing industry.<ref name="":2"" /> As a result, Cahan and Howells were rejected by a number of publishers including ''[[Harper's Weekly]]'' and ''[[McClure's]]''.<ref name="":2"" /> Frustrated, Cahan decided to translate ''Yekl'' into [[Yiddish]] and published it in his own paper under the original title, ''Yankele the Yankee''.<ref name="":2"" /> Howells was initially upset learning about this, but considered that the book was not published because it wasn't in English.<ref name="":2"" /> Eventually, Howells would get the [[novella]] published with [[D. Appleton & Company
column4: D. Appleton and Company]], where it would be published in 1896.<ref name="":2"" />

column1: Despite finding a publisher and the glowing review Howells gave the novella, ''Yekl'' was not a commercial success.<ref name="":5"">{{Cite journal
column5: title=""YEKL:"" The Ghetto Realism of Abraham Cahan
column11: issn=0002-9823}}</ref> Literary realism was still growing as a genre and contemporary readers seemed to want ""their fiction to include beautiful people, attractive objects, and happy endings.""<ref name="":5"" /> As a result, some critics today feel that ''Yekl'' is a ""neglected masterpiece"", much like [[Kate Chopin]]'s ''[[The Awakening (Chopin novel)
column12: The Awakening]]'', because of its examination of how dominant cultures impact minority groups; a problem that is still present in the United States.<ref name="":2"" />

column2: Location in the Hitman video game series}}
Hitman]]'' video game franchise. It takes place in a fictional hospital in a remote location of Japan.

column1: Hokkaido was created by lead level designer Torbjørn Christensen. Christensen and lead game designer [[Jesper Hylling]] describe it as an absurd location due to how remote and inconvenient it is for people to get to it, but Christensen regarded that as a strength, owing to its ""fantastical"" nature that allows them to take more liberties than if it was set in [[Tokyo]].<ref name=""RPS""/> The developers had been looking for an opportunity to include a hospital in the ''Hitman'' series for a while, brainstorming on what could go wrong in a hospital setting.<ref name=""Interview""/> Initially, the setting was just going to be a hospital, but the team elected to add the resort and morgue in order to make it more surprising for players. They also sought to make the different parts of the level feel visually and thematically distinct. They went to lengths to ensure that the different areas felt like they made sense to be connected to one another, justifying the presence of a resort being that a rich patient would want to recuperate or the staff room having a [[dance mat]] game because it's set in Japan. When describing the level archetype Hokkaido fits into, Christensen called it a spiral, due to how they wrap around and interconnect with stairs and slopes.<ref name=""RPS"">{{cite web
column3: title= How Hitman's Hokkaido level was made

column1: They set the location in Japan as part of their effort to have a hospital where the technology ""borders on science fiction."" They also chose it because they wanted to have a controlled climate setting located in a setting that's otherwise harsh. They also aimed to make the spa area inviting from a tourist point of view.<ref name=""Interview""/> The level is designed to be more restrictive than normal, requiring Agent 47 to be wearing certain disguises to get into certain areas. This is done by having an AI control the facility, and it only allows doors to open if Agent 47 is wearing a disguise that it deems fit to enter that area of the facility. The idea was that clothes were fitted with RFID chips that the AI would identify. This was a difficult thing to get working well, creating a number of issues for the team.<ref name=""RPS""/> They wanted to experiment with the idea of emphasizing the disguises after they experimented with a more military-focused level in [[Colorado (Hitman)
column2: Colorado]].<ref name=""Interview""/> They had to avoid potentially confusing players, which they accomplished by having an early area require them to learn the gimmick, as well as through signposting the access levels on the doors and the clothing.<ref name=""RPS""/>

column1: Hokkaido is a more dense level, which affects how the 300 non-playable character limit manifests. In other levels, areas that should be more densely populated than they are have justifications for why they aren't. Meanwhile, because the level is smaller, no such justification is necessary, and the level is busier as a result.<ref name=""RPS""/>

Art director Jonathan Rowe worked on the level, and found that Hokkaido being ""clean, stark, and austere"" made it more difficult to make the level look good. He felt that more details make something look more realistic, but due to how sterile the level was, it was difficult to make it not seem unfinished. Rowe accomplished this by focusing on ""micro details and surface details"" to complete the package.<ref name=""Vice"">{{cite web
column3: title=How 'Hitman' Uses Thoughtful Level Design to Tell Stories
column9: accessdate=April 28, 2023}}</ref> A surgical robot resembling a spider was featured in the level, and was based on car manufacturing robots. Rowe wanted something that was both ""industrial and clunky"" yet moved unnaturally fluidly, finding those two themes working in concert ""very disturbing.""<ref name=""Vice""/>

column1: With Hokkaido, Christensen wanted to experiment with a static target to see if it would be interesting. This was attempted with the character Erich Soders, who is unconscious while undergoing gene therapy. Christensen wanted to take advantage of the spiral structure of the level as part of this target. He was partly designed in response to a mission in the [[Sapienza (Hitman)
column2: Sapienza]] level, where Agent 47 has to eliminate a virus in an underground seaside cave. Christensen felt limited by this due to the fact that the virus had only few ways to be eliminated, and thus aimed to provide more in this case. This was accomplished by implementing failsafes designed to resuscitated Soders that need to be prevented.<ref name=""RPS""/> Soders was also chosen for this because of his role in the game, being that he had the power to determine whether Agent 47 would live or die. The designers put him in a helpless state in order to turn the tables in their roles.<ref name=""Interview"">{{cite web
column4: title=Hitman Season 1 Interview Series - Chapter 6: Hokkaido

column1: Helmut Krueger, a character from the [[Paris (Hitman)
column2: Paris]] level, was featured in this level in response to positive fan feedback.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Hitman Season One: Looking Back With Creative Director Christian Elverdam

column1: The level takes place in a hospital located in Japan, featuring three tiers. The top tier is a luxury resort, sushi restaurant, garden, hot springs, and more. The middle tier is the area where surgeries are performed and the staff live. Finally, the bottom tier is a morgue.<ref name=""RPS""/>

Hokkaido first appeared as the setting of the sixth and final episode of the 2016 ''Hitman'' game, with the episode releasing on October 31, 2016.<ref name=""renamed_from_247_on_20230501135613"">{{cite web
column3: title=Hitman: Episode 6 - Hokkaido is the Season Finale and out later this month
column8: accessdate=April 28, 2023}}</ref> It was later featured in a complete edition of ''Hitman'', which launched on January 31.<ref name=""renamed_from_247_on_20230501135613""/> Hokkaido reappears in ''[[Hitman 2 (2018 video game)
column9: Hitman 2]]'', given a new mission.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Hitman 2 Bonus Episode takes players back to Hokkaido

column1: The Hokkaido level and its containing episode was met with generally positive reception, holding an 81 and 83 on [[Metacritic]] for [[PlayStation 4]] and [[personal computer
column2: PC]]s respectively.<ref name=""MC""/><ref name=""MC2""/> ''[[Destructoid]]'' writer Chris Carter found himself uninterested in the assassination targets, being more interested in the level and environment itself. He felt it evoked the vibes of Sapienza, while praising the RFID gimmick.<ref name=""Destructoid""/> ''[[IGN]]'' writer Luke Reilly praised it as one of the best levels in the 2016 ''Hitman'', calling it ""vintage ''Hitman'' at its most creative"" as well as ""atmospheric and tricky.""<ref name=""IGN""/> ''PC Gamer'' writer Phil Savage praised it for how it made the systems and level design work together so thoroughly as well as how ""confident and experimental"" it was. Savage considered it his all-time favorite stage in the series due in part to the RFID mechanic.<ref name=""PCG""/><ref name=""PCG2""/> ''Push Square'' writer Sam Brooke felt that, while it wasn't the perfect ending to ''Hitman'', it was a ""nice swansong,"" calling it the most ""atmospheric and creative"" of all the episodes.<ref>{{cite web
column9: accessdate=April 28, 2023}}</ref> ''Hardcore Gamer'' writer Adam Beck praised the atmosphere and level design, as well as the gameplay, but found the plot anticlimactic <ref name=""HCG""/> ''[[Kotaku]]'' writer Riley MacLeod praised it as a finale due to it not feeling like a finale. He discussed how the level is strange and challenging due to how much information certain NPCs have, citing a moment when he was disguised as a patient and a guard caught him wandering outside. He felt that the level's ""long, subtle burn"" contrasted with the previous episode, Colorado, which was more ""upfront aggression.""<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Hitman Hokkaido Is Sleek And Subtle

column1: ''[[PC Gamer]]'' staff ranked it as the third best level in the ''[[World of Assassination]]'' trilogy. Writer Fraser Brown appreciated how it started off relatively uncomplicated, but only grew more complicated as he uncovered it.<ref name=""PCG2"">{{cite web
column3: title=Every modern Hitman level, ranked from worst to best
column10: accessdate=April 28, 2023}}</ref> ''Paste Magazine'' writer Hamish Black ranked it as the fourth best level in the game, praising the variety of strategies you could employ as well the atmosphere. However, they felt that, with there being less area to explore and going back to the two-target system, it makes Hokkaido feel anticlimactic.<ref>{{cite web
column17: accessdate=April 28, 2023}}</ref>''Hardcore Gamer'' writer Adam Beck ranked Hokkaido as the second best mission in ''Hitman 2'', feeling that the size was just right and that Japan is a good choice for a level.<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=Every Hitman Mission, Ranked from Worst to Best
column24: accessdate=April 28, 2023}}</ref> ''TechRadar'' writers Samuel Roberts and James Peckman ranked it as the fifth best level in the ''World of Assassination'' trilogy, with James praising it for shaking things up by making a level that's more restrictive and challenging to navigate.<ref>{{cite web
column26: title=The 10 best Hitman levels – including Hitman 3 locations

column2: image = Hyundai Motor Manufacturing Alabama Highsmith 01.jpg
caption = Hyundai plant whose parts suppliers used child labor
charges = Violating [[Fair Labor Standards Act#1949 Fair Labor Standards Amendment
column3: Fair Labor Standards Act]] and Alabama state child labor regulations

column4: parts suppliers]] were found to be [[Child labour
column5: illegally employing children]] to operate heavy equipment.<ref name="":3"" /><ref name="":0"" /> Most of these children were [[Refugee
column6: refugees]] from [[Central America]], some of whom were put to [[Debt bondage
column7: work against threat of deportation]].<ref name="":0"" />

column1: In 2005, Hyundai started manufacturing cars at a new [[Hyundai Motor Manufacturing Alabama
column2: plant in Alabama]]. Production is supported by a number of parts suppliers in Alabama, including SMART, which Hyundai owns. Other parts suppliers  involved in the scandal include SL, Hwashin, and {{Ill
column5: 아진산업}}. Some workers at these parts suppliers were recruited by [[Temporary work
column6: temporary work agencies]], which reduced the liability of those suppliers to recruit laborers who are legally eligible to work.

column1: In July 2022, [[Reuters]] reported that SMART, a Hyundai subsidiary in [[Luverne, Alabama
column2: Luverne]], [[Alabama]], U.S.A. had hired minors as young as 12 years old to work in one of its [[Stamping (metalworking)
column11: title=Exclusive: Hyundai subsidiary has used child labor at Alabama factory
column15: language=en}}</ref> The subsidiary supplies parts for Hyundai's nearby assembly plant in [[Montgomery, Alabama
column17: title=Behind the investigative report on child labor allegations at Hyundai Alabama plant
column21: access-date=2022-08-02}}</ref> A former employee of SMART said that there were around 50 [[Child labour
column22: underage workers]], some of which were children of [[History of Guatemalan migrants in the United States
column23: Guatemalan migrants]]. The report was confirmed by ""area police, the family of three underage workers, and eight former and current employees of the factory."" In response, Hyundai said the company ""does not tolerate illegal employment practices at any Hyundai entity"" and that it is ""unaware of any evidence of the allegations.""<ref>{{Cite news
column27: title=Hyundai Says It Has 'No Evidence' of Child Labor at Alabama Unit
column31: access-date=2022-08-14}}</ref> SMART stated separately that it follows the law and denied knowingly employing ""anyone who is ineligible for employment."" It expects the temporary work agencies that fill its jobs to ""follow the law in recruiting, hiring, and placing workers."" [[Child labor laws in the United States
column32: State and federal labor laws]] limit minors younger than 18 from working in metal stamping and pressing jobs near dangerous machinery. Alabama also [[Compulsory education
column33: requires children 17 and under to be enrolled in school]], which some of the underage workers had to forego in order to work long shifts at the plant.<ref name="":1"" /> Following the report, a California Hyundai owner filed a [[Class action
column34: class action lawsuit]] against Hyundai claiming that ""Defendants materially omit and fail to disclose that Class Vehicles are manufactured using child labor"" and that Hyundai owners and lessees were harmed as a result.<ref>{{Cite web
column38: title=Hyundai Alabama child labor allegations lead to class action lawsuit

column1: On 29 September, 2022, the [[United States Department of Labor
column2: U.S. Department of Labor]] fined SL Alabama, a division of Korean [[SL Corporation
column3: SL Corp]], $30,076 for violating the [[Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938
column4: Fair Labor Standards Act]]'s child labor provisions, following an inspection on 9 August, 2022. The [[consent decree]], ordered by the [[United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama
column5: U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Alabama]], also prevents SL Alabama from shipping or delivering any goods produced using underage labor. It also requires training materials to be provided to employees and subcontractors to ensure compliance with child labor laws, quarterly trainings provided by a third party for three years, and sanctions on any management found responsible for violations. SL Alabama, which is based in [[Alexander City, Alabama
column6: Alexander City]], supplied parts to Hyundai, as well as [[Kia]]. Separately, Alabama's state Department of Labor fined SL Alabama and JK USA Inc., its temporary labor recruiting firm, $17,800 each for a total of $35,600. Property records show that the house where some underage workers lived alongside other SL employees is owned by a company registered under the name of the president of the recruiting firm.<ref name="":3"" /> However, because the underage workers were at companies who only produced parts for Hyundai and Kia's supply chain, neither department of labor accused Hyundai or Kia of any wrongdoing.<ref>{{Cite press release
column7: title=Federal court orders Hyundai, Kia auto parts manufacturer to stop employing minors illegally, end ‘oppressive’ child labor law violations
column19: title=Hyundai, Kia auto parts supplier in Alabama fined for child labor violations

column1: Regulators were first tipped off about child labor in Hyundai's supply chain by a school official in 2021, who told them that a child around 12 years old was working at the Hwashin plant in [[Greenville, Alabama]]. After the Reuters investigation into SMART, Hwashin fired all their underage workers in fear of an inspection. Another parts supplier, {{Ill
column4: 아진산업}}, employed more than 10 underage workers according to several employees, including one manager who was told to ""focus on production"" after reporting the violations to his higher ups. At SMART, over 20 boys and girls aged around 12 to 16 worked around heavy equipment, including operating [[Forklift
column5: forklifts]] and [[welding]]. After two incidents of teenage workers falling and injuring themselves, Carlos Herrera, an employee, said ""[he] would tell them: this person shouldn't be working... but they didn't care."" Herrera also alleges that Hyundai officials wearing Hyundai branded shirts visited the plant while children were working on the floor, saying that ""it was obvious there were minors."" Notes from the [[Office of Refugee Resettlement]] described how the underage workers experienced ""exploitation from [[debt bondage]] (repaying smuggling debts)"" and that ""some children expressed fear of [[deportation]] based on comments made by company officials to them.""<ref name="":3"">{{Cite news
column13: title=Child workers found throughout Hyundai-Kia supply chain in Alabama

column1: On 22 November, 2022, inspectors from the state and federal departments of labor conducted a surprised inspection of a [[Hyundai Glovis]] warehouse in [[Montgomery, Alabama
column2: Montgomery]]. They found that a boy had been working at three different parts manufacturers from the age of 14, which resulted in the Alabama Department of Labor fining three separate staffing companies $5,050, which is the maximum state penalty for a child labor violation.<ref name="":0"">{{Cite news
column10: title=Special Report: How a fake ID let Hyundai suppliers use child labor in Alabama

column1: In February, 2023, Hyundai entered talks with the Department of Labor to ensure compliance with child labor regulations.<ref>{{Cite news
column9: title=Exclusive: Hyundai in talks with U.S. Labor Department over Alabama child labor
column13: access-date=2023-04-28}}</ref> A group of 33 [[Member of Congress
column14: members of Congress]], led by [[Democratic Party (United States)
column15: Democratic]] Michigan Congressman [[Dan Kildee]], wrote to urge the Department of Labor to ""take immediate action to rid Hyundai's supply chain of child labor.""<ref>{{Cite web
column18: title=Letter to DOL on Child Labor in U.S. Auto Supply Chain
column27: title=Exclusive: U.S. lawmakers press Labor Department to probe child labor in Hyundai supply chain
column31: access-date=2023-04-28}}</ref> CEO Jae Hoon Chang announced to shareholders on 24 February 2023 that Hyundai would be divesting its controlling stake in SMART.<ref>{{Cite news
column39: title=Exclusive: Hyundai to divest Alabama subsidiary following child labor revelations
column43: access-date=2023-04-28}}</ref> This controversy, along with other instances of illegal child labor in [[Meat-packing industry
column44: meat packing]] plants, motivated a bipartisan group of lawmakers to introduce legislation to increase federal penalties for child labor law violations.<ref>{{Cite news
column50: title=Bipartisan bill aims to increase penalties for US child labor violations
column55: title=Increases in child labor violations, young workers’ injuries prompts enhanced outreach, strong enforcement by US Department of Labor

73670713,Gabi_Dao,"­Gabi Dao (b. 1991) is a Canadian artist and organizer currently based in Rotterdam. Dao’s research-based practice includes sculpture, collage, and sound and moving image installations. Many of their installations create olfactory experiences using scents from their small-batch perfume business, PPL’S PERFUME.
Dao received a Bachelor of Fine Art from [[Emily Carr University of Art and Design]] in 2014<ref>{{Cite web
column5: website=iffr.com}}</ref> and is currently a Master of Fine Art candidate at the [[Piet Zwart Institute]] in Rotterdam.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: website=Morris and Helen Belkin Art Gallery

column1: She has exhibited in artist-run spaces and galleries in Canada, Asia, and Europe. Notable solo shows include ''a sentimental dissidence'' at [[Grunt gallery]] (2019)<ref>{{Cite web

column28: website=National Gallery of Canada}}</ref> and [[Vancouver Art Gallery]] (Vancouver, Canada).<ref name="":1"">{{Cite web

column1: = Ethics of Media (Journalists) in the U.S. =

News media journalists play a key role in informing American citizens about health, policies, scandals, and more. Inadvertently, news media journalist shape or influence the public perception of events and issues. In a democratic country like the United States, it is important to have information about issues that impact one's life quality, because citizens have the power to change them through voting. Additionally, news media can highlight injustices going on in the country or on smaller scales (states, cities, counties). Change from the people relies on information from the news media companies, which is why in the constitution the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution

As the government and the public began to realize the importance of journalistic influence, several organizations established a code of ethics. It first appeared in the United States in 1923 under the direction and approval of The American Society of Newspaper Editors<ref name="":3"">{{Cite web
column2: title=About the USA - The Media in the United States > Media Ethics
column5: website=usa.usembassy.de}}</ref>. Soon after, the [[Society of Professional Journalists]] and Associated Press Managing Editor endorsed these ethics<ref name="":3"" />. Each of these organizations are still in practice today and still teach the same code of ethics produced nearly a hundred years ago.

column1: ==== The American Society of Newspaper Editors: Code of Ethics ====
The American Society of Newspaper Editors or ASNE follows six principles in the organizations code of ethics.

* In ASNE's first principle, they encourage all journalists to act responsibly. According to them, responsible journalists do not abuse the trust given to them by the public<ref name="":0"">{{Cite web
* In their second principle, ASNE believes journalists should understand the importance of the [[Freedom of the press
column2: Freedom of the Press]]. The Freedom of the Press is the voice of the people, and journalists should be vigilant to make sure it is heard<ref name="":0"" />.

column1: * In ASNE's third principle, the organization encourages journalists to act independently. For journalists, independence looks like avoiding conflicts of interest or anything that may influence their integrity<ref name="":0"" />.

* ASNE's fourth principle wants journalists to uphold truth and accuracy. Journalists can uphold truth and accuracy by represent both sides of the event, remain unbiased, and refrain from substantial fact errors<ref name="":0"" />.

* In the organization's fifth principle, ASNE believes that journalists should remain impartial. For journalists, impartiality means refraining from adding personal biases into their work<ref name="":0"" />.
* In their sixth principle, ASNE wants journalists to incorporate fair play into their work. Journalists should honor confidentiality and allow persons to respond to accusations<ref name="":0"" />.
==== Society of Professional Journalists: Code of Ethics ====
The Society of Professional Journalists or SPJ follows four principles in their code of ethics<ref name="":1"">{{Cite web
column3: title=SPJ Code of Ethics - Society of Professional Journalists

column1: * In their first principle, SPJ believes journalists should seek and report the truth, which means journalists should prioritize the accuracy of their work over being the first to break the latest news story<ref name="":1"" />.

* The second principle emphasizes that journalists should not cause harm to others. SPJ believes journalists should show compassion for others and consider other people's perspectives or situations<ref name="":1"" />.

* In the third principle, SPJ encourages journalists to act independently, which means they should avoid conflicts of interest. Additionally, they should not accept anything for personal gain while reporting a short<ref name="":1"" />.

* The last SPJ principle encourages journalists to be accountable and transparent to their audience. For SPJ, accountability and transparency are answering the audience's questions and acknowledging mistakes<ref name="":1"" />.
==== Associated Press Managing Editors: Code of Ethics ====
The Associated Press Managing Editors follow four principles in their code of ethics<ref name="":2"">{{Cite web

* The Associated Press Managing Editors' first principles describe the responsibility of journalists. A responsible journalist avoids conflict of interest, adheres to confidential agreements, and provides current accurate facts<ref name="":2"" />.

* In their second principle, the Associated Press Managing Editors encourage journalists to be accurate. Accuracy means refraining from biases, not distorting or enhancing facts, and correcting errors<ref name="":2"" />.

* In the organization's third principle, they encourage journalists to act with integrity. The Associated Press Managing Editors believe journalists should remain impartial and report on issues even if it is out of their interests<ref name="":2"" />.

* In their last or fourth ethic principle, the Associated Press Managing Editors advise journalists to avoid conflicts of interest. Conflicts of interest may be bribes, and involvement in communities, among others<ref name="":2"" />.

Several decades later, the role of journalists in media began to shift, specifically in the 1960s. Journalists during this period took the position of ""watchdog."" They were giving American citizens updates about the Vietnam War, which fields the negativity surrounding the war<ref name="":3"" />. Soon after, two journalists, Bob Wood Ward, and Carl Bernstein, revealed incriminating evidence against Richard Nixon that made him resign<ref name="":3"" />. Journalist's role as watchdog landed them on trial with the U.S. Supreme Court because the government believed they are interfering with safety protocols<ref name="":3"" />. Despite journalists' best efforts, the American citizens trust began to waver because they questioned their ethics and intentions for breaking stories. {{Dashboard.wikiedu.org draft template/about this sandbox}}

The '''1923 Davis & Elkins Senators football team''' was an [[American football]] team that represented [[Davis & Elkins College]] of [[Elkins, West Virginia]], during the [[1923 college football season]]. In its first year under head coach [[Cam Henderson]], the team compiled a perfect 8–0 record.<ref name=CFDW>{{cite web
Davis & Elkins was one of several unbeaten and untied football teams in 1923, others including [[1923 Illinois Fighting Illini football team
column3: Michigan]], [[1923 Marquette Golden Avalanche football team
column4: Marquette]], [[1923 Colorado Silver and Gold football team
column5: Colorado]], [[1923 Cornell Big Red football team
column8: Yale]], and [[1923 New Mexico A&M Aggies football team
column9: New Mexico A&M]]. Because of Davis & Elkins' weaker schedule, it has been rejected as a candidate for 1923 national champion.<ref>{{cite news

column1: Davis & Elkins played its home games at Davis Stadium in [[Elkins, West Virginia]].

column1: 73684023,Rita_Mulier,"'''Rita Mulier''' (born 1934) is a Belgian feminist author and economist. Writing for ''De nieuwe maand'' (''The New Month''), she set up the  {{ill
column4: Furia (denktank)}} (VOK, Women's Consultation Committee) and played a role in the  [[women's liberation movement in Europe
column5: women's liberation movement]] in Belgium. She focused on mother's rights in the workplace and held a post in the  [[Flemish Community]] from 1991 until 1996. She was recognised with a [[Belgian_nobility#Barons
column6: baronetcy]] and published her autobiography in 1999.

column1: Rita Mulier was born in 1934 in [[Kortrijk]], [[Flanders]], Belgium. She was the eighth of nine children. She survived World War II then studied law and economics at [[Catholic University of Leuven (1834–1968)
column2: Leuven University]], on the insistence of her father who was a political activist.<ref name=""Knack"">{{cite news
column15: language=nl}}</ref> She was the only female editor of the student newspaper, writing about women's issues whilst studying how women in Belgium only had as much rights as children and the mentally disabled.<ref name=""Knack"" /> Whilst at university Mulier met her husband, with whom she had six children (one dying in [[premature birth]]). She then decided to take the [[oral contraceptive pill]], going against her [[Catholic]] upbringing.<ref name=""Knack"" />

column1: Mulier started working at Katholieke Arbeidersvrouwen (KAV - Catholic Female Workers) and published a report entitled ''De vrouw nu: Een nieuw statuut'' (''Women now: A new status'') in 1966, which argued there should be more help for women to re-enter the job market after having children.<ref name=""Knack"" /><ref name=""Molle"">{{cite journal
column4: title=De nieuwe vrouwenbeweging in Vlaanderen, een andere lezing
column11: language=nl}}</ref> She next worked at the youth section of the [[Christelijke Volkspartij]] (CVP - Catholic Workers Party); she was involved in the 1968 debate over [[Abortion in Belgium
column12: abortion]] and wrote for various journals about women's rights.<ref name=""Knack"" /> She became editor of ''De nieuwe maand'' (''The New Month'') and organized a [[feminist]] weekend in 1972; the latter inspired the creation of both the first national women's day on 11 November that year and the {{ill
column15: Furia (denktank)}} (VOK, Women's Consultation Committee).<ref name=""Atria"">{{cite news
column21: language=en}}</ref> Mulier became the first president of VOK from 1973 until 1981 as it pioneered feminism in Belgium, as part of the [[women's liberation movement in Europe]] and following the example of [[Dolle Mina]] in the Netherlands.<ref name=""GG"">{{cite web
column39: title=Social Movement Organizations and Changing State Architectures: Comparing Women's Movement Organizing in Flanders and Scotland
column46: issn=0048-5950}}</ref> She worked with other feminists such as [[Lily Boeykens]], [[Ireen Daenen]], [[Moniek Darge]] and [[Renée van Mechelen]], to make the VOK more dynamic and responsive than previously existing organisations such as the KAV.<ref name=""HN"" /><ref name=""BR"">{{cite journal
column49: title=Je ziet het al aan de sacoche. Veertig jaar Vrouwendagen: Over representatie gesproken

column1: With the foundation Omschakelen (which grew out of VOK in 1980), she focused directly on women's employment rights after having children.
She then became representative for emancipation in the [[Flemish Community]] from 1991 until 1996. Her achievements were recognised with a [[Belgian_nobility#Barons
column3: title=Raymond Ceulemans in adelstand, ridder Jacques Rogge wordt graaf
column14: language=nl}}</ref> In 1999, she published a chapter in the book ''Democratization and Women's Grassroots Movements'' with [[Alison Woodward]]. They evaluated how VOK worked to unite disparate feminist groups in Belgium.<ref name=""Introduction"">{{cite book
column30: isbn=9780253028143 }}</ref> The same year, her autobiography ''Dwars & loyaal: Een getuigenis over veertig jaar engagement'' (''Contrary & Loyal: An account of forty years of activism'') was published.<ref name=""Knack"" />

column4: title=Dwars & loyaal: Een getuigenis over veertig jaar engagement [Contrary & Loyal: An account of forty years of activism]

column15: chapter=Building democratic bridges over Belgian political bastions}}</ref>

column3: Totnes]], winning a seat.  In Parliament, he argued for shorter Parliamentary terms, and for the bishops to lose their automatic seats in the [[House of Lords]].  He held his seat until 1839, when he retired.<ref name=""stenton"">{{cite book

column2: 2011 inventory of notable aerial cableways, funiculars and ski lifts in Switzerland}}
Inventaire suisse des installations à câbles}}, {{lang-it
column3: Inventario svizzero degli impianti a fune}}, literally ''Swiss Inventory of Cableways'') was published in 2011 by the [[Federal Office of Culture]].<ref name=""NZZ-SDA""/> Of about 3000 [[Cable transport
column5: heritage]] inventory assesses 67 as of national importance and 44 as of regional importance in terms of the Swiss Federal Act on the nature and cultural heritage.<ref name=""FabianMuster""/><ref name=""BAK""/>It also includes 18 noteworthy more recent systems. Installations are included for their cultural or technological significance.<ref name=""method""/> The inventory covers aerial cableways ([[aerial tramway]]s, [[gondola lift]]s, [[chair lifts]], [[material ropeway]]s), [[funicular]]s and [[Surface lift
column6: ski lift]]s. Classifications applied are those of Swiss authorities. It does not cover [[inclined elevator]]s, mobile lifts and installations part of residential, military or industrial building complexes.<ref name=""method""/>

column1: Mandated by the Federal Office of Culture, the inventory was prepared by Karin Zaugg, Michael Gerber, Peter Bannwart, Thomas Batschelet, Erwin Bloch, Stefan Kraus, Brigitte Müller and Rudolf Saum.<ref name=""impressum""/>
They were advised by a commission from the following agencies and organisations:<ref name=""impressum""/>
* [[Federal Office of Transport]] BAV: Urs Wohlwend

column4: Eidgenössische Kommission für Denkmalpflege}} EKD: Bernhard Furrer

column1: * [[Verband Seilbahnen Schweiz]] SBS: Anna Amacher Hoppler and Fulvio Sartori
* [[Interkantonales Konkordat für Seilbahnen und Skilifte]] IKSS: Reto Canale
* [[Society for Art History in Switzerland]] GSK: Nina Mekacher
At the Federal Office of Culture, Oliver Martin was in charge of the project and Reto Müller of the publication<ref name=""impressum""/>
The project started in January 2008 and most onsite inspections took place in 2009. The inventory was completed in 2010 and aimed to reflect the state at end of 2010.<ref name=""method""/>
From the initial list of 2934 installations, 175 were evaluated in detail and 129 included.<ref name=""method""/>
*detailed evaluation: concept, technology, architecture, authenticity, history, location, local infrastructure
*appendices: technical data, years of components, images

column2: + Number of cableways by type and importance

column1: The inventory is meant to guide the federal and cantonal agencies (notably [[Federal Office of Transport]] and the office of the [[Interkantonales Konkordat für Seilbahnen und Skilifte]]) when delivering concessions for the infrastructure.<ref name=""FabianMuster""/><ref name=""BAK""/>
Twelve funiculars are considered of national importance, these are:<ref name=""N1""/>
13 of regional importance consists of:<ref name=""N1""/>
Also the following not built for commercial transport of persons:

column2: Université de Neuchâtel - Gare CFF, Fun'Ambule]]

column1: The inventory is published online in static form.<ref name=""N1""/> A summary booklet was published in print and as pdf.<ref name=""N2""/> The German original was translated into French and Italian and published in tri-lingual form<ref name=""N1""/> with a preface by Jean-Frédéric Jauslin of the Federal Office of Culture.<ref name=""N2""/>
The online version includes a history of cableways in Switzerland by Karin Zaugg, ''Seilbahnen in der Schweiz. Hintergrund''.<ref name=""Zaugg""/>

column1: '''Pot Roast''' (2014-February 16, 2022) was an American cat from [[Kansas City, Missouri
column2: Kansas City]] who went viral on [[TikTok]] for her bedraggled appearance. She was owned by an anonymous woman who goes by Pot Roast's Mom online due to privacy concerns.<ref name="":0"">{{Cite web
column6: title=TikTok-famous cat's death underscores dangers of parasocial relationships

column1: Pot Roast was adopted as a kitten in 2014, when her owner met her at an event hosted by the [[Missouri University of Science and Technology]].<ref name="":1"">{{Cite web
column3: title=Pot Roast is KC's viral TikTok feline celeb
column7: language=en-US}}</ref> Her owner, a student at the time, kept the kitten in her [[Fraternities and sororities
column8: sorority]] house for a week, but due to the house's no-pet rule, the kitten took up residence in the neighboring fraternity house.<ref name="":2"">{{Cite web
column11: title=Fans are heartbroken on learning the beloved TikTok famous cat Pot Roast has died
column15: language=en-US}}</ref> The shelter was not forthcoming about all of the cat's health problems, including [[Feline viral rhinotracheitis
column16: feline herpes]] and [[stomatitis]] (which resulted in all of her teeth eventually being extracted).<ref name="":1"" />

column1: After first posting on TikTok in late 2020, Pot Roast and her owner quickly gained traction, in part due to the cat's ""listless"" and ""stiff-limbed"" appearance, which resulted in an ongoing joke that Pot Roast was [[Taxidermy
column6: title=Cat Beloved On TikTok For Her ‘Taxidermy’ Energy Has Died
column14: title=Beloved TikTok cat Pot Roast has died
column18: language=en-US}}</ref> Videos included her owner monologuing or answers to comments, all while holding Pot Roast, who sometimes wore hats.<ref name="":2"" />

column1: At the time of Pot Roast's death, Pot Roast's Mom had 930,000 followers.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Our favorite TikTok cat, Pot Roast, has died

column1: In early February 2022 Pot Roast was diagnosed with [[Feline immunodeficiency virus
column2: FIV]], and her quality of life declined in the following weeks.<ref name="":2"" /><ref name="":3"" /><ref name="":4"">{{Cite web
column6: title=TikTok Mourns Death of Beloved Cat Pot Roast
column9: website=E! Online}}</ref> She died on February 16.<ref name="":4"" /> Her owner continued to post on TikTok, updating followers on her [[Grief
column14: title=Letter from the Editor: Love, loss, and Pot Roast
column20: title=Grieving the Star of the Pot Roast Cinematic Universe: Pot Roast’s Mom reflects on life one year after the famous TikTok cat’s death
column24: language=en-US}}</ref> Some viewers harassed her owner and criticized her for jokes she made about her grieving process or her decision to keep and articulate Pot Roast's bones.<ref name="":0"" />

column1: As of April 2023, Pot Roast's owner is writing a book about pet grief.<ref name="":5"" />

73694978,Battle_of_Khankala_(1395),"During the [[Timurid invasions of Simsim#Main Timurid invasion
column2: Main Timurid campaign against Simsim]] in [[1395]], the main [[Princedom of Simsim
column3: Simsim army]], led by [[Khour II]] as well as other Chechen nobles clashed with the Timurids led by [[Timur]]. The battle resulted in the defeat of the former.{{sfn

column2: partof            = the [[Timurid invasions of Simsim#Main Timurid invasion

column3: Flag of medieval vainakh.jpg}} [[Princedom of Simsim]]

Flag of medieval vainakh.jpg}} [[Khour II]]
{{flagicon image

column1: With the victory of  [[Timur]] during the [[Battle of the Terek River]] against the [[Golden Horde]] in [[1395]], he planned on devastating the [[North Caucasus]] because of their support for the Mongols in the [[Tokhtamysh-Timur war]]. Starting West, Timur undertook a short expedition into [[Circassia]], before sending some of his generals to complete the expedition. Meanwhile, he ravaged the land of the kings [[Burak Khan]], [[Kuli and T'aus]], and [[Pul Adi]].{{sfn
With the fall of the fortress Pulada, [[Timur]] returned to his headquarters in the Pjatigorye region, organizing and preparing his troops for the final campaign in [[Princedom of Simsim
column2: Simsim]]. Timur announced to the population of Simsim that anyone who obeyed would be pardoned, and anyone who resisted would be executed. However, this threat of the conqueror did not have the expected result, as evidenced by the hostilities that unfolded here

column1: Having won several clashes with the army of Simsim, Timur occupied the area surrounding the Northwest of the [[Terek River]]. While moving along the left bank of the Terek River, the Chechens conducted ambushes on his army, however he countered these ambushes by digging defensive trenches. Eventually, he reached the [[Sunzha River]].{{sfn

The army of the formidable Timur decided to move into the mountains of Chechnya upstream of the Sunzha and Argun. To do this, Timur wanted to cross to the right bank of the [[Sunzha River]], where the city of [[Grozny]] is now located. It was here, according to legend, that by order of Timur a bridge was built across the Sunzha, from which the crossing itself across the river in this place was called “Kopir-Astagh Timur”, that is, “the bridge of Timur the lame”.{{sfn

The two armies clashed in the Khankala gorge, located Southwest of modern-day [[Grozny]]. A fierce battle began, however, a far more numerical superiority of the Timurids led to the dominance of the latter on the battlefield. Realizing this, [[Khour II]] retreated his forces, planning to conduct a [[Guerrilla warfare
column2: Guerrilla campaign]] against the army of [[Timur]]. However, while trying to retreat, Tamerlane's army inflicted great losses on the [[Princedom of Simsim
column3: Simsim]] army, almost leading to its complete destruction.{{sfn

column4: url=https://anchr.ru/2019/12/nashestvie-timura-i-borba-chechencev-za-nezavisimost/%7Ctitle=%D0%9D%D0%90%D0%A8%D0%95%D0%A1%D0%A2%D0%92%D0%98%D0%95 ТИМУРА И БОРЬБА ЧЕЧЕНЦЕВ ЗА НЕЗАВИСИМОСТЬ

column5: title=Борьба народов Северного Кавказа с экспансией Тимура

column6: publisher=Акционерное общество Издательско-полиграфический комплекс Грозненский рабочий

column4: ʻĀmuitahiraʻa]] joint list, and 3 for [[A here ia Porinetia]].<ref>{{cite web

In 1649, after a visit to [[Viipuri Province
column2: Vipuri]], the Governor-General of Finland, [[Per Brahe the Younger]], decided to establish a new town near the waterways. The land use plan was compiled in 1649 by Erik Nilsson Aspgren.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: On September 20, 1652, the Diet of Stockholm decided to grant special rights to [[Lappeenranta]]. In early 1653, Erik Nilsson Aspgren handed over special rights to the governor Johann Rosenhan.

After the [[Treaty of Nystad]], in the fall of 1721, Sweden established a border commission headed by Axel Löwen, general and state counsellor. In 1722, Axel Leuven established a small garrison to ensure the crossing of the border and the return of refugees. [[Axel Löwen]], Johann Henrik Friesenheim and Brent-Olof Stockenberg then decided to strengthen Lappeenranta. To secure the Lapinranta bitumen trade, pits and frieze horses were set up and 112 soldiers were sent to protect the trading post. In 1723, the brothers Carl Friedrich and Anders Johann Nordenberg were chosen to design the castle along with Jacob Johann Faber. Most of the construction work was done between 1722 and 1728.<ref>{{Cite web

When the Hat Party came to power in the late 1730s, it allocated additional funds to expand the fortifications, led by Adam Reinhardt Bruno. However, the fortification work was stopped by a small outburst of anger.<ref>{{Cite book
column2: title=(fi) Suomalaiset linnoitukset, SKS, Saarijärvi, Suomalaisen Kirjallisuuden Seura, 2011 (ISBN 978-952-222-275-6)}}</ref>

column1: At the beginning of Russian rule, the border guard regiments were often changed. The Lappeenranta fortifications were rebuilt in the 1750s. In the 1790s, the castle came under the command of [[Alexander Suvorov]], who continued to develop it as part of the fortification system of southeastern Finland. During the [[List of wars between Russia and Sweden
column2: Russo-Swedish War]], the Saimaa (fi) fleet became the third garrison of Lappeenranta.

column1: In 1785, during the Russian period, the Orthodox Church of Lapinranta was also built, making it the oldest [[Orthodox Church of Finland
column4: pages=Suomi on venäläinen. Yle TV1, 15.2.2015. directeur: Tommi Pietiläinen, producteur Antti Seppänen, présentateur Juhani Seppänen.}}</ref>

column1: == The camp of prisoners of war ==
After the [[Finnish Civil War]], the [[White Guard (Finland)
column2: White Guards (Finland)]] established the Lappeenranta prison camp at the castle, which was notorious for the arbitrary executions that took place there. This camp had nearly 3000 [[Red Guards (Finland)
column3: Red Guard]] prisoners, about 500 of whom were executed.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: 73692350,Biafra_Republic_Government_in_Exile,"<!-- Please do not remove or change this AfD message until the discussion has been closed. -->

The [[Indigenous People of Biafra]] Republic Government in Exile officially the '''Biafra Republic Government in Exile''' is the present legitimate provisional government of the formerly known ""[[Biafra
column2: Republic of Biafra]]"".<ref>Biafra Republic Government in Exile officially formed.</ref>{{better source

column1: Biafra was officially an independent state that existed from 1967 to 1970. Its territory was ceded back to Nigeria after the war for separation ended on January 15, 1970. Biafran vice president and chief of general staff, Major General Philip Effiong, who assumed leadership of the Republic of Biafra after the original President, Colonel Chukwuemeka Odumegwu Ojukwu, exiled to Ivory coast, conceded to the Nigerian state.<ref>{{Cite web
column2: title=""No Victor and No Vanquished"" - Fifty Years after the Biafran War

column1: In what seemed to be the revival of Biafran course, the government was re-established on April 8, 2023 with headquarters in Maryland, US.
The government was set up to reclaim Biafra from Nigeria. Its core agenda is to liberate Biafra out from Nigeria and re-establish a sovereign, independent [[Republic of Biafra]] once again.
On April 9, 2023, [[Simon Ekpa]] was Officially announced the [[prime minister]] but it was countered by critics shortly after the development.<ref>{{Cite web
column2: title=Nnamdi Kanu's 'Disciple', Ekpa Writes UN, Announces Himself As Prime Minister Of Biafra Government In Exile, Lists Other Ministers, Office Holders {{!}} Sahara Reporters
column9: title=Ohanaeze reacts to Simon Ekpa's claim of being Biafran Prime Minister
column13: language=en-GB}}</ref> The [[Government in exile]] has written to relevant bodies such as UN, EU, ICC, US etc. seeking a date for referendum be granted and it's official recognition.<ref>Biafrans are determined to exit Nigeria,we need a date for referendum - Biafra Republic Government in Exile tells UN, EU, ICC, US and others.</ref>{{better source

column1: <!--lost Territory of Biafra from the current occupying Nigerian state.

government was set up citing the need for Biafra's independence from Nigeria due to what they called ""the Biafra marginalization"". On April 9, 2023, the exiled government dully elected Mr. Simon Ekpa to be the Prime Minister while other Head of departments and ministries of the government were appointed and announced through the o-->
'''María Eugenia Rubio Ríos''', also called ''La Peque'', is a retired [[women's association football
column2: footballer]] who played as a [[Forward (association football)
column3: forward]] for the unofficial [[Mexico women's national football team]] at the [[1970 Women's World Cup
column6: title=Ella es María Eugenia Rubio, 'La Peque', la histórica futbolista mexicana}}</ref> In 2018, she became the first Mexican woman inducted into the [[:es:Salón de la Fama del Fútbol Internacional
column7: International Football Hall of Fame]] in [[Pachuca]], Mexico.<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=María Eugenia 'La Peque' Rubio, la primera mexicana en el Salón de la Fama del Fútbol
column13: trans-title=María Eugenia 'La Peque' Rubio, the first Mexican in the Football Hall of Fame
column22: title=María Eugenia 'La Peque' Rubio: ""Estar en este lugar es tan especial para mí""
column23: trans-title=María Eugenia 'La Peque' Rubio: ""Being in this place is so special for me""
column26: language=es}}</ref> In 1999, she was named the eighth best woman player in [[Concacaf]] during the 20th century.<ref name=""iffhs"">{{cite press release
column28: title=IFFHS CONCACAF WOMEN TEAM OF THE XXth CENTURY (1901-2000)
column31: publisher=[[International Federation of Football History & Statistics]]}}</ref>

column1: In the first match of the 1970 Women's World Cup, contested between Mexico and [[Austria women's national football team
column2: Austria]] in [[Bari, Italy]], Rubio scored the tournament's first goal in the first minute of the match. She scored again in the 31st minute of the match.<ref>{{cite web
column15: last4=Stokkermans}}</ref> Mexico finished the tournament in third place.<ref name=""pp-rubio"">{{cite web
column22: last=Sánchez}}</ref> Rubio was celebrated at the airport upon the team's return from Italy.<ref name=""futbolera-220"">{{cite book
column23: title=Futbolera: a history of women and sports in Latin America

column1: Rubio again scored the tournament's first goal, in the 21st minute against [[Argentina women's national football team
column2: Argentina]], and scored a second in the 49th minute in a 3–1 victory on 15 August 1971.<ref>{{cite newspaper
column19: title=II Campeonato Mundial de Fútbol Femenil (Women) 1971
column28: last3=Morrison}}</ref> She was among the players who requested to be paid before playing in the final match against [[Denmark women's national football team
column29: Denmark]], which Mexico lost to finish second in the tournament.<ref>{{cite news
column31: title=Sports heroines: The Mexicans who made history

column1: Rubio was among the shortest players on the Mexican team, earning her the nickname ''La Peque'' (""the short one""). Her dribbling ability was remarked upon by reports, including one story that suggested she ran through the legs of a taller Austrian defender.<ref name=""futbolera-226"">{{cite book
column2: title=Futbolera: a history of women and sports in Latin America
Sergio]] played professionally for [[Cruz Azul]] and [[C.D. Guadalajara]], where he was nicknamed ''El Peque''.<ref name=""futbolera-317"">{{cite book
column3: title=Futbolera: a history of women and sports in Latin America

column3: title=Por qué cayó el Partido Colorado
column6: year=2008}}</ref> – April 24, 1978) was a [[Paraguay]]an [[politician]] and [[soldier]] who served as [[List of Presidents of Paraguay
column7: President]] of [[Paraguay]] from September 10, 1949, to May 4, 1954. He was a member of the [[Colorado Party (Paraguay)

column1: Chaves was born on February 15, 1882, in [[Paraguarí]]. His parents were the Portuguese Federico Chaves and his wife Felicia Careaga, from Guaira, Paraguay.<ref>*{{cite book
column4: title=Crónica Histórica Ilustrada del Paraguay III

column1: Chaves, who received his [[law degree]] in 1905, was a longtime leader of the right-of-centre National Republican Association, better known as the [[Colorado Party (Paraguay)
column2: Colorado Party]]. When his party served in a coalition [[government]] in 1946, Chaves was appointed to the [[Supreme court
column3: Supreme Court]]. He served as Paraguay's [[foreign minister]] from 1947. He was elected in April 1949 as [[List of Presidents of the Chamber of Deputies of Paraguay
column4: President of the Chamber of Representatives]],<ref>{{Cite book
column14: date=2021-05-19 }}</ref> and kept that post until he became president in September 1949. He was elected for a three-year term in 1950 and later reelected in 1953. When Chaves tried to strengthen his regime by arming the national police in 1954, a [[1954 Paraguayan coup d'état
column15: coup d'état]] led by General [[Alfredo Stroessner]] on May 4 ended his administration.

column1: Chaves died on 24 April 1978 at the age of 96 in the city of [[Asunción, Paraguay

column1: '''Ancient text corpora''' is the entire collection of texts from the period of [[ancient history]], defined in this article as the period from the beginning of writing up to 300 AD. These corpora are important for the study of [[literature]], [[history]], [[linguistics]], and other fields, and are a fundamental component of the world's [[cultural heritage]].

column4: Greek]] are examples of ancient languages with significant text corpora, although much of these corpora are known to us via transmission (frequently via [[medieval]] [[manuscript]] copies) rather than in their [[historical documents
column5: original form]]. These texts - both transmitted and original - provide valuable insights into the history and culture of different regions of the world, and have been studied for centuries by scholars and researchers.

column1: Through advances in technology and digitization, ancient text corpuses are more accessible than ever before. Tools such as the [[Perseus Digital Library]] and the [[Digital Corpus of Sanskrit]] have made it easier for researchers to access and analyze these texts.

Two types of ancient texts are known to modern scholars – those that have only survived in younger manuscripts, but whose great age is undisputed (this applies to the bulk of the Chinese, Brahmi, Greek, Latin, Hebrew and Avestan tradition), and those known from original inscriptions, papyri and other manuscripts.{{sfn

Counting of the words in each corpus presents significant methodological challenges – in principle, every single occurrence of a word in the text is counted separately, but in the case of parallel transmission of literary texts, only a single transmission is taken into account. Just as the Book of the Dead and the coffin texts are only included in the number given for the Egyptian, the Greek and Latin literary works should only be counted according to one manuscript. If, on the other hand, tombs, royal inscriptions or economic documents of certain ancient languages often show a more or less identical form, this is not evaluated as a purely ""parallel tradition"". The [[Article (grammar)
column2: definite article]] incorporated in languages such as Hebrew, Aramaic, and Greek has no equivalent in most languages, so its frequency would significantly affect the comparability of numbers - this is excluded in the estimates below.{{sfn

column15: <ref>""The Demotic Dictionary Project, based at the Oriental Institute in Chicago, in which the Demotic texts published between 1955 and 1979, with the exception of the definite and indefinite articles and the suffix pronouns, were completely bogged down (J.H. Johnson in S. Grunert & L Hafemann, Textcorpus und Handbuch , Leiden 1999, p. 243), has produced more than 200,000 slips (R.K. Ritner in S.P. Vleeming, Aspects of Demotic Lexicography, Leuven 1987, p. 145). Of course, this represents only a fraction of the total number of known demotic texts, which could be in the region of a million words.</ref>

column3: Greek]] ([[Ancient Greek literature]], [[New Testament]], [[Church Fathers]], etc.)
column17: <ref>""thesaurus linguae Graecae to about 400 AD; note Greek artikel. This corpus also contains writings by the Church Fathers written in Greek. The vocabulary of Greek is completely recorded in the Thesaurus Linguae Graecae, which is published on CDRom by the University of California in Irvine. The currently available version E, in which all texts up to 600 AD and a selection of Byzantine texts from the following epoch are included in their entirety, comes to a total of around 76 million text words. In 1985, when the authors up to 400 AD were mostly scattered (2700 authors), but only 200 authors from the period after 400, the database still contained 57 million words (L. Berkowitz & KA Squitier, Thesaurus Linguae Graecae, Canon of Greek Authors and Works, New York 1986, p. xii f.). Even if the vocabulary of the texts up to AD 300 must still be somewhat smaller and we also want to deduct the numerous examples of the Greek definite article, we can still clearly declare Greek to be the best preserved ancient language within the framework of our specifications.</ref>

column16: <ref>""thesaurus linguae latinae 9 to 10 million words (selective). The vocabulary of Latin can also be estimated to some extent. The Munich-based company Thesaurus Linguae Latinae has all texts up to AD 150 complete and the following texts up to AD 600 selectively bogged down (W. Ehlers, Der Thesaurus Lin guae Latin ae, in Antiquity and Occident 14, 1968, 172ff.) and thereby nine (according to other sources: ten) million slips of slips accumulates. Even if the vocabulary of Latin up to the year 300 AD has not yet been precisely determined, it should be clear that it surpasses that of Egyptian but is below that of Greek. However, the rule of thumb often heard among classical philologists, that there are ten times as many Greek as Latin texts, is exaggerated, at least if one takes our time limit of 300 AD as a basis.</ref>

column24: <ref>Peust estimated > 10,000,000, stating that estimating the disparately published corpus of this language is extremely difficult. As with the Thesaurus Linguae Latinae and the Egyptian Dictionary, the Chicago Assyrian Dictionary (“Assyrian” means Akkadian as a whole, not just its Assyrian dialect) began with a systematic fragmentation of text. When, in 1948, 1,249,000 slips had been reached, the systematic fiddling was stopped and the index was only expanded to include selected slips, so that by 1964 around 1500,000 to 1750,000 entries had come together (I.J. Gelb in CAD Vol. A 7, Chicago 1964, p. xvi). In my estimation, however, this should only be a fraction of the entire Akkadian material. The Assyriologist S.N. Kramer is said to have estimated that there were 500,000 cuneiform tablets (most of the cuneiform texts are in Akkadian). Also of interest is the estimate by A.L. Oppenheims, Ancient Mesopotamia, Chicago 21977, p. 17f., that the private library Assur banipals found in Nineveh contained 1200 to 1500 tablets, the number of lines of which ""would probably reach, if not exceed in bulk, even the size of the M ahabharata with its 190,000 verses"". Far less than half of this library has survived and been published, but on the other hand there are of course many more texts than those in Ashurbanipal's library. Instead of a specific number, I'd like to conclude by conjecturing that the corpus of Akkadian may be of the order of Latin.</ref>

column21: <ref>Sumerian corpus is difficult to estimate. According to W. Sallaberger & A. Westenholz, Mesopotamia: Akkade period and Ur III period, approximations 3, Freiburg/Schw. 1999 (OBO 160/3), p. 128, just under 40,000 administrative and legal documents from the Ur III period that have been published to date, each of which may contain an average of 20 to 30 words, which amounts to a million word forms. However, the total volume will probably remain below that of the Egyptian texts.</ref>

column15: <ref>""The most heavily attested of these languages is Hurrian, which is not related to Hittite. The previously published volumes (1,2, 4, 5, 7, 9) of the corpus of Hurrian language monuments published by V. Haas contain a good 10,000 Hurrian words; MitannikönigsTusrattaanAmenophisITI(ed.J.Friedrich , Asiatic language monuments, Berlin 1932, p. 8 ff.) with approx i s c h e (ed. G.A. Melikisvili, Urartskije klinoobraznyje nadpisi, Moskva 1960, about 10 000 words), which can be considered as a successor language of Hurrian.</ref>

<ref>""1980 600,000 words = 90% of the text material wasted at the chD. Among the cuneiform languages, Hittite, known for the most part through texts from Boghazkoi, the old capital of the Hittite Empire, comes in third place attested. The index boxes of the Chicago Hittite Dictionary contained over 600,000 index cards in 1980, when they had completely bogged down ""over 90 percent"" of the texts published up to that point (H.G. Güterbock & H.A. Hoffner, The Hittite Dictionary, Vol. 3/1 [L ], Chicago 1980, p. xv). In the text material from Boghazkoi, several regional languages from the Hittite sphere of influence are also attested, mostly in the form of Hittite foreign languages Bilinguals of religious content or in the form of foreign-language passages interspersed in Hittite ritual texts.</ref>

<ref>""Another Boghazkoi language that has so far hardly been understood is Hattian . The total mass of the known Hattic text material should not exceed a few thousand words (the texts edited in J. Klinger, Studien zur Reconstruction of the Hattic Cult Layer, Wiesbaden 1996 contain about 500 words); the number will be easier to determine as soon as the announced compilation of texts in the Hattic language by H. Otten & Ch. Rüster (StBo 37) has been published.</ref>

column15: <ref>2,087 Persepolis tablets + royal inscriptions etc. This is the number divided by r. t. hallock published tables. Numerous other panels are still unpublished. see M.W. stolper (http://persepolistablets.blogspot.com/2007/01/what-are-persepolis-fortication.html): “there were as many as 15,000 to 30,000 or more tablets and fragments. Most (thousands of tablets and tens of thousands of fragments) were in the elamite language in cuneiform script.” This is a little-known but comparatively well-attested cuneiform language Elamite used in Persia. A count of the most important publications gives the following: R.T. Hailock, Persepolis Fortification Tablets, Chicago 1969, 2087 clay tablets with about 50,000 words (besides that, many tablets have remained unpublished); F.W. King, The [sc. pre-Achaemenidic] Elamite royal inscriptions, Graz 1965, approx. 10000 words; F.H. Weissbach, Die Keilinschriften der Achaemeniden, Leipzig 1911, approx. 5000 words; GC Cameron, Persepolis Treasury Tablets, Chicago 1948, about 5000 words. With all the Elamite material published so far, one will get close to 100,000 words.</ref>

<ref>""c after englund 1998, 22 note. 8: 1,450 published texts from susa and 146 unpublished texts. This does not include the 1435 known written in the Proto-Elamic script, which was only partially deciphered Benen panels from the third millennium (ed.P.Meriggi, Lascrituraproto-elamica, 3 vols., Roma 1971/4), which contain around 20,000 characters, most of which can be read logographically.</ref>

<ref>2,436 complete panels, 13947 fragments of different sizes. After I. samir, see appendix 1 below to the national Museum of Syria, Idlib for a breakdown of the fragments by size. Peust assumed 1,800 tablets and 15,000 fragments. The oldest known Semitic language is Eblaitic from the third millennium, discovered only in the 1970s, of which 1800 intact, often quite extensive clay tablets were found along with around 15,000 fragments (G.Pettinato, CatalogodeitesticuneiformidiTeilMardikh-Ebla, Napoli 1979, p. xvi f.). The 3,000 or so pieces published to date (G. Conti, Index of Eblaitic texts published or cited, Firenze 1992) should contain around 300,000 words.</ref>

<ref>""The Ugaritic cuneiform alphabetic texts collected in M. Dietrich et al, The Cuneiform Alphabetic Texts, Munster 21995 comprise about 40000 words. There is also an insignificant number of Ugaritic glosses in syllabic cuneiform.</ref>

<ref>""The Old Persian cuneiform inscriptions (ed.R.G.Kent,Old Persian,New Haven 1953) contain about 7000 words; the linguistically closely related Avesta texts (ed. K.F. Geldner, Avesta, 3 vols., Stuttgart 1896), which have survived only in recent manuscripts, contain around 100,000 words</ref>

column18: <ref>""The Hebrew Old Testament contains about 305,500 words (these and the following numbers from D.J.A. Clines, The dictionary of Classical Hebrew, Vol. 1 (Vi), Sheffield 1993, p. 28), plus 38,349 words from the Qumran texts, 7020 wor ter come from the apocryphal book of Ben Sira and 2528 words from the inscriptional material. From this we want to subtract the 34,622 instances for the definite article H, and one can also argue about the 62,760 cases of 1 ""and"", which is grammaticalized in a special way in Hebrew; in any case, the corpus of Ancient Hebrew is of the order of 300,000 words.</ref>

column2: Aramaic (ancient, imperial, biblical, Hasmonean, Nabataean, Palmyrenean)
column14: <ref>The corpus of Aramaic is fragmented into numerous dialects and quite confusing. First of all, there are old Aramaic inscriptions from the first half of the first millennium BC ([[Kanaanäische und Aramäische Inschriften]]) with about 4000 words Documents from Egypt exist ([[Textbook of Aramaic Documents from Ancient Egypt]]; the first three volumes contain approx. 20,000 words), but it is also preserved in numerous other inscriptions and documents. Imperial Aramaic also includes the Aramaic text of Papyrus Amherst 63, written in Egyptian-Demotic script, which must contain around 3000 words, but has only been published in extracts in several essays (e.g. Ch.F. Nims & R.C. Steiner in Journal of the American Oriental Society 103, 1983, 261ff.). The Aramaic passages of the Old Textament (""Biblical Aramaic"", above all Daniel 2.4b7.28; Ezra 4.86.18 and 7.1226) are closely related to Imperial Aramaic with a volume of a good 5000 words. It is followed by the Hasmonean, which is found above all in Atapocrypha and Targumen from Qumran, but is also attested in Judean documents (ed. Klaus Beyer, The Aramaic Texts from the Dead Sea, Göttingen 1984, p. 157318); 15,000 words in total. With emphasis in 1.3. century AD the Nabataean and the Palmyrenean are attested in about 1000 grave and votive inscriptions each. The total Aramaic corpus available up to this time is probably not much less than 100,000 words. From about 300 AD the Aramaic text corpus increases in leaps and bounds, since several major literary languages are now developing (Syriac, Mandean, Galilean, Samaritan).</ref>
<ref>""The corpus of Phoenician including Punic (ed. H. Donner&W.Röllig, Canaanite and Aramaic Inscriptions, Wiesbaden 2196669) amounts to around 10,000 words.</ref>

column17: <ref>""P. stein states that 10500 (information from 2.10.2007). Peust reckoned with 8,000 inscriptions. According to Stein, the texts are divided as follows: Sabaean: 5,300 texts; Qataban: 2,000; Minaean: 1,200, Haḍramite: 1,500; other/uncertain: 500. The corpus will be further increased by the chopsticks, which will be published bit by bit.g P. Stein also sent me this number (information from October 2nd, 2007). Peust reckoned with more than 100,000 words. According to Stein, the words break down as follows: Sabaean: 85,000 words; Qataban: 11,000; Minaean: 11,000; haTMramite: 5,000; other: 500. The corpus of the Old South Arabic languages has been published in scattered publications and is difficult to survey. The old compilations in the Corpusinscriptionum semiticarum (ed. Academiedes InscriptionsetBellesLettres), pars4inscriptiones himyariti- casetsabceascontinens, 3 vols., Paris 18891931 and in the Repertoire d'epiographie semitique (ed. G. Ryckmans), vols. 57, Paris 19291936 (volume 8, which is also relevant, was not accessible to me) contains around 3,000 texts with over 50,000 words. Included it must be taken into account that a (smaller) part of these texts dates from after 300 AD, but on the other hand the number of known Old South Arabic texts has increased considerably since then, according to J. Ryckmansetal, Textes du Yemenantiqueinscrits sur bois, Louvain 1994, p. 25 on "" plus the 8000 inscriptions"". Thus, a stock of well over 100,000 words can now be assumed. The Old South Arabic texts are mainly in Sabaean, but also in other languages such as Written in M inaean, Qataban and Hadramautic, although the attribution of some shorter monuments remains uncertain; I have to do without a determination of the amount of text broken down according to the individual languages here.</ref>

<ref>In ancient Italy there were many other languages besides Latin. Quantitatively the best attested is the still barely understandable Etruscan (corpus compiled in H.Rix, EtruskischeTexte, Editiominor, 2 vols., Tübingen 1991), which is known from several thousand almost all very short texts with a total of around 25,000 words;</ref>
