column1: There are significant number of ancient micro-corpus languages. Estimating the total number of attested ancient languages may be as difficult as estimating their corpus size. For example, Greek and Latin sources hand down an enormous amount of foreign-language glosses, the seriousness of which is not always certain.{{sfn

column3: Conservation and restoration of cultural property}}

column1: [[Historic preservation]] and maintaining ancient text corpuses presents several challenges, including issues with preservation, translation, and digitization. Many ancient texts have been lost over time, and those that survive may be damaged or fragmented. Translating ancient languages and scripts requires specialized expertise, and digitizing texts can be time-consuming and resource-intensive.

The field of [[corpus linguistics]] studies language as expressed in text corpora. This includes the analysis of word frequency, collocations, grammar, and semantics. Ancient text corpuses provide a valuable resource for corpus linguistics research, enabling scholars to explore the evolution of language and culture over time.
* [[List of languages by first written account]]

73694041,Eternal_functional_subordination,"'''Eternal functional subordination''' or '''Eternal subordination of the Son''' is a [[Trinity
column2: Trinitarian]] doctrine which proposes a hierarchy within the trinity, where though the Son is ontologically equal to the Father, He is subordinate in role, obeying the Father in eternity. Advocates of eternal subordination generally see this as a model for human relationships. Eternal Subordination is contrasted with the view held by [[Augustine of Hippo
column3: Augustine]], where the obedience of the Son to the Father is only by virtue of His human nature. The main advocates of the doctrine are [[Wayne Grudem]] and [[Bruce A. Ware
column5: title=Trinitarian Agency and the Eternal Subordination of the Son: An Augustinian Perspective
column12: title=Why Should Evangelicals Reject the Eternal Subordination of the Son? Michael Bird and Matthew Barrett - Credo Magazine
column17: title=Another Thirteen Evangelical Theologians Who Affirm the Eternal Submission of the Son to the Father
column25: title=Eternal Functional Subordination of the Son (EFS), Part I: Why It Misunderstands God
column30: title=Question & Answer: The Orthodox Presbyterian Church

column1: [[Wayne Grudem]] argued that the doctrine has been affirmed by many theologians within the last few centuries, including [[Carl F. H. Henry]], [[Jonathan Edwards (theologian)
column3: Charles Ryrie]], [[Charles Hodge]] and others. However, his interpretation of some of these theologians has been challenged.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=A Response To Grudem’s Appeal To Hodge On Eternal Subordination

column12: language=en}}</ref> Eternal Functional Subordination stands in contrast to the views of [[Augustine of Hippo
column13: Augustine]] and [[Thomas Aquinas]], who denied any such relations. The doctrine is also contrary to the [[Westminster Confession of Faith
column15: title=Trinitarian Agency and the Eternal Subordination of the Son: An Augustinian Perspective
column29: title=Does Eternal Subordination Compromise Biblical Orthodoxy? Liam Goligher and Matthew Barrett - Credo Magazine
column35: title=Review: Simply Trinity by Matthew Barrett

column1: [[Wayne Grudem]] holds that the Son eternally submits to the Father, arguing that authority is not an attribute of God but of relationship. Grudem however denies that the doctrine of eternal subordination implies three wills in God, instead saying that God has one will but three distinctive expressions of that will.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Why a denial of the Son’s eternal submission threatens both the Trinity and the Bible

column1: 73694203,777_Partners,"'''777 Partners''' is an American private investment company based in [[Miami]]. Founded in 2015, it has acquired several [[association football
column2: soccer]]<!--Do not change to football, company is American, page is in American English--> teams such as [[Genoa C.F.C.]] in Italy, [[Standard Liège]] in Belgium, [[Red Star F.C.]] in France, [[CR Vasco da Gama]] in Brazil and [[Hertha BSC]] in Germany. It has minority shareholdings in [[Sevilla FC]] in Spain and [[Melbourne Victory FC]] in Australia. The company owns the [[British Basketball League]] and its [[London Lions (basketball)
column3: London Lions]] team. The company also owns the [[low-cost carrier]]s [[Flair Airlines]] in Canada and [[Bonza (airline)

column1: 777 Partners was founded in 2015 by Joshua Wander and Steven Pasko. Its first investment in soccer was to purchase a minority stake in Spanish [[La Liga]] club [[Sevilla FC]] in 2018.<ref name=aarons>{{cite news
column4: title=Collective goals: multi-club ownership is changing world football’s landscape
column8: date=April 4, 2023}}</ref> In 2020, it elevated its share to 7.5%.<ref>{{cite news
column11: title=‘777 Partners’ adquiere el paquete de Rodri y eleva su capital al 7,5%
column12: trans-title='777 Partners' acquires Rodri's stake and raises its capital to 7.5%

column1: In September 2021, 777 Partners bought 99.99% of Italian [[Serie A]] club [[Genoa C.F.C.]], the country's oldest club, founded in 1893. It became the sixth club in the league to have an American owner, and the transaction to buy the club from long-term owner [[Enrico Preziosi]] was estimated at €150 million.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Italian club Genoa bought by U.S. investment firm 777 Partners
column6: date=23 September 2021}}</ref> The club hired former [[A.C. Milan]] and [[Ukraine national football team
column7: Ukraine]] striker [[Andriy Shevchenko]] in November, firing him in January;<ref>{{cite news
column8: title=Genoa sack Shevchenko after only two months in charge
column12: date=January 15, 2022}}</ref> Genoa ended the season relegated, as did another US-owned team, [[Venezia F.C.
column16: title=American owned clubs struggle: Bordeaux, Genoa and Venezia sought stability but found relegation

column1: In February 2022, 777 Partners bought 70% of [[CR Vasco da Gama]], a [[Campeonato Brasileiro Série A]] club from [[Rio de Janeiro]] for [[Brazilian real
column3: title=Vasco faz acordo para vender 70% do clube por R$ 700 milhões
column4: trans-title=Vasco reach agreement to sell 70% of the club for R$700 million
column9: language=Portuguese}}</ref> During the negotiations, Brazilian newspaper ''[[O Globo]]'' revealed that Wander had been convicted in 2004 for ordering [[cocaine]] in the mail while a 22-year-old student of the [[University of Florida]].<ref name=aarons/><ref>{{cite news
column10: title=Vasco: condenação de Josh Wander por tráfico de 31g de cocaína, de 2004, repercute nas redes sociais; 777 diz que ‘incidente ficou para trás’
column11: trans-title=Vasco: Josh Wander's sentence for trafficking 31g of cocaine, in 2004, reverberates on social networks; 777 says that 'the incident stays in the past'
column16: language=Portuguese}}</ref> Facing a possible 26-year sentence, he pleaded [[no contest]] and received 15 years of probation, that ended in 2018.<ref>{{cite news
column17: title=Alabama man indicted, faces murder charges

column1: In March 2022, 777 Partners bought 100% of [[Standard Liège]] in the [[Belgian Pro League]] for €55 million.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Le Standard de Liège officialise sa reprise par le fonds d'investissement américain 777 Partners
column3: trans-title=Standard Liège confirm their acquisition by the American investment firm 777 Partners
column8: language=French}}</ref> The following month, it bought [[Red Star F.C.]] of the French third-tier [[Championnat National]]; the club was founded in 1897 by [[Jules Rimet]], who was later president of [[FIFA]]. The takeover was met with backlash due to the club's working-class and left-wing history, and concerns that the club would become a [[farm team]] for 777's other assets. Former presidential candidate [[Jean-Luc Mélenchon]] was one of several politicians to sign a letter published in ''[[Le Monde]]'', stating ""For us, Red Star is a common good that cannot be sacrificed on the altar of profit.""<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=French left cries foul over US takeover of Red Star soccer club

column1: In October 2022, 777 Partners bought a minority stake in [[Melbourne Victory FC]] of the Australian [[A-League Men]].<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=A-League club joins portfolio of Miami-based 777 Partners
column8: date=October 5, 2022}}</ref> The following March, the company took a 64.7% stake in [[Hertha BSC]] of the German [[Bundesliga]] after its sale by [[Lars Windhorst]], who had been majority shareholder since 2019.<ref>{{cite news
column11: title=Miami-based 777 Partners takes 64.7% stake in Hertha Berlin

column2: London Lions]] basketball team. The company bought 45% of the [[British Basketball League]] for £7 million in December 2021. Company vice president Adam Weiss told the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' in February 2022 that the sport could grow in the UK in the way that it had grown in Canada in the last 30 years.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=EXCLUSIVE: London Lions owner claims capital can emulate Toronto to become new basketball hotbed

column5: title=The US private equity giant funding Australia’s new budget airline Bonza

column2: Σαράνταινα; Όρος Οξιά}}) is a mountain in Greece with a peak of the same name, part of the [[Southern Pindus]] massif.

column1: The name carries both the highest peak at 1,923 meters above sea level and the entire mountain. Its alternative name in Greek is [[Oxya]], which comes from (The) '''Beech mountain''' — a name by which it is denoted in Bulgarian. In Bulgarian, the name of the mountain means [[roebuck]] or [[Macrolepiota procera]].
The northwestern edge of the mountain is called [[Kokalia]] ({{lang-el
column2: Κοκκάλια}}) with the etymology of ""bone"" in Bulgarian or bones. This ridge connects the mountain with the [[Tymfristos]] massif to the northwest. To the southeast, the mountain is connected to a common ridge with Mount [[Vardousia]]. South of the mountain is another prominent mountain from the Southern Pindus — [[Kokinia]]. In this mountain is the most extensive ''[[beech]] forest'', and in Kokinia is the southernmost ''beech area''. Precisely because it is a Beech mountain, it is included in the ''[[Pindus]] massif'', although in antiquity this name was borne by the river with the settlement of [[Pindus (city)]], located in a straight line twenty kilometers southeast of the mountain.

column1: To the west of the mountain massif are scattered numerous mountain elevations which collectively bear the name Southern Pind. Among them the highest is [[Kaliakouda]].

Between the villages of [[Gardiki Omilaion]] in [[Makrakomi]] and [[Grammeni Oxya]] there is a mountain road along a pass on which the [[armatoles]] in the winter of 1828/29 kept the new Ottoman army from entering [[Kravara]].<ref>[http://www.dimosmakrakomis.gov.gr/episkeptes/axiotheata/386-oxua-sarantaina Οξυά - Σαράνταινα]</ref>

column2: caption             = Lakha as the Lord Mayor of Coventry

office2 = Member of [[Coventry City Council]]
for [[Binley and Willenhall]]

column1: '''Ram Parkash Lakha''' [[Order of the British Empire
column2: OBE]] was [[Lord Mayor of Coventry]] for 2005 to 2006.<ref name=""auto1"">{{Cite web
column4: title=At last - Ram gets turn to be lord mayor
column8: website=CoventryLive}}</ref> He was first elected in May 1989 in Upper Stoke Ward. Then after with one years’ absence, he was elected in May 1991 to represent Binley and Willenhall Ward and has been serving this ward as Labour Councillor since then.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Councillor details - Councillor Ram Parkash Lakha OBE

column1: Lakha was born into a [[Ravidasia]] Sikh family in a small village (Nawan Pind Naicha) in the Indian Punjab in 1949. Lakha gained a degree in economics, politics, and English from [[Panjab University]], later working as a civil servant before coming to Coventry in 1977.<ref name=""auto1""/>

He was appointed Deputy Lord Mayor of Coventry for 2004 to 2005 and then [[Lord Mayor of Coventry]] for 2005 to 2006. He served on the West Midlands Fire and Civil Defence Authority for one year as a representative of the council and also served as a non-executive director of Whitefriars Housing Group. He was a governor of Coventry Technical College during 1989–1990 and served as a school governor at Stoke Park Secondary School for over ten years. He is currently the school governor at Willenhall Community Primary School.

During his tenure as president of the Shri Guru Ravidass Sabha UK, he helped the development of the Shri Guru Ravidass Technical College in Phagwara, Punjab, by supporting the fundraising efforts.<ref name=""auto"">{{Cite web
column3: title=Cllr Ram Parkash Lakha OBE – Global Ambedkarite Convention}}</ref>

column1: He was a victim of political caste discrimination during the initial days of his political life.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2006/jul/04/india.world#:~:text=The%20former%20mayor%20of%20Coventry,a%20derogatory%20name%20for%20Dalits%5D.</ref> He faced caste discrimination from the Indian Brahmin and Jatt communities in Coventry because they could not tolerate him on the front lines of politics. Hence, they organised his deselection as a Labour Party candidate at the end of his one-year term in 1990. Because of his work within the Labour Party, he was selected from Binley and Willenhall Wards by all ""white"" members of the Labour Party in 1991. With their support, he won the election, and since then, he has carried on being selected as a Labour candidate and winning to continue as a Labour councillor.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Hindu Groups in UK Hit Back at British Government's Plans to Ban Caste-Based Discrimination

column2: Association football club in Angus, Scotland, UK}}

column1: '''Angus Football Club''' was an [[association football]] club from [[Forfar]] in [[Scotland]].  Although it was entirely unsuccessful as a club, it was instrumental in the formation of [[Forfar Athletic]].

column3: Forfar Athletic 3–1 Angus, Scottish Cup 1st round, 1885–86, from the Dundee Courier, 14 September 1885]]

column1: The club was founded in 1880.  Although the first club senior club in the town, it remained a small outfit for the first half of its existence; with 25 members in 1882, it was still the smallest senior club in [[Forfarshire]].<ref>{{cite book
Angus first entered the [[Scottish Cup]] in [[1882–83 Scottish Cup
column3: Balgay]] 1–0, a second Balgay goal not being allowed as the goalposts had been knocked down in the struggle around the ball.<ref>{{cite journal

column1: A one-goal defeat was Angus' best result in the competition.  In [[1883–84 Scottish Cup
column2: 1883–84]] the club went down 9–0 at the strong [[Dundee Harp F.C.
column3: Dundee Harp]] side, and in [[1884–85 Scottish Cup
column4: the following season]] 5–1 at home to [[Strathmore F.C. (Dundee)
column6: title=Scottish Association Cup Ties - Northern District
column9: page=4}}</ref>  Angus was just as unsuccessful in its two [[Forfarshire Cup]] entries, losing 3–0 at home to Tay Bank of Dundee - a junior side - in 1884–85<ref>{{cite journal
column13: page=8}}</ref> and 2–0 at home to [[Dundee West End F.C.

column1: ===The cuckoo in the nest: Angus Athletic===
Angus strengthened in September 1883 by taking over the Forfar East End junior club, the East End side becoming the Angus second XI, taking on the name of '''Angus Athletic'''.<ref>{{cite journal
column5: page=4}}</ref>  This meant that by 1884 Angus had 37 members, but was still much smaller than any of the [[Dundee]] clubs.<ref>{{cite book
column12: page=70}}</ref>   The Angus Athletic took part in junior <ref>{{cite journal
column13: title=Angus Athletic (Forfar) v East End Wanderers (Dundee)
column16: page=3}}</ref> and second XI competitions in the county; in 1884–85 the Athletics finished as runner-up in the Forfarshire Second XI cup, losing 4–1 to the Dundee Harp reserves in the final.<ref>{{cite journal
column17: title=Forfarshire Second Eleen Association - Final Cup Tie

column1: The Athletics also occasionally played senior sides in friendlies.<ref>{{cite journal
column5: page=4}}</ref>  In 1884–85, the Athletics played the nearby [[Lindertis F.C.
column6: Lindertis]] side on at least three occasions, with wins of 4–2 and 6–1 (at home)<ref>{{cite journal

column1: ===Forfar Athletic formation and demise of Angus===
Senior football grew hugely in Forfar in 1885. Angus increased its membership to 60.<ref>{{cite book
column8: page=72}}</ref>  However, towards the end of the season, the Angus Athletic split away to form  a new club, '''Forfar Athletic'''.  Its last match as Angus Athletic was a 5–4 win over the Alpine club of [[Arbroath]] on 2 May 1885;<ref>{{cite journal
column12: page=4}}</ref> its first recorded match as Forfar Athletic was against Our Boys Rangers of Dundee on 16 May 1885.<ref>{{cite journal
column13: title=Our Boys Rangers v Forfar (late Angus) Athletic
column16: page=4}}</ref>  The Forfar match secretary (James Black) had been the East End secretary in 1883,<ref>{{cite journal
column20: page=4}}</ref>  and Angus' honorary secretary the previous season.<ref>{{cite book
column27: page=70}}</ref>  The new club acquired 40 members before the 1885–86 season started.<ref>{{cite book

column1: The Athletics joined the Forfarshire Football Association in June, alongside the Angus.<ref>{{cite journal
column5: page=5}}</ref> The key match between the sides came in the first round of the [[1885–86 Scottish Cup]].  It was Forfar's first match in the competition; it proved to be Angus' last.  Angus had warmed up for the match with a rare big win the previous week, 5–1 at Dalhousie,<ref>{{cite journal
column9: page=3}}</ref> and took the lead in the tie, but did not take enough advantage of having the conditions in its favour in the first half, and went down 3–1.  On the Forfar side, eight of the players - Ogilvie, Christie, Stormont, Smith, Menzies, Anderson, Samson, and Lamond - had played for Angus Athletic in the Second XI Cup final the previous season, and one more player (Black) was the Forfar nominated umpire for the tie.  None of the Angus Athletic players was playing for Angus.

column1: The result of the tie switched momentum to the new club.  By 1886, Angus was stuck on 60 members,<ref>The Angus formed a replacement Angus Athletics reserve XI which played one tie in the 2d Eleven Cup, losing 6–1 at home to Strathmore Athletics of Dundee; Dundee Courier, 21 September 1885, p. 4</ref> while the Athletic had risen to 150 members, and was one of the biggest clubs in the county.<ref>{{cite book
column7: page=62}}</ref>  The nail was driven in in the Forfarshire Cup; Angus went out in the first round while Forfar reached the semi-final.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Angus nearly had one slight moment of retribution against Forfar, in a friendly on 7 November 1885 at Station Park, in which Angus was 3–1 up at half-time and still 4–3 up early in the second half; however, the play was ""brought to an abrupt conclusion"" and the match abandoned.<ref>{{cite journal
Given this sweeping rise of a rival club, Angus shut up shop. its final reported match was a 7–2 defeat at [[Montrose F.C.
column6: page=3}}</ref> and it was struck off the association membership roll for non-payment of subscriptions in August 1886.<ref>{{cite book

column1: The club played in 2"" hooped<ref>{{cite book
column8: page=72}}</ref>  blue and black jerseys and hose, with white knickers.<ref>{{cite book

column1: The club's ground was originally at Bankhead Farm, 5 minutes' walk from [[Forfar railway station]]<ref>{{cite book
column8: page=143}}</ref> owned by Andrew Christie.  When the club decided to move, it presented Mr Christie with a portrait.<ref>{{cite journal
column12: page=8}}</ref>  The Angus Athletic reserves played  on Market Muir.<ref>{{cite journal

column1: In the 1884–85 season, the club moved to [[Station Park, Forfar
column2: Station Park]], shared with the new Forfar Athletic club.<ref>{{cite book
column9: page=72}}</ref>  The first match reported match played there, with the ""wet and sloppy"" pitch described as ""a field behind the station"", was an Angus Athletic game against [[Partick Thistle]] at the start of 1885, which ended in a 1–1 draw.<ref>{{cite journal

column1: The name of the mountain is explained by the fact that it sheltered the Bulgarian soldiers defeated in the [[Battle of Spercheios]].<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Βουλγάρα, ένα ανέγγιχτο βουνό με ιστορία στο δίκτυο ορειβατικών διαδρομών Αγράφων Καρδίτσας

column1: The mountain is sparsely populated, with nine inhabitants per square kilometer. Mixed forests and Bulgarian fir prevail. The average annual temperature in the area is 11 °C. The warmest month is July when the average temperature is 22 °C and the coldest is January with 2 °C. The average annual amount of precipitation is 1051 mm.{{citation needed

column3: 2А70}}) is a model of low-pressure [[rifled cannon]]s designed in the Soviet Union by the [[KBP Instrument Design Bureau]]. Integrated into Bakhcha-U and Sinitsa turret modules, the gun equips the [[BMD-4]], [[BMD-3]], and [[BTR-90M]] [[infantry fighting vehicle]]s. It is capable of launching the [[high-explosive fragmentation]] (HE-FRAG) 3OF32 and 3OF70 projectiles, as well as the [[9M117 Bastion]] [[List of gun-launched missiles
column4: gun-launched]] [[anti-tank guided missile]]s (ATGM) and related systems.

فوربرنقا}}) is a town located in [[West Darfur]], Sudan.

column1: The villagers from 20 villages near Foro Baranga town held a demonstration over the lack of availability of the new currency in front of the city council on 14 August 2011.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Protests in Foro Baranga over lack of currency

column1: An armed militia robbed Foro Baranga court, Zakat Bureau office, and six shops on 25 November 2013.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Militiamen attack bus, lorries, shops, and a court in three Darfur states
column8: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> On 30 March 2014 midnight, a fire incident that razed down 18 houses occurred in El Kifah neighborhood.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Fire destroys 18 houses in West Darfur’s Foro Baranga

column1: On 29 May 2021, a protest occurred in Foro Baranga in response to the death of one man killed by an unknown armed group in the Foro Baranga market. The protestors blocked the main roads. They torched shops in the market, administrative offices, the Zakat chamber, and the tax office. Security forces were deployed to ease the tensions.<ref name=""FB"">{{cite web
column4: title=Angry protests follow deadly West Darfur market attack

column2: Masalit]] and Arabs occurred in Foro Baranga on 10 and 11 April 2023. The militia burned houses in six neighborhoods and looted civilian belongings. This attack caused the death of 25 people and displaced 20.000 people from Foro Baranga and the surrounding areas. Responding to this ethnic strife, the West Darfur government imposed a curfew for two weeks from 19:00 to 07:00 in Foro Baranga.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=At least 25 dead, thousands displaced following West Darfur violence

column1: On 15 April 2023, a clash [[Rapid Support Forces]] between [[Sudanese Armed Forces]] happened in Foro Baranga.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Deaths and injuries as  clashes continue  between the army and the Rapid Support Forces in El Fasher

column1: There is a market in Foro Baranga. The market holds importance for camel trading.<ref>{{cite report
column4: title=Trade and Market Bulletin West Darfur

'''Fort Rapids''' was a [[hotel]] and [[water park]] located in [[Columbus, Ohio]].
Fort Rapids was constructed alongside the existing [[Holiday Inn]] ''Columbus East'' hotel. The hotel was renovated as part of the project. It opened in 2006.<ref>{{Cite web

'''Wanda Szuman''' or '''Szumanówna''' (1890–1994) was a Polish educator.
She was born on 3 April 1890 in [[Toruń]], Poland (then [[Kingdom of Prussia
column2: Prussia]]), and died on 1 December 1994 aged 104.<ref name=torun /> Her parents were Eugenię Gumpert and surgeon Leon Szuman, a surgeon. She had six siblings. Her mother died in 1895 and her father married her aunt, Emilię Osiecką (née Gumpert). Wanda attended the Sacred Heart Sisters' Gymnasium in [[Lviv]]. In 1911 she went to [[Kraków]] and graduated from the seminary Sebaldy Műnichowa. In 1914 she co-founded Wełnianka, an education club for young women.<ref>{{cite book
column7: title=Wanda Szuman - pedagog i andragog specjalny : szkice do portretu
column9: publisher=Wydawnictwo Naukowe Instytutu Technologii Eksploatacji - PIB
column15: chapter=Historia życia Wandy Szuman}}</ref> Szuman later became a Polish national. While living in Warsaw she was superintendent of a seminary.<ref>''Official Journal''. (1932). Switzerland: League of Nations. p. 2238</ref>

column1: She ""is considered a pioneer of Polish special education"" and worked particularly with orphans and children with special needs.<ref name=torun />
She was awarded the [[Order of Polonia Restituta]] in 1923, described as ""''referentka kuratorjum szkolnego pomorskie''"" (clerk to the Pomeranian school board),<ref>{{cite book
column2: title=Order Odrodzenia Polski : trzechlecie pierwszej kapituły : 1921-1924
column5: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> and in 1992 was given honorary citizenship of the city of [[Toruń]].<ref name=torun>{{cite web

column1: [[File:Tablice informacyjna i pamiątkowa Przedszkola Miejskiego Nr 1 imienia Wandy Szuman w Toruniu.jpg
column4: Plaque on a nursery school named in Szuman's honour]]

column1: In 1931 in Warsaw, Szuman initiated a special committee arranging for the placement of children in [[foster care]]. Children up to the age of two were placed in the homes of families that had few or no children.<ref>Schilde, K. (2005). ''Need and Care: Glimpses Into the Beginnings of Eastern Europe's Professional Welfare''. Germany: Barbara Budrich Publishers. p. 189</ref>
A school in Turuń is named in her honour: VII Liceum Ogólnokształcące im. Wandy Szuman,<ref>{{cite web
column4: publisher=VII Liceum Ogólnokształcące im. Wandy Szuman
column5: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> as is a nursery school.<ref>See image of plaque for Przedszkola Miejskiego Nr 1 imienia Wandy Szuman w Toruniu</ref>

column1: A book ''Wanda Szuman - pedagog i andragog specjalny : szkice do portretu'' (Wanda Szuman - pedagogue and special andragogue: sketches for a portrait) was published in 2009 by Beata Borowska-Beszta ({{ISBN
column5: title=Wanda Szuman pedagog i andragog specjalny - szkice do portretu
column8: access-date=1 May 2023}}[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Beata-Borowska-Beszta/publication/215473102_Wanda_Szuman_pedagog_i_andragog_specjalny_-_szkice_do_portretu/links/589dbbdb45851598bab3fe78/Wanda-Szuman-pedagog-i-andragog-specjalny-szkice-do-portretu.pdf Full text as pdf]</ref>

column5: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> is an under construction RRTS station in Ghaziabad district, [[Uttar Pradesh]], India which will serves mainly [[Higher-speed rail
column6: higher-speed]] trains. It will serve as a elevated station for higher-speed trains on the [[Delhi–Meerut Regional Rapid Transit System]] that can reach speeds of up to 180 km/h. The station will be powered by solar energy, with 1,100 solar panels on the station's roof.<ref name=""timesofindia-indiatimes2"">{{cite web
column8: title=Ghaziabad: RRTS station in Sahibabad taking shape, to be  powered by 1,100 solar panels

column1: Sahibabad RRTS station is likely to be commissioned in 2023 along with the 17 km long Sahibad-Duhaiyya section of [[Delhi–Meerut Regional Rapid Transit System
column4: title=RRTS section nears launch, but links to metro, bus stand will take longer
column10: title=Delhi-Meerut RRTS corridor: Duhai-Sahibabad section likely to open for public by April – Details inside

column1: The [[National Capital Region Transport Corporation]] (NCRTC) had invited tenders for the construction of the Sahibabad RRTS station along with the 7.3 km long Sahibabad ramp–Ghaziabad section of the 82.15 km Delhi-Meerut RRTS line. [[KEC International]] and China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation emerged as the lowest bidder for construction work. As a result, KEC International and [[China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation]] has been awarded a Rs 579.76 crore contract responsible for Package 1 (Sahibabad ramp–Ghaziabad) in August 2019. Under the agreement, companies started construction of Sahibabad RRTS station.<ref name=""themetrorailguy1"">{{cite web
column2: title=APCO-CRFG & KEC-CCECC Resume Work on Delhi – Meerut RRTS Line

column1: The Sahibabad RRTS station will have 2 elevated station platforms, With the under constructed station building will be located underneath of platform level. The RRTS station will have 2 [[Side platform
column2: side platforms]], which will serve 2 rail tracks for regular service.

column1: It will have three levels - platform, concourse and street level. Sahibabad RRTS station will be 215 meters long and 26 meters wide. The rail tracks will be constructed at a height of 24 meters above the ground level.<ref name=""msn"">{{cite web
column2: title=Delhi-Meerut RRTS update: Ghaziabad station to have 5 exits, to be linked with Naya Bus Stand Metro Station

column1: There are a total of 2 entrances and exits, 1 on each side of the mezzanine level. An entry and exit from the south side of the mezzanine floor crosses Madan Mohan Malviya Marg and is connected to the ground at Loh Purush Drada Sardar Patel Udyan. Another entrance and exit connects northern side of the station's mezzanine floor with the ground floor in front of the Sahibabad Bus Depot Petrol station.

column14: title=Dragons' Den coffee wannabe gets a roasting but the childhood cutlery sweethearts have their day
column22: title=Dragons' Den: Business lessons from Series 15, Episodes 6, 7 & 8

column1: The company producing the Oomph closed in April 2022, citing the death of one of its founders and financial supporters, as well as the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] as having affected the company.

The device is [[plastic]] and measures 230 x 83 x 83 mm and weighs 0.613 kg. It has a rubber plunger which, when pushed, forces hot water through the ground coffee and into a second chamber. As the device has two chambers, the brewed coffee is no longer in contact with the coffee grounds. The device can then be used as a portable [[cup]].<ref>{{Cite web

column4: Guds nådes husholdning}} ('The Dispensation of God's Grace')

column1: '''Knud Kittelsen Spødervold''' (24 July 1791 – 20 March 1848) was a Norwegian author and [[lay preacher]] and leader of the [[Strong Believers]] ({{Lang
column3: Sterktroende}}), a theologically conservative Norwegian Christian movement in opposition to the [[Haugean movement]], with roots in the [[Lutheranism

column1: Knud Spødervold was born in [[Bjerkreim]], [[Rogaland]], Norway, to farmer Kittel Gulliksen and Marthe Rasmusdatter Osland.<ref name="":2"">{{Citation
column9: language=no}}</ref> He grew up on the Spødervold farm in Bjerkreim. During his childhood he received his education at the [[ambulatory school]] of the time. He was confirmed by provost {{Ill
column14: p=2}} When he herded sheep in his youth, he carried the Bible and the [[Augsburg Confession]] in his backpack. He has been described as an [[Autodidacticism
column24: oclc=1153911989}}</ref> In his youth, Knud is said to have been a teacher in Sirdal for some time. In 1813 his father's farm was divided between Spødervold and his brother Michel.

column1: In 1811, Spødervold was 20 years old and became a soldier in the {{Ill
column4: Vesterlenske infanteriregiment}}; due to the tense relations with Sweden, he was first ordered to [[Larvik]]. During his military service in 1813, Spødervold met priest {{Ill

column1: After his military service, Spødervold returned to his homeland and found work on the farm of the priest {{Ill
column6: p=24}} In 1821 he bought his brother Michel's share of their father's farm, and five years later – on 8 November 1826 – he married Joren Larsdatter Kvitlen (1806–1886).{{Sfn
column9: p=7}}<ref name="":2"" /> They had eight children, but only five survived to adulthood. From 1825, he worked as a teacher and bell-ringer in Sirdal for a time.{{Sfn
column12: p=463}} In 1836 Spødervold and his family moved to the farm Efteland, and in 1842 they moved to Stavanger. He first leased land in Egenes, but later moved to the city and lived in great poverty. He is said to have received financial help from [[Haugean movement

column1: In his time, Spødervold was known for ""his incomparable knowledge of the Bible"", and writer [[Arne Garborg]] refers to him in {{Lang
column6: p=118}} as ""a farmer in Western Norway who belonged to the [[Strong Believers]] and wrote books in defense of this sect"". He was also referred to by writer [[Henrik Wergeland]] in the 1832 {{Lang
column11: title=Henrik Wergeland – samlede skrifter. III. Artikler og småstykker, polemiske og andre
column16: via=[[University of Oslo]]}}</ref> a political and economic journal, as a prophet. Spødervold easily connected with people, and household devotions were common under his leadership.

column3: no}}, he held several meetings in Egersund, which were well attended. Together with {{Ill
column5: no}} he continued the gatherings in 1829. These meetings were reported and a complaint was sent to [[Provost (religion)
column10: no}}. Meldal forwarded the complaint to the bishop of Kristiansand, [[Johan Storm Munch]], who believed it was ""necessary by serious means to inhibit the nuisance of the so-called [[Läsare
column11: ''readers'']] of Bjerkreim parish going around to the villages and holding public religious lectures and speeches to the confusion of the like-minded"".{{Sfn
column14: p=464}} Spødervold and his followers were summoned to see provost Meldal and in 1829 were banned by him from speaking.

column1: Three years later, in 1832, he and some friends, Villads Tollefsen Bjerkreim, and Torger Andersen Fotland, were again reported to the [[Ministry of Culture and Equality
column2: Ministry of Churches and Education]] by Hartvig in Egersund for violation of the [[Conventicle Act (Denmark–Norway)
column3: Conventicle Act]]. The act, in effect until 1842, prohibited lay preachers from holding private religious services ([[Conventicle
column8: no}} to conduct an interrogation. But Schiøtz – because of his own religious views – had no reason to prosecute them. Schiøtz personally interrogated the defendants in June 1832 and sent the case back to the Ministry of Churches. Thereafter, nothing more was heard of the case, and Spødervold and his followers escaped further action.

column1: In 1840, he had followers in a number of areas: Bjerkreim, [[Sirdal]], [[Åseral]], [[Høgsfjord]], [[Stavanger]], [[Egersund]], and [[Helleland]].<ref name="":1"">{{Cite thesis
column5: title=Gammelpietistiske minoriteter : tradisjoner, særtrekk og fellespreg
column9: oclc=492209240}}</ref> The movement would later split into several branches.<ref name="":0"" />

column5: Guds nådes husholdning}} (''The Dispensation of God's Grace''), published in 1848]]

column1: In his later years, Spødervold lived in Stavanger, where he settled in 1842, and it was here that he finished the book {{Lang
column3: Guds nådes husholdning}} ('The Dispensation of God's Grace'), popularly known as {{Lang
column5: Knudabogjæ}} in the local dialect. With its original 90-word title, it consisted of 360 pages of [[Officialese
column6: dense, wordy]] polemic against Haugeans, the [[Moravian Church]], [[Quakers]], and others.<ref name="":2"" /><ref name="":0"" /><ref name="":3"" /> In the book, he takes the reader through the history of the Bible from the creation of the world through Moses and David and the prophets. He shows that there is a struggle between good and evil, between God and the devil. The only remedy against deception is knowledge – a right knowledge of God and his [[God's will
column7: will]]. Through examples from history, he shows God's punishment when people do not want right knowledge and Christian enlightenment.

column1: In the last four chapters, Spødervold shows himself to be a critic of contemporary spiritual movements. He first attacks {{Ill
column3: no}}, who allowed for the possibility of conversion after death. Spødervold disagrees entirely and argues that judgment comes after death.

column1: Throughout his adult life, Spødervold had lived alongside the [[Pietism
column3: Haugean]] revival and had also been in contact with [[Hans Nielsen Hauge]].<ref name="":3"" /> However, he had very little sympathy for Hauge and his views, since his teachings and writings were permeated by the system of works.<ref name="":0"" /> Spødervold believed that Hauge drove people ""from vices to virtues""{{Sfn
column6: p=308}} in order to win God's favor and grace. He rebuked the Haugeans for what he perceived as a legalistic, excessive focus on [[Works-righteousness
column7: works righteousness]]. He also criticizes Hauge for his doctrine of the [[Eucharist in Lutheranism
column8: Eucharist]], since Hauge denied that Christ's human nature was in the sacrament, i.e. he did not support the Lutheran view of [[Real presence of Christ in the Eucharist
column9: real presence]]. Hauge emphasized rather the spiritual benefit of the Eucharist. With this starting point, Spødervold characterizes Hauge as a [[Calvinism

column1: In another chapter he rebukes the Moravian Church, which had taken root in Stavanger. He attacks their lack of enlightenment on the [[triune God]]; nor did they have the right knowledge about the word of God, [[Law and Gospel
column2: the Law, and the Gospel]]. In Spødervold's opinion, they could not explain how a person was [[born again]] and [[Justification (theology)
column6: p=330}} Spødervold's focus, conversely, was on justification through faith alone (''[[sola fide]]'').<ref name="":3"" />

column1: In the last chapter, Spødervold takes a stand against the Quakers. They mixed the effect of the law and the gospel,{{Sfn
column4: p=362}} and they had a wrong concept of the Spirit of God. They did not regard the Bible as the word of God, and they rejected baptism and communion. Spødervold shows that the Holy Spirit does not work apart from his word, which is his medium of communication with mankind. God is in the literal word, and it expresses his will.

column1: Spødervold died in Stavanger in 1848.<ref name="":2"" />

[[Anton Christian Bang]] writes in his biography of Hauge that ""Knud Spødervold does not seem to have undergone any deeper penetration into the secrets of Christian life. On the other hand, a diligent reading of Luther's writings has given him a fairly clear theoretical insight into the doctrine of the justification of faith.""{{Sfn

Bang also writes that there was a split in Stavanger around 1850. The background is said to have been that some held firmly to Spødervold's doctrine of [[baptism]] and rebirth, while others rejected it as heresy.{{Sfn
column4: p=466}} In the appendix to ''The Dispensation of God's Grace'', Spødervold wrote that in baptism one is not reborn to resemble the image of God. On the contrary, one is in Satan's kingdom from baptism to faith, ""although God preserves his established foundation"".{{Sfn

column1: A memory of Spødervold is preserved in a discussion he had with the provost Hans Lund, who met him one day late in the fall after everyone else had long since brought their grain in. ""The weather is good now"", said Lund, ""now you must see to it that you bring in the grain"". Spødervold was immediately ready with his answer: ""In the fullness of time God sent his son, and in the fullness of time I too will bring in my grain.""{{Sfn

column3: no}}, grandfather of writer [[Alexander Kielland]], came to Stavanger as chaplain in 1818 and left as provost in 1839. In his memoirs, he recounts his meeting with Spødervold:

column2: text=Knud Spjødevold from Birkreim parish also paid me a visit. He was a horrible man. His countenance and whole manner were so rough, wild, and almost beastly, that one could consider him capable of anything. He pretended to want to ask me for information concerning passages in the Old Testament, but all his questions were based on obscenities, so I seriously rebuked him and let him know that if he did not seek any other information, I would have nothing to do with him. He went away, and I never saw him again.{{Sfn

column4: title=Enfoldigt og kort Gjennemsnit af Tiden til sand og velgrundet Betænkning over Guds Naades Huusholdning med Menneskene...

column1: '''Kim Olof Axel Sebastian Lundbäck''' (born 24 July 1996), known as '''Sebastian Lundbäck''', is a Swedish [[association football
column2: footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[IFK Östersund]].

column1: In 2014, following impressive performances in his native Sweden with IFK Östersund, Lundbäck was invited to trial with clubs across Europe.<ref name=sr>{{cite web
column4: trans-title=Football talent Sebastian Lundbäck auditions abroad
column8: language=Swedish}}</ref> He had already played for [[Östersunds FK]] at youth level, but had rejected their contract offer in favour of IFK.<ref name=sr/> However, in November of the same year, he decided to make the switch to Östersunds FK.<ref>{{cite web
column18: language=Swedish}}</ref> The following season, he returned to IFK on loan, playing three times in the [[Division 2 (Swedish football)
column20: 2f7c02b2-8101-4684-91b6-eb9e2ba0f39a}}</ref> He would be loaned out twice more by Östersunds FK, both to [[Team TG FF
column21: Team TG]], before making the switch permanent for the 2018 season.<ref>{{cite web
column23: title=Nu är Lundbäck klar på riktigt
column24: trans-title=Now Lundbäck is ready for real

column1: He returned to IFK in February 2019, signing a one-year deal with the club.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Välkommen tillbaka till IFK Östersund, Sebastian
column4: trans-title=Välkommen tillbaka till IFK Östersund, Sebastian
column8: language=Swedish}}</ref> He appears to have taken a break from football, before returning again to IFK, this time signing a deal as a sporting director, while also being registered for the first team.<ref>{{cite web
column15: language=Swedish}}</ref> He left his role as sporting director in October 2022, but continued to play for the first team.<ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Lundbäck lämnar jobbet som sportchef i IFK: ”Det har varit tufft att få allt att klaffa”
column18: trans-title=Lundbäck leaves his job as sporting director in IFK: ""It has been tough to get everything going""

column1: Lundbäck has represented Sweden from under-17 to under-19 level.<ref name=sf/><ref>{{cite web
His brother, Jonathan, is also a footballer, and the pair played together at numerous times during their careers.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Sebastian 'Batti' Lundbäck åter till Team TG
column4: trans-title=Sebastian 'Batti' Lundbäck back to Team TG

column1: 73694847,"Sir_Richard_Keane,_2nd_Baronet","'''Richard Keane''' (1780 – 16 February 1855) was an Irish politician.
Keane lived a Cappoquin House in [[County Waterford]].  At the [[1832 UK general election]], he stood for the [[Whigs (British political party)
column3: County Waterford]], winning a seat.  He stood down at the [[1835 UK general election]].  He lived for a further twenty years.<ref name=""stenton"">{{cite book
column6: title=Who's Who of British Members of Parliament

column1: [[Category:Members of the Parliament of the United Kingdom for County Waterford constituencies (1801–1922)]]
73694865,John_Matthew_Galwey,"'''John Matthew Galwey''' was an Irish politician.
Galwey lived at Duckspool in [[County Waterford]].  He stood in the [[1832 UK general election]] in [[County Waterford (UK Parliament constituency)
column2: County Waterford]], winning the seat, as an [[Irish Repeal]] candidate.  At the [[1835 UK general election]], he instead contested [[Dungarvan (UK Parliament constituency)
column3: Dungarvan]], where he was defeated.  He was again unsuccessful there at the [[1837 UK general election]].<ref name=""stenton"">{{cite book
column6: title=Who's Who of British Members of Parliament

column1: [[Category:Members of the Parliament of the United Kingdom for County Waterford constituencies (1801–1922)]]
73694899,Charles_John_Greville,"'''Charles John Greville''' (died 1836) was a British politician.

The younger brother of the [[Earl of Warwick]], Greville served in the [[British Army]], becoming a major-general.  He was also appointed as a colonel in the [[98th (Prince of Wales's) Regiment of Foot]].<ref name=""stenton"">{{cite book
column4: title=Who's Who of British Members of Parliament

column1: At the [[1812 UK general election]], Greville was elected for the [[Tories (British political party)
column3: Warwick]], serving until [[1831 UK general election
column4: 1831]].  He stood again at the [[1832 UK general election]], winning the seat, but was unseated on petition.  He was re-elected at the [[1835 UK general election]], this time for the new [[Conservative Party (UK)
column5: Conservative Party]], but stood down in 1836 by accepting the [[Chiltern Hundreds]].  He died later in the year.<ref name=""stenton"" />

column1: '''''The Veterinary Journal''''' is a monthly [[peer-reviewed]] [[scientific journal]] covering [[veterinary science]] and related topics. The journal was established in 1875 as ''The Veterinary Journal and Annals of Comparative Pathology'' and renamed ''The Veterinary Journal'' in 1900,then renamed ''British Veterinary Journal'' in 1949 before finally obtaining its current title in 1997. It is published by [[Elsevier]] and the [[editor-in-chief]] is Annette L. Litster ([[Purdue University]]). The journal publishes research articles, review articles, and case studies.
The journal is abstracted and indexed in:

73694996,John_Leach_(MP),"'''John Leach''', also known as '''John Leech''' (died 16 April 1847) was a British politician.
Leach lived at Lea in Surrey.  He was a trustee of the Agricultural Employment Institution.  At the [[1832 UK general election]], he stood for the [[Whigs (British political party)
column3: West Surrey]], winning a seat.  In Parliament, he argued in favour of the [[Corn Laws]], and for reform of the church, in order to equalise the income of the various bishops.  He served until the [[1835 UK general election]], when he stood down.<ref name=""stenton"">{{cite book

column6: lead=yes}}}} is a 2001 [[role-playing video game]] developed and published by [[Square (video game company)
column8: WonderSwan Color]]. It was Square's first original title for the platform. The player takes on the role of a protagonist going through a series of freely-available scenarios, building the world based on character interactions. The world, characters and turn-based battle system are represented using cards.

column1: Production, which lasted one year, was led by ''[[SaGa]]'' creator [[Akitoshi Kawazu]]. The main artist was [[Akihiko Yoshida]], while the music was scored by [[Kenji Ito]] in one of his last projects before going freelance. Selling 40,000 copies, the game met with a mixed reaction from critics, noting its experimental nature while praising the artwork. Kawazu would revisit the game's card-based style with ''[[Unlimited Saga]]'' (2002).

''Wild Card'' is a single-player [[role-playing video game]] in which players take on the role of a character exploring the game's world. Everything in-game, from locations and characters to items, are represented through cards and static artwork.<ref name=""NTTwild""/><ref name=""SQEXinfo""/><ref name=""WCcharacters""/> Set in a world built on stories and belief, the story opens with a narrator recording the oral traditions of their ancestors, which are under threat of extinction. One of these stories tells of a mysterious bright light flew across the sky towards the edge of the world, with the narrator deciding to retell the story and guide the narrative based on how the people might have acted.<ref name=""WCworld""/> From that point, the player is tasked with guiding the narrative based on a selection of up to one hundred ""scenario cards"", progressing the game in a non-linear style.<ref name=""SQEXinfo""/><ref name=""WCworld""/>

column4: All gameplay in ''Wild Card'' is presented using static artwork and cards.]]

column1: Upon starting the game, the player is asked a series of questions which determines their starting character from nine possibles; the other eight are then met during the campaign as potential party members.<ref name=""WCcharacters""/> Scenarios are split into three types; finding a destination, fighting an enemy, and discovering and item or person. Progress through scenarios is entirely dependant on the types of cards players have equipped: ""swim"" cards allow them to cross water, and some cards can make travel through the scenario easier or harder.<ref name=""WCscenario""/> There is no overworld map or traditional dungeons, with the player instead selecting cards to choose their route through a scenario, sometimes encountering either obstacles that must be overcome using a skill card, or battles.<ref name=""WCfield""/>

Combat uses a turn-based system, with the player party having up to five members who can be commanded to attack or be the one to receive enemy attacks.<ref name=""SQEXinfo""/> Combat revolves around using cards which outmatch an enemy's attack or defense card values, with battles ending when one side is defeated.<ref name=""WCbattle""/> The goal is to reduce enemy health to nothing, which is done with standard attacks, skills, and magic abilities.<ref name=""SQEXinfo""/> Cards are limited in number and can only be regained upon completing the current scenario, with the player increasing the number of cards they can hold by completing scenarios and using ""Card Get"" point rewards to purchase new cards. The game ends if all party members are knocked out during battle.<ref name=""WCstrategy""/>
In 1999, ''[[Final Fantasy]]'' developer and publisher [[Square (video game company)
column2: Square]] partnered with [[Bandai]] to produce games for the [[WonderSwan]] portable console.<ref name=""IGNbandai""/> ''Wild Card'' was handled by a team led by [[Akitoshi Kawazu]], known for creating the ''[[SaGa]]'' series.<ref name=""FamSwan""/> Kawazu's team had transferred to working on titles for the WonderSwan console in 1999 following the cancellation of a [[PlayOnline]]-focused numbered ''Final Fantasy'' title.<ref name=""UnlimitedBook""/> Kawazu later noted that he handled much of the game's development outside programming and art.<ref name=""KawazuComment""/> He acted as the game's designer, Kazuhisa Murakami was programmer, while [[Shinji Hashimoto]] and Hiroshi Yamaji co-produced.<ref name=""WildCredits""/> According to staff member Kyoji Koizumi, development lasted roughly a year.<ref name=""KoizumiComment""/> [[Akihiko Yoshida]] created the cover and main art.<ref name=""BandaiInfo""/> The in-game illustrations and graphics were handled by a large team including Nobuyuki Ikeda, Kiyofumi Kato, Tonny Waiman Koo, and Toshiaki Matsumoto.<ref name=""WildCredits""/> The music was composed and arranged by ''SaGa'' composer [[Kenji Ito]].<ref name=""ITOdisc""/> It was one of Ito's last projects before leaving Square to become a freelance composer.<ref name=""ItoInterview""/>

column1: ''Wild Card'' was released on March 29, 2001, and was only compatible with the WonderSwan Color.<ref name=""BandaiInfo""/> The title was Square's first original WonderSwan game.<ref name=""WonderSquare""/> Two guidebooks were published alongside the game; one by [[DigiCube]], and one by [[Shueisha]].<ref name=""DigiGuide""/><ref name=""Guidebook""/> Due to the console not releasing outside Japan, ''Wild Card'' was not localized.<ref name=""RetroSwan""/> Kawazu later revisited the mechanics and presentation of ''Wild Card'' in the [[PlayStation 2]] title ''[[Unlimited Saga]]'' (2002).<ref name=""UnlimitedBook""/>

During 2001, ''Wild Card'' ranked among the top three hundred best-selling games, selling over 25,500 units.<ref name=""SalesFam""/> Square's fiscal report for that year reported the game sold 40,000 copies.<ref name=""Sales""/> In a preview for ''The Gaming Intelligence Agency'', Clifford Chao positively compared ''Wild Card'' to the earlier ''[[Arcana (video game)
column2: Arcana]]'' (1992), noting its unusual card-based presentation and art style.<ref name=""GIApreview""/> Japanese magazine ''[[Famitsu]]'' gave the game a score of 23 points out of 40, with several critics noting its unique style but finding its mechanics and progression difficult to adjust to compared to other games on the market.<ref name=""FamReview""/> ''[[Retro Gamer]]'' noted the game's experimental gameplay and praised Yoshida's artwork.<ref name=""RetroSwan""/>

Advisory body in Nazi era Prussia 1933 to 1945}}
the Prussian State Council during Nazi Germany

column10: coa_caption=[[Hermann Göring]], President of the State Council

column1: The '''Prussian State Council''' '''of Nazi Germany''' ([[German language
column2: German]]: ''Preußischer Staatsrat'') was an advisory body to the Prussian minister president from 1933 to 1945. It was the successor to the [[Weimar Republic]] body of the same name that represented the interests of [[Provinces of Prussia
column3: Prussia's provinces]] in the legislative process. In [[Nazi Germany]] its members were either appointed by Prussian minister president [[Hermann Göring]] or were members as a result of their official positions in the state of Prussia. The Council met only six times and ceased to exist with the end of Nazi rule in 1945.

column1: During the [[Weimar Republic]], the [[Prussian State Council]] was the second chamber of the bicameral legislature of the [[Free State of Prussia]]. Its members were elected by the Prussian provincial parliaments to represent the interests of the [[Provinces of Prussia
With the [[Prussian Landtag elections in the Weimar Republic
column2: elections to the Prussian state parliament]] ({{Lang
column4: Landtag}}) that were held in parallel with the national [[March 1933 German federal election
column5: Reichstag elections]] on 5 March 1933, and also with the elections to the Prussian provincial parliaments held on 12 March 1933, the [[Nazi Party]] was able to secure the necessary majority in the {{Lang
column7: Landtag}} and in the State Council to pass a Prussian [[enabling act]] on 18 May 1933. It gave the Prussian state government the same powers at the state level that the Reich government had received at the national level through the [[Enabling Act of 1933
column8: Enabling Act of 24 March 1933]]. The Prussian minister president could make and implement laws without the involvement of the legislature. Through the enabling act, the State Council was deprived of its co-legislative and co-executive functions. Article 15 of the Prussian State Council Act of 8 July 1933 then dissolved the State Council in its previous form.<ref>{{Cite book
column16: trans-title=Renazification of the Federal Republic of Germany}}</ref>

column1: === Founding of the National Socialist State Council ===

The ""Law on the State Council"" created a new body in line with the [[National Socialist]] worldview. It was a purely advisory body that consisted of members by virtue of office and members awarded the title of State Councilor ({{Lang
column3: Staatsrat}}) who were appointed by [[Hermann Göring]] in his capacity as Prussian minister president. Members by virtue of office were the Prussian ministers and state secretaries as well as certain other office holders.<ref name="":0"">{{Cite web

column1: Members had to be males at least 25 years old with a residence in Prussia. For those who were members by virtue of office, membership ended by leaving office. Appointed members' terms were ended by death, resignation, or dismissal by Göring.<ref name="":0"" /> Members of the State Council received an expense allowance of 1,000 [[Reichsmark]]s per month (from 1 April 1936, RM 500).
Only six meetings of the State Council were held. It met for the first time on 15 September 1933 in the auditorium of the [[Friedrich Wilhelms University of Berlin
column2: Friedrich Wilhelms University]] in Berlin. The second meeting was held on 12 October 1933 and the third on 18 June 1934, with a report by the minister of finance on Prussia's financial situation. The fourth session was convened on 21 March 1935, the second anniversary of [[Potsdam Day]] commemorating the reopening of the [[Reichstag building]] following the [[Reichstag fire
column3: fire of February 1933]], and the fifth was on 25 June 1935. The last session was held on 5 March 1936.<ref>{{Cite book
column10: title=Carl Schmitt: Preussischer Staatrat in Hitlers Reich
column17: trans-title=Carl Schmitt: Prussian State Councilor in Hitler's Reich}}</ref>

column1: After the March 1936 session, the State Council was no longer convened, although it continued to exist. In 1943 [[Albert Hoffmann (Nazi)
column2: Albert Hoffmann]] was the last member appointed to the State Council. With the fall of the National Socialist state in 1945, the State Council also came to an end.

The '''2023 Vuelta Asturias Julio Alvarez Mendo''' was a [[road bicycle racing
column3: stage race]] that took place between 28 and 30 April 2023 in the [[Asturias]] region of northwestern Spain. It was the 65th edition of the [[Vuelta Asturias]] and was part of the [[2023 UCI Europe Tour]] calendar as a category [[2.1]] event.

column2: UCI ProTeams]], and five [[UCI Continental]] teams made up the fifteen teams that participated in the race.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=EQUIPOS CONOCE A LOS EQUIPOS PARTICIPANTES EN ESTA EDICIÓN
column6: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> All but two teams fielded the maximum of seven riders: {{ct
column12: 2023}} entered five. There was a total of 101 riders that started the race.

column1: Ryle lived in [[Macclesfield]], where his father was prominent in the local silk and cotton trade.  He married a granddaughter of [[Richard Arkwright]] in 1811, and became a banker.  At the [[1832 UK general election]], he stood for the [[Tories (British political party)
column3: Macclesfield]], winning a seat.  In Parliament, he argued for limited reforms, and for protection to be given to the silk trade.  He held his seat, after 1834 for the new [[Conservative Party (UK)
column4: Conservative Party]], until the [[1837 UK general election]], when he was defeated.<ref name=""stenton"">{{cite book
column7: title=Who's Who of British Members of Parliament

column1: [[Category:Members of the Parliament of the United Kingdom for English constituencies]]
'''Ann O'Connor Williams Harithas''' (June 12, 1941–December 23, 2021) was an American philanthropist, museum founder, curator and artist.
Harithas was born in Houston, Texas, to Roger Pinckney Williams and Maude O'Connor Williams.<ref name=""obit"">{{cite web
column7: access-date=28 March 2023}}</ref> Through her mother, she was a descendent of Irish immigrant [[Thomas O'Connor (rancher)
column8: Thomas O'Connor]], who at the time of his death in 1887, was the largest land and cattle owner in Texas. During the 1930s, oil was discovered on the O’Connor Ranch; the find soon proved to be the state’s largest oil field.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Phase IB Investigations of the Proposed Site for Victoria County Station, Units 1 and 2, Victoria County, Texas
column17: access-date=27 April 2023}}</ref> Ann grew up in Victoria, Texas, and nearby Tivoli<ref>{{cite web
column20: website=Five Points Museum of Contemporary Art}}</ref> with a sister six years her junior.<ref name=""find"">{{cite web

column1: Harithas loved Texas culture, enjoyed ranch life and befriended many O'Connor Ranch workers.<ref name=""wilcox>{{cite news
column6: date=January 7, 2022}}</ref> Years later, Harithas would celebrate her girlhood environs, the site where she felt ""most connected to the land and to all of nature,""  by commissioning a six-channel video installation, ''Aransas: Axis of Observation'', from artist [[Frank Gillette]].<ref>{{cite book

column1: She became interested in art as a child, purchasing a [[Paul Gauguin
column2: Gauguin]] etching at age 15.<ref name=""pete"">{{cite book
column5: title=Collision, The Contemporary Art Scene in Houston, 1972–1985
column9: edition=First}}</ref> She took art lessons until she was 16 and was mentored by her second cousin (once removed),<ref>{{cite web
column13: access-date=28 April 2023}}</ref> painter  and naturalist Madeline O'Connor.<ref name=""found"">{{cite book
column16: title=The Art of Found Objects: Interviews with Texas Artists

column1: Harithas was especially drawn to the medium of collage. She had a great aunt who cut images from magazines and pasted them into scrapbooks from which Ann learned her first words.<ref name=""find""></ref> Ann began with cut paper and continued to make collages, incorporating new techniques such as digital compositing and large format color printing, throughout her life.<ref name=""found""></ref>
She earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in English from the University of Texas at Austin, and a Master of Fine Arts degree from Rice University.<ref name=""obit""></ref>
She  married first husband, Thomas V. Robinson, in 1970.<ref>{{cite web
column4: website=Texas Department of State Health Services
column5: access-date=27 April 2023}}</ref> Together that year, they established Galerie Ann in a building adjacent to the [[Contemporary Arts Museum Houston]] (CAMH). The new business was inspired by a meeting with Manhattan-based female gallerist [[Terry Dintenfass]].<ref name=""wilcox""></ref>

column1: The Robinsons had four children, three daughters and a son.<ref name=""find""></ref> When they divorced in 1977, Ann took over the gallery space and renamed it Robinson Galleries.<ref name=""pete""/> There, she showed work by [[Edward Hopper]], [[Arthur Dove]],<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Kachina dolls and cowboys inspire artist's work
column7: access-date=28 March 2023}}</ref> [[Jacob Lawrence]] and [[Norman Bluhm]], among many others. She was instrumental in launching the art careers of [[Mel Chin]] and [[Jesse Lott]].<ref name=""found""></ref>

column2: James ""Jim"" Harithas]], the newly-arrived director of the CAMH. From her gallery, she witnessed a fistfight on the museum's loading dock between Harithas and Chicano muralist Leo Tanguma. It made a lasting impression.<ref name=""pete""/>

column1: In 1977, she collaborated with the CAMH on an exhibition, arranged by Harithas, of her [[Kachina
column2: Kachina doll]] collection.<ref name=""pete""/> She made generous donations to the museum and underwrote a program of visiting artists at the University of Houston.<ref name=""pete""/> She funded the [[Lawndale Art Center]] and supported [[Project Row Houses]].

column1: In September 1978, she and Jim married.<ref name=""obit""/> The pair would be the Houston art scene's power couple for decades to come, devoting themselves to local and regional artists as well as those working with politically- and socially-engaged content.<ref name=""local"">{{cite web
column4: title=Houston art legend Jim Harithas has died at the age of 90

column1: Harithas started showing her collages in 1978, the first as part of a group show at Delta Gallery in Houston. She would go on to exhibit in more than 50 shows in the U.S. and internationally. Ten of these were solo exhibitions at such locations as The Museum of Contemporary Art in Washington D.C., Betty Moody Gallery in Houston and The Nave Museum in Victoria, Texas.<ref>{{cite web
In addition to South Texas painter Madeline O'Connor, she counted [[Hannah Höch
column3: Alfonso Ossorio]], Jesse Lott, Susan Plum, Mel Chin and Travis Whitfield among her influences.<ref name=""found""></ref>

column1: She worked instinctively, letting the story unfold as she assembled collage elements. Hopi kachinas, [[Santo (art)
column2: santos]] and other religious icons are prevalent in her work. In ''The Art of Found Objects: Interviews with Texas Artists'', she told author Robert Craig Bunch, ""Both Kachinas and the other religious components of my collages speak to essential and intimate spirituality, and each person who views the work has their own way of relating to this. I use Indian and Christian religious images, taking them out of their traditional familiar context so their 'spirit' can be more clearly communicated.""<ref name=""found""></ref>

column1: As new technologies became available, she would digitally or photographically enlarge small works to enormous proportions. She was intrigued by the way the collages changed at different scales, even shifting the focal point and meaning.<ref name=""found""></ref>
Two years earlier, the Harithases met Larry Fuente, one of the [[San Francisco Bay Area
column2: Bay Area]]'s premier ""glue artists,"" a counterculture junk art movement in which small found objects were used to decorate larger ones. In ''Ancient Roots/New Visions'', a show at The University of Houston's [[Blaffer Art Museum
column3: Blaffer Gallery]], Fuente was represented by a toilet decorated with hundreds of beads, paste gems and a large statuette of the Virgin Mary. Ann was enthralled and bought it, but what she really wanted was one of Fuente's art cars. She commissioned one that took him and a team of assistants five years to complete.<ref name=""pete""></ref>

column1: The ''Mad Cad'' was one of eight monumental works brought in for ''Collision'', a show Ann curated at [[Lawndale Art Center]] in 1984. The 1960 Cadillac Sedan de Ville was encrusted with millions of beads and faux jewels; swan, duck and flamingo figurines; action figures; shoe soles and plastic horses, which resulted in a surprisingly elegant, if over the top, construction.<ref name=""pete""></ref>
Soon after, Ann fashioned ''Swamp Mutha'' from a 1982 Monte Carlo in collaboration with Jesse Lott. Her passion for art cars, shared by her husband, would ultimately manifest in an [[ArtCar Museum
column2: Art Car Museum]] and annual [[Houston Art Car Parade

column1: The Art Car Museum, aka Garage Mahal, opened in 1998. The private, not-for-profit center is dedicated to contemporary art.<ref name=""car"">{{cite web
column5: access-date=31 March 2023}}</ref> The museum's mission is to serve as ""an exhibition forum for local, national and international artists with an emphasis on art cars, other fine arts and artists that are rarely, if ever, acknowledged by other cultural institutions.""<ref name=""car"">{{cite web

column1: As with all of the Harithases' venues, the Art Car Museum also presents overtly political work.<ref name=""rail"">{{cite web

The couple established the Station Museum of Contemporary Art in 2001 with the goal of providing ""a resource that deepens and broadens public awareness of the cultural, political, economic, and personal dimensions of art.""<ref name=""closes"">{{cite web
column4: title=Station Museum of Contemporary Art Closes Until Further Notice

column1: Post-CAMH and without a governing board, Jim Harithas was free to follow his curatorial passions: the work of local artists or groups of outside artists, often that of underrepresented or undiscovered voices of protest.<ref name=""closes""></ref> During its 20 years of operation, the Station Museum mounted shows that dealt with the concerns of Palestinians, Iraqis, the LGBTQ community, people of color, Indigenous Americans and others who question ""society’s morality and ethics.”<ref>{{cite web
In the 2000s and 2010s, Ann served on [[wikidata:Q107318338
column2: The Nave Museum]]'s board of directors and curated several shows. She also exhibited her own work in two solo shows.

column1: In 2007, The Nave organized a solo show for Harithas entitled ''The Collages''.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=""Thought provoking""  collages exhibited at the Nave
column6: date=March 1, 2007}}</ref> A second, ''Transformative Visions'', ran in 2013.<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=Catch the Beauty Before It Fades

column1: As curator, Harithas mounted numerous exhibitions, including the following.
* Jesse Lott's ''Standing at the Crossroads'' was a retrospective solo show of his ""urban frontier"" art.<ref>{{cite news
* ''Tres Latinos'' brought together three Hispanic artists under the age of 30: painter/graffitist [[Carlos Donjuan]], printmaker Juan de Dios Mora and photographer Santiago Forero.<ref>{{cite news
* ''Carter Ernst: Fur Bitten'' showcased the sculptor's surreal, colorful fabric, faux fur and ceramic take on the natural world.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Carter Ernst: Fur Bitten at The Nave Museum

column1: * Susan Plum's ''A World in Glass'' presented glass works, prints and pastels united by the theme of light.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Houston Artist Debuts New Art at Nave Museum

column1: * For Mel Chin's ''Funk and Wag A to Z'', the artist took over the entirety of the museum.  The exterior, fitted out as a ''Temple of the Gods'', was adorned with basketballs bunched like grapes and leaves made of basketball nets, referencing the relationship between popular culture and sports with a nod to The Nave's Greek architecture.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Artist Mel Chin finds new use for encyclopedias
column7: access-date=29 April 2023}}</ref> The interior was filled with 524 collages assembled from photographs extracted from all 25 volumes of the 1953-56 edition of [[Funk & Wagnalls
column8: Funk & Wagnalls Universal Standard Encyclopedia]].<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=The Funk & Wag from A to Z

column1: April 16, 2016 saw the opening of the Five Points Museum of Contemporary Art, a ""gift"" from Harithas to the city of Victoria. She established the free-to-the-public institution following her tenure at The Nave as a place where she could make her own rules.<ref name=""rules"">{{cite news
column4: title=Coming Soon, Five Points Museum of Contemporary Art to open

column1: The opening show, Noah Edmundson's ''Lost Worlds: New Drawings and Sculpture'' coincided with an art car parade through downtown Victoria. Some of the cars and lowriders, which Harithas described as South Texas ""indigenous culture,"" were then put on display at the museum.<ref name=""rules""></ref>
Exhibitions at the Five Points largely involve art cars, but the museum has hosted work by some of Harithas' favorite activist artists. Shows she curated include:
* Irvin Tepper's 2018 exhibition, ''Evidence of Phantoms Made Real Between Thoughts'' was a ""mystical visual exploration"" manifested through drawings, sculpture and video.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Museum to host 'Evidence of Phantoms Made Real Between Thoughts'

column1: *''Lowrider Excellence: The Leal Brothers'' featured ten award-winning cars created by the Corpus Christi artists.<ref>{{cite news

* ''Salvaged Species'', an exhibit of Mark “Scrapdaddy” Bradford's work, was shown in conjunction with the 2019 art car parade. The artist's cars/hydraulic walking machines, kinetic creatures and other sculptures are constructed from scrap metal.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Victoria Art Car Parade to wrap up with  Exhibit, festival

column1: * For ''The Road So Far,'' Harithas brought together Jesse Lott and Travis Whitfield in a 2019 show reflective of the artists' deep roots in the South, urban Texas in Lott's case and rural Louisiana in Whitfield's.

* Harithas organized ''Insurgent: The Paintings of Clark V. Fox'' in 2021. Using appropriated corporate and political icons, the artist's work attempts to dismantle the effect of capitalist culture on our consciousness.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Insurgent: The Paintings of Clark Fox
column4: website=Five Points Museum of Contemporary Art

column1: Community outreach and arts education are part the institution's mission.<ref>{{cite web
column4: website=Five Points Museum of Contemporary Art
column5: access-date=2 April 2023}}</ref> Live theater and film screenings are also offered.<ref>{{cite web
column8: website=Five Points Museum of Contemporary Art

column1: In 2012, Harithas experienced brain trauma that left her with significant memory loss. By assembling collages from family photos and images of her injured brain,<ref name=""founder"">{{cite web
column4: website=Five Points Museum of Contemporary Art
column5: access-date=28 April 2023}}</ref> her faculties improved and she made a full recovery. The series of collages were presented in the exhibit ''Ann Harithas: Memory'' at D.M. Allison Gallery in Houston.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Ann Harithas Makes Art Out of Her Memory Loss and Recovery

column1: Ann’s last curatorial endeavor was the mounting of the major museum show ''Mel Chin: Points of View'' held in conjunction with his large-scale public installation ''Wake'' in downtown Victoria (2021-2022).<ref name=""founder""></ref>
She died in Houston on December 23, 2021, at age 80.<ref name=""find""></ref>
