column1: The '''Second Battle of Nagyszeben''' was a battle in the [[Hungarian Revolution of 1848
column2: Hungarian war of Independence of 1848-1849]] fought on 11 March 1849 between the Hungarian army led by the Polish General [[Józef Bem]] and the garrison of [[Nagyszeben]], the [[Habsburg Monarchy
column4: Transylvania]], composed by the Russian detachment led by Colonel [[Grigory Skariatin]] Austrian troops led by Lieutenant General Alois Pfersmann, and [[Transylvanian Saxon]] [[national guard]]s. Before the battle, Bem managed to make the commander of the Austrian main Commander-in-Chief of [[Transylvania]], [[Lieutenant General]] Anton Puchner think that he barricaded himself at [[Segesvár]], while he escaped, heading to Nagyszeben. While Puchner was trying to encircle Segesvár where he thaught that Bem was hiding, the latter headed through a quick march to Nagyszeben, where he defeated the Ruso-Austro-Saxon garrison led by General Skariatin, and captured the city. Hearing about this, Puchner suffered a mental collapse, as a result of which, the still much superior Austrian and Russian troops retreated from Transylvania. Thanks to this victory Bem reinstalled the Hungarian rule over the province. This victory was the overture of the victorious Hungarian [[Spring Campaign]] which leberated almost all the territories of Hungary from the imperial rule.

column1: After the [[Battle of Piski]] on 9 February, [[Major General]] [[Józef Bem]] was informed that the [[Habsburg Monarchy
column2: Austrian imperial]] troops had again invaded Northern [[Transylvania]], threatening the Hungarian possession of this part of the province.<ref name=""auto"">{{Harvnb
column5: pp=192}}.</ref> Bem responded to this threat quickly, by bypassing Puchner, who prepared him a trap at [[Szászsebes]], and then he quickly reached North Transylvania and drove out the imperial troops led by [[Lieutenant General]] Ignaz von Malkowski.<ref name=""auto""/>

column1: Meanwhile, the main commander of the imperial armies of Transylvania, Lieutenant General Anton Puchner was in a state of near lethargy after the defeats of Piski and [[Alvinc]], suffered against Bem.<ref name=""auto""/> He had waited nearly a week to write his official report on the events of the week which passed between the [[Battle of Vízakna
column2: battles of Vízakna]] and Alvinc, and he had no mindset to dictate it all at once: on 15 February he wrote a chronicle of the successes between 4-8 February, and only the next day pulled himself together to report to the main commander of the imperial forces from Hungary, [[Field Marshal]] [[Alfred I, Prince of Windisch-Grätz]] about the battles of Piski and Alvinc; although from these reports it was hard to understand if they were victories or defeats.<ref name=""auto""/> He felt that fate had once again done him an injustice. His losses so far had been 1,600 soldiers, 1,000 of whom were recovering their injuries in hospitals, writing to Windisch-Grätz, that he had captured 21 guns with the heroism and blood loss of his soldiers.<ref name=""auto""/> Bem had remained - as Puchner claimed - with 3,000 men and 2 cannons after Vízakna, and at the moment when he thought he had been annihilated, a single Hungarian relief force reinforced him, not only replacing his losses, but increasing them two or three times as they were before, while his forces were diminishing day by day, ''and under such circumstances the most brilliant victory won - I mean in its immediate consequences - will be a real defeat''.<ref >{{Harvnb
column5: pp=192-193}}.</ref> He believed that Bem now had 6-8,000 men and 25-30 guns, so he did not want to attack until he had received reinforcements. He asked for help from both Windisch-Grätz and from the Austrian garrison of [[Temesvár]].<ref name=""auto1"">{{Harvnb
column8: pp=193}}.</ref> His officers had previously tried in vain to persuade him to attack immediately, but only on 28 February - having been informed of Malkowski's attack in northern Transylvania - he finally moved out of his headquarters from [[Nagyszeben]], marching northwards. His intention was to clear the valley of the [[Küküllő]], beat Bem at [[Medgyes]] and then take [[Marosvásárhely]]. He asked Malkowski to advance from [[Beszterce]] to Marosvásárhely.<ref name=""auto1""/>

column1: On 1 March Bem arrived in Medgyes. The next day, on 2 March, the imperial attack began at [[Kiskapus]], which was initially successful, but then the Hungarian troops retook their previous positions. ''We ran out of ammunition, so we were forced to retreat until we were resupplied, finally they ''[those whose job was to supply the soldiers]'' stopped us, but they did not supply us with ammunition, because there was none in the whole camp, but ''[they told us that]'' we had to attack ''[only]'' with bayonets and drive the enemy away, which we finally did, in the evening with a great noise, because we could make a noise better ''[scream louder]'' than they could, and we chased them all the way to [[Asszonyfalva]], ''[but]'' we did not chase them any further'' - wrote a participating soldier. <ref name=""auto1""/> Both sides suffered heavy losses in the fierce fighting, and the Hungarian artillery fired almost all its ammunition.<ref >{{Harvnb
On 3 March, all of Puchner's troops arrived on the battlefield and attacked with a considerable advantage.<ref name=""auto2"">{{Harvnb
column4: pp=194}}.</ref> At first the Hungarian troops held against their fire well, but the artillery of the imperial army inflicted increasingly heavy losses on the Hungarian artillery.<ref name=""auto2""/> Puchner's left wing pushed back the Hungarian right wing, forcing the artillery to retreat.<ref name=""auto2""/> Bem attempted to regroup his troops, but Puchner's infantry soon broke through the weakened Hungarian army center, and Bem ordered a retreat.<ref name=""auto2""/> Towards evening Bem received reinforcements, which stopped the advance of the imperials. Bem ordered an attack, but the enemy infantry repulsed it and forced the Hungarian infantry to flee. Bem was then forced to retreat towards [[Segesvár]].<ref name=""auto2""/> The Hungarian losses were at least as high as at Piski - i.e. about 700.<ref name=""Babucs"">Babucs Zoltán: [https://mki.gov.hu/hu/hirek-hu/evfortulok-hu/most-pedig-megyunk-nagyszebenbe „Most pedig megyünk Nagyszebenbe!”] Magyarságkutató Intézet, 21 March 2021</ref>

column1: After the battle, in order to successfully resist an attack from Medgyes, Bem took position in the defensive earth works he had already built between Segesvár and [[Dános]].<ref name=""Gyalókay"">{{Harvnb
column4: pp=55}}.</ref> Bem now had some time to reorganize his troops, and also received new reinforcements in Segesvár, which made him to plan again to attack Nagyszeben, this time hoping to finally occupy the Austrian headquarters from Transylvania, after his [[First Battle of Nagyszeben

column1: Puchner did not pursue the retreating Hungarian army. The Austrian corps was very exhausted from the two days of fighting, which is why Puchner wanted to rest his troops on 4 and 5 March before moving on to strike a decisive blow at Bem.<ref name=""Gyalókay""/>

Puchner, as he had received no reinforcements from anywhere, now had only the troops he had fought with in the [[Battle of Medgyes]], whose order of battle, according to Philipp August Joachim Freiherr von der Heydte - was this. The corps was divided into three brigades. The division commander was József Kalliány, the only general in the mobile corps other than Puchner.<ref name=""Gyalókay""/>
* 2 companies of the 5th (""Prinz von Savoyen"") [[Dragoon]] Regiment,

column2: three-pounder]] infantry battery of the 5th (""Bervaldo"") [[Artillery]] Regiment,
six-pounder]] infantry battery of the 5th (""Bervaldo"") Artillery Regiment.

column1: Total: 4 battalions. 2 cavalry regiments, 2 batteries. (2480 infantry, 180 [[cavalry]], 12 guns).
* 3d Battalion of the 51st (""Karl Ferdinand"") Infantry Regiment,
* 1st and 2nd Battalions of the 63rd (""Bianchi"") Infantry Regiment,
* 3d battalion of the 16th (1st Romanian) Border Guard Infantry Regiment,
* one six-pounder infantry battery of the 5th (""Bervaldo"") Artillery Regiment,
* one three-pounder infantry battery of the 5th (""Bervaldo"") Artillery Regiment.
Total: 4 battalions, 2 cavalry regiments, 2 batteries (2530 infantry, 166 cavalry, 12 guns).
* 3rd and Reserve Battalion of the 62nd (""Tursky"") Infantry Regiment,
* 1/3 Battalion of the Bukovina Border Guards,
* eight companies of the 3rd (""E. H. Max"") [[Chevau-léger]] Cavalry Regiment,
* one six-pounder infantry battery of the 5th (""Bervaldo"") Artillery Regiment.
Total: 5 battalions, 8 cavalry companies, 2 batteries. (2740 infantry, 580 cavalry, 12 guns).<ref>{{Harvnb

So the whole corps consisted of '''13 battalions, 12 cavalry companies, and 6 batteries (36 guns). The total number of its personnel (without the artillerymen and carters) was 8676 soldiers.'''<ref name=""Gyalókay1"">{{Harvnb
column5: Puchner's report to Field Marshal Alfred I, Prince of Windisch-Grätz, mentions only 7452 soldiers, but Heydte's figures seem more likely, because Puchner, by talking about fewer soldiers, may have been trying to convince the main commander to send him more reinforcements.<ref name=""Gyalókay1""/>}} From this figure, however, must be deducted the losses caused by the battle of Medgyes, which were 322 men. Thus, the Austrian troops under Puchner, without the artillerymen and charioteers, numbered 8354, but with them, they could have reached 9000.<ref name=""Gyalókay1""/>

column1: His victory at Medgyes made Puchner to make a bold to surround and destroy Bem's troops with attacks from several directions.<ref name=""auto2""/> The [[military operation plan]] of Puchner’s army was prepared by the [[chief of staff]] of the Corps - [[Major]] Maroičić.<ref name=""Gyalókay""/> Its basic idea was that a stronger detachment under the leadership of Major August von Heydte would feign an attack in the direction of the Medgyes-Segesvár road through [[Berethalom]]-[[Váldhíd]]-[[Erzsébetváros]]-[[Holdvilág]]-Dános,<ref>{{Harvnb
column4: pp=77-78}}.</ref> make Bem to think that the main imperial troops are coming from there, thus luring him into the aforementioned defensive position.<ref name=""Gyalókay""/> Meanwhile, the rest of the corps would start its march on 6 March, bypassing Segesvár from the south, via Riomfalva (today a village of the municipality of Berethalom)-[[Bürkös]]-[[Szentágota]]-[[Hégen]]-[[Apold]]-Segesd (today a village of the municipality of Apold),<ref name=""2013b"">{{Harvnb
column7: pp=78}}.</ref> cutting off the Hungarian army from the main source of its strength, [[Székely Land]].<ref name=""Gyalókay""/> At that time, Maroičić was still counting on the support of Lieutenant-General Malkowski's troops from [[Bukovina]], which, he thought, by the time Puchner reached Segesvár, should have reached Marosvásárhely (he did not know that Bem already had driven Malkowski out of Transylvania),<ref name=""Gyalókay""/> thus tying up part of the Hungarian forces in Székely lLnd, from where Bem expected his reinforcements.<ref name=""auto2""/><ref name=""2013H"">{{Harvnb
column10: pp=77}}.</ref> Captain Count Alberti, with 1 1/2 companies of the 3rd Chevau-léger Regiment, starting from Medgyes, will [[Reconnaissance
column11: reconnoitre]] the right bank of the [[Târnava Mare
column12: Nagyküküllő]] and seek a connection to Marosvásárhely with the division of Lieutenant General Malkowski.<ref name=""Gyalókay2"">{{Harvnb
column15: pp=62}}.</ref> The plan had one, but very serious flaw: it had too many uncertainties. If Malkowski didn't attack, if any of the encircling columns were late, if Bem detected the encirclement attempt, the whole plan could fall apart.<ref name=""auto2""/>

column1: The quicker Puchner made his encircling movement, the less the Hungarian army could reorganize itself from the damages suffered at Medgyes, and the less he could strengthen itself by picking up reinforcements.<ref name=""Gyalókay2""/> But it was also certain that, it would have been inadvisable to attack Bem with a worn-out, exhausted Austrian army, after they covered the distance of 92 kilometers over hills and valleys on unmaintained bad roads, as it was planned.<ref name=""Gyalókay2""/> But, as we have seen above, this - and the waiting for Malkowski - was the main reason that caused Puchner to lose two days, and thus to lose the advantage won at Medgyes.<ref>{{Harvnb
The weather was also the worst possible: rain and melting snow, blizzard and frost alternated constantly.<ref name=""Gyalókay3"">{{Harvnb
column4: pp=63}}.</ref> The road, which had been passable enough a day before, had now become a thick mortar, in which man, horse, cannon, and cart alike could only move forward with bitter agony.<ref name=""Gyalókay3""/> The retreating Hungarians' guns were also stuck in the mud on the Medgyes-Segesvár road, and it was only due to the sluggishness of the pursuers that they did not fall into the hands of the Austrians.<ref name=""Gyalókay3""/> Thus it was easily conceivable, therefore, that on the side roads, which were isolated from the heavier traffic and not sufficiently prepared, even greater obstacles were placed in the way of the Austrian corps.<ref name=""Gyalókay3""/> The malnourished and exhausted traction horses were soon exhausted, so that 6 pairs of oxen had to pull each cannon out of the mud.<ref name=""Gyalókay3""/>

column1: Heydte reached Dános on 7 March, carried out the [[Demonstration (military)
column2: demonstration attack]], but then, on the night of 7 to 8 March, on Puchner's orders, he marched from Dános via the Holdvilág-Erzsébetváros-[[Szászsáros]] route to Bese (today part of Dános) to cover the left flank of the main column during the planned attack on Segesvár.<ref name=""2013b""/> As Puchner had ordered three companies of the 62nd Infantry Regiment to occupy Medgyes,<ref name=""Gyalókay2""/> and Heydte had a battalion of infantry, two companies of border guards, five companies of the [[National Guard]]s from Segesvár and one and a half companies of cavalry if he had remained in his original position, he could have formed a considerable obstacle to Bem's march towards Medgyes.<ref name=""2013b""/> However, Heydte's departure from Dános left the Medgyes-Segesvár-Nagyszeben route essentially uncovered.<ref name=""2013b""/>

column1: Heydte's appearance did indeed alarm the Hungarian corps at Segesvár, but after no battle occurred, and the enemy retreated at midnight, only his abandoned campfires glowed in the night until they too went out towards dawn.<ref >{{Harvnb

As seen above, Maroičić's operation plan was for Heydte's demonstrating detachment to lure Bem to a position between Dános and Segesvár, while Puchner's corps, behind the back of the Hungarians, would take Segesvár.<ref name=""Gyalókay4"">{{Harvnb

But for this to succeed, the demonstration at Dános should have taken place on the 8th, and not on the 7th, but before Bem could get news of the Austrian corps' approach.<ref name=""Gyalókay4""/> If the Hungarians didn't send scouts towards the south, Puchner might have been able to slip behind them undetected.<ref name=""Gyalókay4""/> But Bem was not so careless.<ref name=""Gyalókay4""/>

Maroičić, as can be seen from the plan, wanted to deploy Heydte's detachment in two directions, namely at Dános and Bese, but which, in the end, could not be sent either here or there, all the less so because he had not received any new orders to postpone the feigned attack until 8 March.<ref name=""Gyalókay4""/>

Puchner's bypassing column was thus thoroughly delayed on unpaved roads, in terrible weather conditions, thus on 8 March its brigades only reached Hégen and Apold.<ref name=""2013b""/> Because of the exhaustion of the soldiers, Puchner gave his troops a rest, and the two brigades at Hégen did not leave for Segesvár until the morning of the 9th, and Van der Nüll’s advance brigade from Apold departed only after their arrival at noon that day.<ref name=""2013b""/>

On the 8th, Bem had a clear view of the situation, which showed that the Austrians would not attack from Medgyes with any greater force, because according to the reports he received, most of Puchner's corps was approaching from the south.<ref name=""Gyalókay4""/>

Bem now was certain that, the nearest part of Puchner's corps was 15 1/2 and its farthest part 22 kilometers from Segesvár, so he decided to undertake the daring operation of leaving the town, marching through Medgyes and [[Szelindek]], and quickly attacking and occupying Nagyszeben before Puchner could intervene.<ref name=""Gyalókay4""/> Puchner, because to the aforementioned rest from exhaustion of his troops, started his march on the morning of the 9th, just as Bem was leaving Segesvár. Without this rest he might have succeeded in surrounding Bem.<ref name=""Gyalókay5""/>
The Hungarian success depended primarily on how fast the corps was moving, whether the enemy was directly behind it, and how long it would take to occupy Nagyszeben.<ref name=""Gyalókay5"">{{Harvnb
So on the morning of 9 March Bem's troops left Segesvár.<ref name=""Gyalókay8""/>

The Van der Nüll brigade left Apóld at noon on the 8th, where it waited for the other two brigades to approach, and therefore did not arrive to the vicinity of Segesvár until late afternoon, towards dusk: here it exchanged a few shots with the remaining Hungarian troops.<ref name=""Gyalókay5""/> The brigade's Staff Officer writes that Colonel Van der Nüll wanted to persuade the Corps' Chief of Staff to occupy Segesvár immediately.<ref name=""Gyalókay5""/> The latter, however, perhaps because Puchner had also held it back, was reluctant, and so the brigade received orders only at 9 p.m. to push into the town, which, according to the news received, had already been abandoned by the Hungarians that morning.<ref name=""Gyalókay5""/> Puchner with the Stutterheim brigade did not enter Segesvár until 2 a.m. on the 10th, and the Uracca brigade, together with the cavalry, moved in at 4 a.m., while the small Hungarian guard retreated towards [[Székelykeresztúr]].<ref name=""Gyalókay6"">{{Harvnb
column4: pp=66}}.</ref> Puchner did not understand the gravity of the situation at all.<ref name=""Gyalókay6""/> According to the military historian Jenő Gyalókay, when it turned out that there were no Hungarian soldiers in Segesvár, at 10 a.m. on 10 March Puchner was still of the opinion that Bem was either marching to Medgyes, to [[Kolozsvár]] or to Marosvásárhely, and therefore he did not decide anything for the time being, because he was waiting for news of the approach of the troops of Malkowski and Colonel [[Karl von Urban]] and wanted to plan his further actions in concordance to their positions.<ref name=""Gyalókay6""/> But also on 10 March at 5 p.m., he wrote to Lieutenant General Alois Pfersmann von Eichtal, head of the garrison from Nagyszeben, that according to the latest reports, part of the Hungarian army was moving towards Medgyes and that it may happen that Bem wanted to ''scare'' the garrison of Nagyszeben.<ref name=""Gyalókay6""/> So, as he wrote further, to prevent this ''very unlikely'' event to happen, he will march with his whole army through Riomfalva towards Nagyszeben.<ref name=""Gyalókay6""/>

column1: According to Puchner's calculation, Bem could not attack this city before 12 March; and its [[Russian Empire
column2: Russian]] and Austrian garrisons could successfully defend it for at least 24 hours.<ref name=""Gyalókay7"">{{Harvnb

column1: According to Heydte, the Austrian corps left Segesvár at 11 o'clock at night on the 10th, while according to Kalliány, 2 hours later.<ref name=""Gyalókay7""/> However, the Van der Nüll brigade, which was again put as advance guard, had already reached Dános during the morning.<ref name=""Gyalókay7""/> There the whole corps turned off the road from Segesvár to Medgyes and headed for [[Újegyház]] via Berethalom and Riomfalva, partly because this road was somewhat shorter than the other, and partly because the Austrians feared that Bem had destroyed the bridges behind him and tried to hold up Puchner's corps by occupying certain strategic points.<ref name=""Gyalókay7""/> The question was whether the Hungarian army would be able to take Nagyszeben before the pursuers arrived, or whether it would be destroyed in the ring of the defenders and pursuers.<ref name=""auto2""/>

Bem's troops reached [[Baráthely]] in torrential rain, drenched to the skin, at 2 a.m. on the 10th, and at 8 a.m. Medgyes, where three companies of the Austrian 62nd Infantry Regiment remained after Puchner's victory from 3 March.<ref name=""Gyalókay8"">{{Harvnb
column4: pp=68}}.</ref> This garrison was joined, on the evening of the 9th, by Captain Alberti's scout troop.<ref name=""Gyalókay8""/> The Austrian outposts were stationed between Medgyes and Baráthely, and here they had a small skirmish with the Hungarian advance unit; but no serious fighting took place, for the Austrian troops withdrew from Medgyes towards Nagyszeben at 7 o'clock on the morning of the 10th.<ref name=""Gyalókay8""/> However, First Lieutenant Henter, who had been sent to Nagyekemező, was taken prisoner by the Hungarians along with 30 of his men.<ref name=""Gyalókay8""/>

column1: Bem left behind 1000 rearguards at Medgyes,<ref name=""auto2""/> while others say 1500 soldiers and 4 guns, led by [[Lieutenant Colonel]] Pereczy.<ref name=""Gyalókay9"">{{Harvnb
column4: pp=69}}.</ref> In addition, as a mobile flank defence, Bem sent a detachment led by Lieutenant-Colonel Count Gergely Bethlen towards Dános-Váldhíd-Berethalom-Musna-Ivánfalva-Kiskapus at noon on the 9th.<ref name=""Gyalókay9""/> Bem's army arrived at [[Nagyselyk]] at 1 a.m. on 11 March, and after some rest continued on its way to Szelindek. From here he departed at noon, on the way he scattered a Russian [[Cossack]] troop and reached [[Nagycsűr]].<ref>{{Harvnb
column7: pp=79}}.</ref> Towards 4 p.m. he marched out from Nagycsűr, at its southern exit, behind the Alter Berg (Old Hill), which separates this village from Nagyszeben, and here he deployed his army in battle formation.<ref name=""Gyalókay10"">{{Harvnb
column10: pp=70}}.</ref><ref name=""Bánlaky"">Bánlaky József: [https://mek.oszk.hu/09400/09477/html/0021/2199.html Nagy-Szeben bevétele. 1849. március 11-én. A magyar nemzet hadtörténete XXI] Arcanum Adatbázis Kft. 2001</ref>

column1: In 1849, Nagyszeben was the most important city in Transylvania for the imperials. It was the headquarters of the Austrian troops from Transylvania called ''General-Commando'' and the main armament and equipment depot of the Transylvanian [[K.u.K.]] Corps, where a lot of clothing, weapons and ammunition, as well as all kinds of other war material were stockpiled.<ref name=""Gyalókay10""/> The ''Königsboden'' (King's Land) where the most Transylvanian Saxons lived, and which's center was Nagyszeben, also provided plenty of men for the war, and so this region was in fact the base of operations for the Austrian corps in Transylvania.<ref name=""Gyalókay10""/> Its importance was increased by the fact that at the beginning of February Windisch-Grätz authorized Puchner to retreat to [[Wallachia]] if necessary.<ref name=""Gyalókay10""/> The [[Turnu Roșu Pass
column2: Vöröstorony]] (Red Tower) Pass, the most easily accessible link between Transylvania and Wallachia, has its northern entrance below Nagyszeben: the loss of this city could cut off this route and force the Austrian army, which might be forced to leave Transylvania, to take the [[Rucăr-Bran Pass
column4: Tömös Pass]] by a long detour.<ref name=""Gyalókay10""/>

column1: On 10 March, in the afternoon, Puchner himself had already thought - though he did not really believe - that Bem could attack Sibiu.<ref name=""Gyalókay10""/> He, therefore, marched towards it, confident that the city was adequately prepared and well-equipped for defense, and would be able to defend itself until the arrival of the Austrian relief corps.<ref>{{Harvnb
column4: pp=70-71}}.</ref> It was surrounded by a strong and high circular wall, interrupted by towers, and in 1702 King [[Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor
column5: Leopold I]] ordered the construction of a [[citadel]] with a bastioned [[façade]].<ref name=""Gyalókay11"">{{Harvnb
column8: pp=71}}.</ref> By 1777, only traces of this fortress, built of earth, remained. In the course of time, parts of the city walls were demolished and it was only in November 1848 that the reconstruction of Nagyszeben was started, in order to become a defensible fortress.<ref name=""Gyalókay11""/>

column1: It was no perimeter wall on the southeast side of the town. A temporary fortification - with an earth and pile wall - compensated for its absence.<ref name=""Gyalókay11""/> The [[Cibin
column2: Szeben]] river, which flows on one side of the city center, replaced the main ditch.<ref name=""Gyalókay11""/> The suburbs were surrounded by earthworks and their surroundings were artificially flooded, where it was possible, with the swollen water of the river.<ref name=""Gyalókay11""/> Every street in the town leading to the defenses was blocked off with a pile barrier or barricade.<ref name=""Gyalókay11""/> The perimeter walls were equipped for the positioning of cannons on them; defensive corridors were built around them and [[embrasure]]s were cut into them.<ref name=""Gyalókay11""/>

column1: So everything seemed to be in place for the successful defense of the city, and Puchner was not unreasonably confident that Bem would not be able to take Nagyszeben in less than 24 hours.<ref name=""Gyalókay11""/>

The battlefield of 11 March was divided into three distinct parts. The first is the Alter Berg and its immediate surroundings, the second was the small plain between the Alter Berg and Nagyszeben, and the third was the city itself.ref>{{Harvnb

Nagycsűr was built in the Krummbach stream’s valley. On its southern side, Alter Berg rose more than 100 meters above the village, and the slope towards Sibiu was covered with vineyards. The rest of the hill was barren.<ref name=""Gyalókay14"">{{Harvnb
column4: pp=74}}.</ref> The plain at the southern foothills, interspersed with small willows and serving mainly as a pasture, in addition to several waterways, was crisscrossed by draining ditches in all directions, which were hindering, in particular, the rapid movement of cavalry and artillery.<ref name=""Gyalókay14""/>

column1: On the afternoon of March 10, the Austrian troops retreating from Medgyes brought the alarming news of Bem's approach.<ref name=""Gyalókay14""/> The leader of the Russian troops at Nagyszeben, Colonel [[Grigory Skariatin]], at 5 p.m. that afternoon, launched a battalion and two cannons each at Szelindek and Vízakna, not being sure of the direction of Bem’s attack. At the same time, he ordered his troops stationed at [[Nagytalmács]] to come to Nagyszeben, and they arrived during the night.<ref name=""Gyalókay14""/> On the 11th the Russian battalion sent to Szelindek withdrew from the Hungarians without a fight, and together with the battalion sent to Vízakna retreated towards Nagyszeben.<ref name=""Gyalókay14""/>

At the same time, Pfersmann urgently wrote to Puchner that the situation in Nagyszeben was indeed critical and that the city would not be able to resist Bem's army for long. He, therefore, asked for urgent help.<ref name=""Gyalókay15""/>

However, Lieutenant-General Pfersmann and Colonel Grigory Skariatin did not seem too worried about Bem's troops, and, somewhat overconfident, instead of remaining behind the city walls, they marched out in front of them, did not occupy the city defenses, nor did they use the artillery on the walls.<ref name=""auto2""/> This may have been due to the fact that the commanders of the forces defending Nagyszeben, hearing of Bem's defeat at Medgyes, believed that the disorganized units of the defeated army had arrived in front of the city, and they hoped to give them the coup de grâce.<ref name=""Babucs""/>
The Hungarian army that arrived under Nagyszeben had covered 85 kilometers in 53 hours, so they could not be called well-rested by any meaning.<ref name=""auto2""/>
Bem had around 4500-4700 soldiers, the total number of the army defending the city was around 6000.<ref name=""2013i""/>
The composition of the '''Troops from Nagyszeben''', as can be seen from the official report of 1 April 1849, was as follows:<ref name=""Gyalókay12"">{{Harvnb
* 3 companies of the [[Modlin, Nowy Dwór County
* 2 rookie companies of the 31 infantry regiment;
* 6 reserve companies of the 51 infantry regiment;
* 1 rookie company of the 16 border guard regiment;
* 2 platoons of the 11. Székely hussar regiment.
* 2 battalions of the Saxon national guards.
Garrison total: '''cc. 6000 soldiers, 4 cavalry companies, 8 cannons.'''<ref name=""2013x""/>
The '''Hungarian army''' was composed as it follows:
* 3. battalion of the 37. (Michael) Line Infantry Regiment
* 2. battalion of the 14. infantry regiment (later 77. Honvéd battalion)
* 3. battalion of the 14. infantry regiment (later 78. Honvéd battalion)
* 3. battalion of the 14. infantry regiment (later 78. Honvéd battalion)

Skariatin himself now set off with the rest of his troops to occupy the top of the Alten Berg; but he was too late, and settled at the foot of the hill, instead of taking the roof.<ref name=""Gyalókay14""/> Only a single line of [[skirmisher]]s pushed up the slope into the vineyards; but the bulk of the infantry, with their right flank against the base of the hill, was on the eastern side of the highway to Nagycsűr.<ref name=""Gyalókay14""/> The artillery was deployed near the highway, with the Cossacks on the left, near the Krummbach.<ref name=""Gyalókay15"">{{Harvnb
column4: pp=76}}.</ref> The second battle line, in Pfersmann's report, was formed by the combined Austrian battalion led by Captain Count Heusenstamm.<ref name=""Gyalókay15""/> The defenders were thus developed to fight on the plain to the north of the city, at the bottom of the heights of Nagycsűr, with the Imperial troops to the east of the main road.<ref name=""Bánlaky""/>
Transylvanian Panorama depircting the Second Battle of Nagyszeben - Jan Styka]]

column1: The Saxon National Guards remained in the town as a reserve, and defense force of the city<ref name=""Bánlaky""/> for the protection of which, as Pfersmann claimed in his report, all the measures were taken.<ref name=""Gyalókay15""/> The Saxon National Guard was united in the main square of the town and the castle cannons were provided with cannoneers.<ref name=""Gyalókay15""/> The ammunition stored in the warehouses was placed on the ammunition carts, just in case, and the war chest was sent towards the Vöröstorony Pass.<ref name=""Gyalókay15""/>
It was 4 o'clock in the afternoon when Bem's infantry, having reached the top of the Alter Berg Hill from Nagycsűr, caught sight of the enemy in battle formation.<ref name=""Gyalókay15""/>
[[File:Second Battle of Nagyszeben 11.03.1849. The situation between 4-5 p.m.png
column5: Second Battle of Nagyszeben 11.03.1849. The situation between 4-5 p.m]]

column1: Bem, who deployed his artillery on the high ground along the highway,<ref name=""Bánlaky""/>as usual, poured in a tremendous artillery barrage on the enemy troops positioned in front of the town. The Russian infantry withstood this relatively well,<ref name=""auto2""/>and for the moment his skirmish line between the vines has not faltered either. Skariatin sent his Cossacks to attack the Hungarian right flank, in order to bypass it from the rear,<ref name=""Gyalókay16"">{{Harvnb
column4: pp=77}}.</ref> but the [[grapeshot]] of the Hungarian artillery put them in disorder, causing them to flee in panic.<ref name=""auto2""/> The Hungarian artillery inflicted so much damage on the Cossacks that they could not be used against the Hungarians in the rest of the battle.<ref name=""Bánlaky""/> Bem now ordered the center and right wing to advance<ref name=""Babucs""/> and pressed more and more infantry against the enemy's left flank, advancing on the slope of the Pfaffenbrunn hill, intending to bypass it.<ref name=""Gyalókay16""/> However, Skariatin saw what was happening and before the encirclement could take place, at 5 p.m., he retreated to a second position between Alten Berg and Nagyszeben.<ref name=""Gyalókay16""/> Bem's troops immediately descended from the hill, then the artillery duel started again.<ref name=""Gyalókay16""/>

column1: [[File:Second Battle of Nagyszeben 11.03.1849. The situation between 5-7 p.m.png
column4: Second Battle of Nagyszeben 11.03.1849. The situation between 5-7 p.m]]

column1: On Bem's orders, the Mátyás hussars attacked in the direction of [[Gușterița
column2: Szenterzsébet]] (Hammersdorf), the Koburg and Wilhelm hussars led by Lieutenant-Colonel Kiss, attacked the left flank of the Russian army,<ref name=""Bánlaky""/>while the rookie Székely infantry, some of whom, because of the shortage of riffles, had only spears, launched a bayonet charge against the enemy's center.<ref name=""Bóna"">Bóna Gábor: [https://www.3szek.ro/load/cikk/78814/nagyszeben-bevetele-erdely-felszabaditasa-a-magyar-forradalom-es-szabadsagharc-harom-pillanata A magyar forradalom és szabadságharc három pillanata. Nagyszeben bevétele, Erdély felszabadítása] Háromszék. 2015. március 14., szombat</ref>

column1: Seeing that both of his flanks were threatened by encirclement, as early as 6 a.m., Skariatin ordered the retreat to the entrenched suburbs.<ref name=""Gyalókay16""/>
[[File:Battle of Hermannstadt - sketched by Capt. Ed. Scheifele ; drawn on stone & lith by Schaerff & Bro. 71 Market Str. St. Louis. LCCN2006677461.tif
column4: Battle of Hermannstadt - sketched by Capt. Ed. Scheifele]]

column1: At the same time, Lieutenant-Colonel Sándor Kiss with the Coburg and Wilhelm Hussars attacked the Russian battery which was covering the retreat of the troops, and forced it to withdraw.<ref name=""Gyalókay17"">{{Harvnb

Major General [[Artur Nepokoychitsky]] describes the retreat of the Russian troops as follows: ''The retreat was carried out in exemplary order despite the persistent pursuit of the Hungarians. The infantry stopped several times and charged the enemy with bayonets. In the meantime, it had become so dark that the enemy's columns could no longer be seen, and even the line of attack was only indicated by rifle fire. It was feared that our columns, bravely repulsing the advancing enemy with their bayonets, would become so involved in the fight that the enemy would cut them off, so Colonel Skariatin himself led the bayonet charges, and did not allow our soldiers to venture too far.''<ref name=""Babucs""/>

The combined Austrian battalion led by Lieutenant General Pfersmann, apart from a few aimless movements behind the front line, had done nothing so far. Now, however, the 20th Company of the 51st Infantry Regiment occupied the barricaded eastern gate of the suburb, while the 19th Company, which was slightly behind, stood in reserve.<ref>{{Harvnb

The battle continued at the suburb's defenses, the Hungarians trying to enter the city. After an hour's fighting - at 7 pm - despite the Hungarian troops had taken the outlying houses, their attack had stalled there for the time being.<ref name=""Gyalókay17""/> The [[Royal Hungarian Honvéd
column2: Honvéds]] were exhausted by the long march, followed by the battle, and the darkness prevented any orientation; and Gergely Bethlen's long-awaited detachment, which had arrived at Kiskapus only on the morning of the 11th, was nowhere to be seen.<ref name=""Gyalókay17""/> Hosszabb szünet állott be.<ref name=""Gyalókay17""/>

column1: [[File:Siege of Nagyszeben - postcard from the Period of the Dualism.jpg
column5: Siege of Nagyszeben - postcard from the Period of the Dualism]]

column1: In the meantime, Bem's artillery was shelling the city.<ref>{{Harvnb
column4: pp=194-195}}.</ref> Bem was about to postpone the siege until the next day, when the reserve brigade of about 850-1000 men and 4 guns, led by Colonel Gergely Bethlen, finally arrived,<ref name=""2013d"">{{Harvnb
column7: pp=80}}.</ref> with a Székely battalion, the 11th Honvéd battalion and a [[Jäger]] [[squadron]].<ref name=""Bánlaky""/> ''Mr. Major, do you want to sleep in Nagyszeben today?'' asked Bem to the unit's commander, Olivér Bethlen. ''Yes, and my battalion has the same wish,'' Bethlen replied. ''Well, then, go on the attack with your battalion and stand up in the square,'' Bem said, as if nothing could be more normal.<ref name=""auto3"">{{Harvnb

column1: [[File:Heinrich Gerhart - Die Schlacht bei Hermannstadt den 13ten März 1849 - Wien Museum Online Sammlung 88629 1-2.jpg
column4: Heinrich Gerhart - Battle of Nagyszeben 11 March 1849 - Wien Museum Online Sammlung 88629 1-2]]

column1: Bem immediately directed Bethlen's detachment to the left flank of the Hungarian army, and then ordered his troops to attack the outskirts.<ref name=""Gyalókay17""/> But here there was a near-fatal mix-up among the troops. For in the total darkness, it was impossible to distinguish friend from foe, and so it happened that some of the left wing's troops which remained behind blindly shot into Bethlen's battalions, which were ahead of them, thinking that they were enemy soldiers.<ref name=""Gyalókay17""/> Fortunately, Hussar Colonel Sándor Kiss, who recognized the danger that could result from this, somehow brought order and calm among the troops, by stopping the senseless shooting.<ref name=""Gyalókay17""/>

In the meantime, some houses in the suburbs had been set on fire by the Hungarian grenades, so due to this, now it was easier to see.<ref name=""Gyalókay17""/> But now the firelight also benefited the city's defenders by illuminating the attackers.<ref>{{Harvnb
column4: pp=78-79}}.</ref> But this could not stop the assault troops, which had gained new momentum and were led by the 11th Honvéd Battalion. It was joined by the Máriássy Battalion, a Székely battalion, and part of the [[Debrecen]] Jägers.<ref name=""Gyalókay18"">{{Harvnb
column7: pp=79}}.</ref> Soon the 4 companies of the 3rd Battalion of the 14th Border Guard Regiment, about 520-530 men, led by Major Károly Kabos, arrived and they also joined the attack.<ref name=""2013d""/>

column1: The veteran soldiers of the 11th and the Máriássy battalions went on the attack, singing war songs and showing death-defying courage.<ref name=""Bóna""/> On two occasions, the attack was repulsed by the defenders' rifle fire, until finally a third time, which succeeded.<ref name=""Gyalókay18""/> Captain Miklós Szigeti, commander of the 11th (Kolozsvár) battalion, distinguished for their bravery shown in numerous earlier battles, with the red caps which they wore, wrote the following about their decisive attack: ''""Let's go, Hungarian! Long live the homeland!"" - rang out in the darkness painted red by flames, and with this cry the whole mass rushed forward with their bayonets, climbing the [[rampart]]s with incredible speed, breaking the main gate, mowing down the enemy gunners beside their guns (...) and all this happened as if by magic.''<ref name=""Babucs""/> Skariatin renounced to further defense of the suburbs, and evacuated them, retreating to the upper town.<ref name=""Gyalókay18""/> There, at the great barracks, at the outer end of the street towards Vöröstorony, he gathered his troops, joined also by the Austrian soldiers.<ref name=""Gyalókay18""/>
[[File:The capture of Nagyszeben in 11 March 1849 - György Gracza.jpg
column5: The capture of Nagyszeben in 11 March 1849 - György Gracza]]

column1: To the success of the Hungarian assault also contributed the fact that the stalemate of Bem's troops at 7 pm and the temporary cessation of the attacks led the defenders to wrongly believe, that the siege would continue the next day. It was precisely for this reason that the Saxon National Guard was dispersed and the city walls were not properly defended.<ref name=""Gyalókay18""/> The Saxon garrison in the walled inner city, which was destined to defend the main square, was sent home, allegedly on the news that Bem's 7 o'clock attack on the city had failed, without any provision being made for closing and guarding the gates.<ref name=""Gyalókay23""/>
[[File:Second Battle of Nagyszeben 11.03.1849. The situation between 7-12 p.m.png
column4: Second Battle of Nagyszeben 11.03.1849. The situation between 7-12 p.m]]

column1: Thus the Hungarians were able to enter the inner city through two gates without any resistance.<ref name=""Gyalókay18""/>

Major General Artur Nepokoychitsky describes the retreat as follows: ''The detachment, which had been hard pressed all the time, reached the gate towards Vízakna at 10 o'clock in the evening... Shortly afterward, flames broke out in several places in the suburbs, and even in our rear, on the other side of the town, on the road to Vöröstorony, which forced Colonel Skariatin to march quickly through the town towards ''[the city's entrance from the direction of]'' Vöröstorony. The commander of the detachment, after sending the artillery under the cover of ten infantry regiments, himself remained behind with a battalion in the rearguard, and engaged the advancing enemy, first at the city gate and then in pursuit ''[by the Hungarians]'' through the suburbs towards Vízakna, sometimes with bayonets and sometimes in hand-to-hand combat.''<ref name=""Babucs""/>
The retreat, in the narrow streets of the city, soon degenerated into a dangerous stampede.<ref name=""GyalókayII"">{{Harvnb
column4: pp=85}}.</ref> The darkness, dispersed from time to time only by the flash of shells exploding here and there and the flames from burning houses, was not a source of encouragement. Skariatin's troops did not want to remain in the rear; this undesirable role was intended for the Austrian soldiers, whom the Russians, therefore, sought to bypass, even by force.<ref name=""GyalókayII""/> Only on the other side of the city was the order restored, but there was no question of either the Russians or the Austrians trying to resist there.<ref name=""GyalókayII""/>

column1: On the following morning, the Russo-Austrian troops retreated as far as Nagytalmács, at the narrow entrance to the Vöröstorony Pass, and smaller Imperial detachments as far as Zóod and Talmacsel (today parts of the same city), where they remained, without being attacked, until 16 March.<ref name=""Bánlaky""/> Nagyszeben was in Bem's hands already between 9 and 10 p.m.<ref name=""Gyalókay18""/>

In terms of casualties, Bem's report seems completely unbelievable, as it indicates that only 5 soldiers of the Hungarian corps were killed and 35 wounded in the battle, which lasted more than 5 hours.<ref name=""Gyalókay19""/> Other sources put Hungarian casualties at 40 dead and 98 wounded, which may be closer to the truth.<ref name=""Gyalókay19""/> By their own account, the Russians had 99 dead and 104 wounded.<ref name=""Gyalókay19""/> The British Consul-General in [[Bucharest]] [[Robert Gilmour Colquhoun]] reports 97 dead, 150 wounded, and 154 missing Russians.<ref name=""Gyalókay19""/> The, probably smaller, losses of the Austrians and the Saxon National Guards are unknown.<ref name=""Gyalókay19""/>

The booty taken by the Hungarians was very considerable. According to the contemporary historian László Kővári, ''21 cannons, 1 million rifle cartridges, 6,000 cannonballs, 5,000 small guns ''(probably riffles)'', 150 [[hundredweight]] of gunpowder, large quantities of food and clothing, and among other things the cannon battery that the Hungarians lost at Vízakna. Lieutenant-Colonel B. Berger and Major Teichert, 14 officers, 115 enlisted men were taken prisoners; 850 sick ''[soldiers]'' were left behind in the hospitals, among them 123 wounded Russians.""<ref name=""Babucs""/>

Besides this, Nagyszeben was also the headquarters of the General-Commando, the Saxon movement, and of the Romanian National Committee, both hostiles to the Hungarian revolutionary government.<ref>Egyed Ákos: [http://varlap.hu/content/vkt_2013_4/vkt_2013_4_2_1.pdf Nagyszeben bevétele 1849. március 11-én] Várak, kastélyok, templomok. 9. évf. 4. sz. / 2013, pp. 14</ref> Therefore the documents left behind of all of these fell prey to the Hungarians.<ref name=""Babucs""/>

In addition to these, Hungarian men and women prisoners and hostages, who had been rounded up by the Austrians during the Austrian rule in Transylvania and held as prisoners in the monasteries and convents of the city, were also freed.<ref name=""Babucs""/>
The mayor of the town had previously offered a 3000 [[Hungarian forint
column2: forint]] bounty on Bem's head, and now Bem went to him, offering himself for the reward: ''Well, Mr. Mayor, here I am, I brought myself here, I want the three thousand forints. The ''[frightened]'' mayor half-consciously paid the sum to the commander-in-chief, who then distributed the money among his soldiers.''<ref name=""Babucs""/> Nagyszeben did not get away that easily. It had to pay 100,000 silver forints for military uniforms, to provide 50 pairs of equipped horses, and to produce the following items of uniform: 3,600 [[Attila (clothing)
column3: atillas]], 5,700 trousers, and the same number of pairs of boots, 6,000 hats, and 10,000 shirts and underpants.<ref name=""Babucs""/>

column1: So the victory also had the character of avengement. For Bem for the defeat on 21 January, for the Hungarian army for the fall of the city that had joined forces with all the enemies of the Hungarian revolution, not only the Habsburg power but also Tsarist Russia.<ref name=""vkt"">Egyed Ákos: [http://varlap.hu/content/vkt_2013_4/vkt_2013_4_2_1.pdf Nagyszeben bevétele 1849. március 11-én] Várak, kastélyok, templomok. 9. évf. 4. sz. / 2013, pp. 15</ref>  Bem also reprimanded Nagyszeben for calling in the Russian troops, but, true to his well-known amnesty policy, he promised that the Hungarian government would ""cast a veil of oblivion over the past"".<ref name=""vkt""/>

Bem, in his appeal to the people of Nagyszeben, written on 12 March, pointed out that the support of the Austrian army, the call-up of the Russian army, and the propaganda spread from the city, which was defamatory of the Hungarians, containing slanders and untruths, and the ''understandable'' anger of the soldiers who finally took the city, led to some robberies and atrocities<ref name=""Egyed"">{{Harvnb
column4: pp=369}}.</ref> (for example the killing by a hussar, ""in unknown circumstances"", of Joseph Benigni, the editor of the leading newspaper of Nagyszeben, the ''Siebenbürger Bote'', who consistently called Hungarians rebels and used derogatory terms against the Hungarian army)<ref name=""vkt""/> but from now on he forbids any further violence under the most severe penalty.<ref name=""Egyed""/>He also pointed out that during the previous battles, all the towns whose Saxon inhabitants, who, despite not having a positive view of the Hungarians but did not attack the Hungarian soldiers (Beszterce, Medgyes, Segesvár, [[Szászváros]]) were spared, and that the reason for the brief robberies in Nagyszeben, which lasted until his forceful intervention, was the justified anger of his soldiers at the invitation of the Russians.<ref name=""Egyed""/> The appeal also stated that the Hungarian army is fighting for the freedom not only of Hungarians but also of other nationalities living in the country and that this is shown by the fact that not only Hungarians but also a large number of nationalities of all languages and religions are fighting in its ranks.<ref name=""Egyed""/> ''You called for Russian help. This is a disgrace to the whole of Europe and a stamp of justice on our cause. This could not have been the wish of all the Transylvanian Saxons, who had been such [[Anti-Russian sentiment
column5: Russophobes]] even a short time before. You can only clear yourselves of the accusation of this despicable act by publicly withdrawing it.''<ref name=""Egyed""/> Finally, he promises to ""cast a veil of oblivion over the past"" and to give the people of Nagyszeben the freedom to choose their officials, but they must accept the Union with Hungary, which he says meant a ''choice between the freedom and the [[knout]]'', and promise not to invite the Russians in again.<ref name=""Egyed""/> The Saxons in Nagyszeben have promised everything, including a formal protest against the Russian intervention.<ref name=""Egyed1""/>

column1: [[File:The liberation of southern Traansylvania from the Austrian and Russian forces by the Hungarian army after the Battle of Nagyszeben from 11 March 1849.png
column4: The liberation of southern Traansylvania from the Austrian and Russian forces by the Hungarian army after the Battle of Nagyszeben from 11 March 1849]]

column1: Bem wanted to bring order and restore everyday life as quickly as possible, so he promised protection to all residents who were harmed, and he would bring the perpetrators of robbery or pillage to justice in a court-martial.<ref name=""vkt""/>

The new commander-in-chief of the city, Colonel Bánffy, appointed by Bem, promised, in the spirit of Bem, to protect the safety of persons and property, which he considered his main task, and asked the population that had fled to return to their homes in the city.<ref name=""vkt""/>

Before he moved out from Segesvár to Nagyszeben Bem had to expect the dangers which this bold action could bring. He had to anticipate three possible outcomes. The first was that Puchner would arrive before the assault on Nagyszeben; the second, that he would arrive during the battle; and the third, that he would arrive after the capture of the city..<ref name=""Gyalókay20"">{{Harvnb
column4: pp=81}}.</ref> The first two possibilities, though unlikely, would have posed a threat to his armies, but in the end the third, the most likely, was the one that materialised.<ref name=""Gyalókay19""/>

column1: Bem's plan of operations was based on the assumption that Puchner - either because he was late or because his fatigued troops needed rest - would not be able to intervene in time.<ref name=""Gyalókay19""/> He did not think that his opponent would be in Nagyszeben before him, nor did he expect even his arrival on the 12th, which is evident from the fact that seeing his attack losing its strength on the evening of the 11th, he was already thinking of postponing the capture of Nagyszeben until the next day.<ref name=""Gyalókay19""/>

Even if Bem had not succeeded in taking the city, his advance on Segesvár-Nagyszeben would still have had an important strategic result: to turn Puchner back towards Nagyszeben.<ref name=""Gyalókay21"">{{Harvnb

The main source of Bem's strength was Székely land, and as events have shown, he tried his best to keep the enemy away from this territory until the very end of the war.<ref name=""Gyalókay21""/> Puchner, on the other hand, relied on Königsboden (Királyföld), the region of [[Fogaras]], and the [[Barcaság]]. It was Königsboden he feared the most to lose.<ref name=""Gyalókay21""/> thus, the fact that Bem, who had slipped away from Segesvár, and was marching towards Nagyszeben, forced Puchner to turn on his heel and rush to the defense of his base of operations, which was now under imminent threat.<ref name=""Gyalókay21""/> In other words, the Austrian commander did what Bem forced him to do.<ref name=""Gyalókay22"">{{Harvnb
And since Bem had already driven the Austrians out of the [[Tihuța Pass
column2: Borgó Pass]], after Puchner's return the enemy no longer threatened Székely land from either direction. In contrast, the Austrian corps had to march almost 200 kilometers from Medgyes to Segesvár and from there to Nagyszeben - and all this in vain.<ref name=""Gyalókay22""/> Twice as much as Bem, who started from Segesvár with rested troops, on a much better road than the Austrians.<ref name=""Gyalókay22""/> Puchner's army was therefore much more tired, and even if he would have scored a decisive victory against Bem on 11 March, due to the exhaustion of his troops, he would have been unable to launch a major offensive operation immediately after it, which could have end the war in his favor.<ref name=""Gyalókay22""/>

column1: All the less so because Bem's army kept growing, while his army kept shrinking.<ref name=""Gyalókay22""/> Bem did not take with him the whole Transylvanian army under Nagyszeben, and thus only a part of it, in the worst case, could be destroyed in an eventual defeat, as happened earlier in the battle of Vízakna, and later at [[Battle of Segesvár
column2: Segesvár]].<ref name=""Gyalókay22""/> However fatal a crushing defeat at Nagyszeben would have been for a part of the Transylvanian army of Bem, the fate of the campaign could not have been decided by this, but only by a successful attack on the rest of the Transylvanian army that followed immediately afterwards.<ref name=""Gyalókay22""/> Puchner, however, could not do such a thing, with his ever-dwindling army.<ref name=""Gyalókay22""/> It was only strong enough when it was in the immediate vicinity of Nagyszeben or [[Brassó]], where it could count on the support of the Russians who did not want to venture too far from those cities.<ref name=""Gyalókay22""/>

column1: It should be mentioned that Austrian officers involved in the campaign attributed Bem's rapid success not only to Puchner's delay but also to the serious omissions made in the defense of Nagyszeben.<ref>{{Harvnb
column4: pp=83-84}}.</ref> According to them, the city would certainly have been defensible until the arrival of the relief corps.<ref name=""Gyalókay23"">{{Harvnb
column7: pp=84}}.</ref> It also appears from the description of the eyewitness Captain Rästle that not everything was done to defend Nagyszeben.<ref name=""Gyalókay23""/>

column1: At the time, when the attacking Hungarians were stalled for lack of reinforcements, there was just enough time to pack the city walls with soldiers.<ref name=""Gyalókay23""/> Indeed, it is hard to believe that Bem could so easily overpower Nagyszeben if the defenders did not stop fighting after the first success of Gergely Bethlen's attack.<ref name=""Gyalókay23""/> Every hour that the resistance was prolonged brought the relief corps closer, so that the struggle, which was so soon interrupted, did not seem hopeless.<ref name=""Gyalókay23""/>
However, Bem had no offensive intentions until the newly recruited battalions that came with him were armed and the situation was sufficiently clarified.<ref name=""GyalókayIII""/>

On 12 March, the bulk of Puchner's army which was following Bem, reached as far as Újegyház, his vanguard as far as Alzen. Puchner himself learned of the fall of Nagyszeben in Alzen.<ref name=""auto3""/> Ironically, Lieutenant General Puchner was appointed Field Marshal on 11 March, on the very same day his career as an army leader collapsed.<ref name=""Bóna""/>The news of the loss of Nagyszeben made him quite sick, so he handed over command to Major General József Kalliány. Kalliány's plan was to join forces with Skariatin to retake Nagyszeben.<ref name=""auto3""/> He therefore sent his troops to [[Felek]] and Fenyőfalva (today part of Felek) on the 13th.<ref name=""auto3""/>

Bem was right to fear that the Austrians would try to retake Nagyszeben. In his report on the battle to [[Lajos Kossuth]], Bem wrote that he feared that Puchner would try to retake the city. He was also aware that the Austrians still had a superior force in Transylvania.<ref name=""Egyed1"">{{Harvnb

On the night following the battle, Bem equipped his around 2,000 Szekler volunteers, who had until then only spears, with bayonet riffles and supplemented from among them the 11th Honvéd and the Máriássy battalions to 1360 soldiers.<ref name=""Bánlaky""/> In addition to this, he called to him the troops of Bánffy and Pereczy, who had been sent out earlier with about 4,000 men, the detachment of Major Herkalovics with the 32nd  and 50th Honvéd Battalions, whom he had sent to Kolozsvár, and a squadron of the 15th (Matthias) Hussar Regiment, formed in Kolozsvár,<ref name=""Bánlaky""/><ref name=""GyalókayIII""/> increasing his army to 14-15,000 men.<ref name=""auto3""/> On 12 March in the same afternoon, with his army, thus increased in size and reorganized, he then set up camp between Sibiu and [[Sellenberk]],<ref name=""GyalókayIII"">{{Harvnb
column4: pp=86}}.</ref > Lieutenant-Colonel Károlyi occupied Vesztény (today part of Sellenberk) to prevent any attempt of Russian counterattack,<ref name=""GyalókayIII""/> and also sent Lieutenant-Colonel Bethlen with a small detachment to find the bulk of the Imperial Army under Puchner, via [[Dolmány]], Holcmány and Leschkirch (today both are parts of Újegyház), towards Erzsébetváros and Segesvár.<ref name=""Bánlaky""/>

column1: According to Czetz, Bethlen wanted to fight with the approaching Austrian army, but according to Kalliány, some Hungarian prisoners of war said that he wanted to return to Székely land.<ref name=""GyalókayIII""/>

The total force at Kalliány's disposal was 8,000 soldiers, not counting the [[Gyulafehérvár]] garrison and the thousands of Romanian insurgents.<ref name=""auto3""/> Skariatin was at the Vöröstorony Strait with 4,200 men, and Engelhardt at Brassó with 4,800.<ref name=""auto3""/> So he had still a much stronger force than Bem's troops. But the Russians could only be counted on in defensive fighting.<ref name=""auto3""/>
Bem left 2,000 soldiers in Nagyszeben as a garrison,<ref>{{Harvnb
column4: pp=369}}.</ref>  and then led a brigade under Colonel János Bánffy against Skariatin in the Vöröstorony Pass.<ref name=""auto3""/> János Czetz's brigade was given the task of occupying the bridge from Felek and cutting off the connection of the K.u.K. detachment there with Skariatin.<ref name=""auto3""/> On 15 March, this order was carried out. On that day, the Bánffy Brigade led by Bem attacked the Imperial troops defending the Vöröstorony Pass, which was the rearguard of the Russians, and drove them out of Transylvania.<ref name=""auto3""/>

column1: By 16 March, the entire Russo-Austrian from the Vöröstorony pass was already camped south to the [[Carpathian Mountains
column2: Carpathians]] in Wallachia.<ref name=""auto3""/> On 16 March Czetz's brigade reached Fogaras. Kalliány regrouped his troops west of Brassó.<ref name=""auto3""/> Soon, however, he received a message from Major General Engelhardt, commander of the Russian troops in Brassó, telling him that if he was threatened by a force larger than his own, he would have to retreat to Wallachia.<ref name=""auto3""/> Kalliány then withdrew his troops to the immediate vicinity of Brassó, and decided to defend the city together with the Russians.<ref name=""auto3""/> However, when Engelhardt saw the exhausted, worn-out imperial troops, he announced that he would retreat to Wallachia, and demanded that Kalliány occupy the Tömös Strait with two brigades to ensure this. Kalliány complied with the request but weakened his main forces at [[Feketehalom]].<ref name=""auto3""/>

battle took place there]] on 19 March.<ref name=""auto3""/> Czetz's artillery repulsed the attempts of the Imperial Infantry to attack, and after the reinforcements led by Bem broke the resistance of his left flank, the Imperial Army retreated to Brassó.<ref name=""auto3""/> During the pursuit, the imperial troops suffered heavy losses. On 20 March, the allies evacuated Brassó and retreated toward the Strait of Tömös. Bem occupied the city the same day and ordered the pursuit of the retreating troops.<ref name=""auto3""/>

column1: On 21 March, the detachment of Lieutenant Colonel József Beke and Major Nándor Szabó caught up with the Imperial troops and made their retreat, already torturous in cold, snowy, and icy weather, even more difficult.<ref>{{Harvnb
column4: pp=195-196}}.</ref> On the same day, Major August Heydte's detachment left Transylvania through the Törcsvár Strait.<ref name=""auto4"">{{Harvnb

column1: After the occupation of Brassó, Bem returned to Nagyszeben because he had received news that Skariatin was trying to invade again.<ref name=""auto4""/> On 28 March, he attacked the Russian detachment stationed at the quarantine house in the Vöröstorony strait (a building used for the medical isolation of arrivals in case of customs and epidemic danger) and drove it to Wallachia.<ref name=""auto4""/> This meant that now almost all Transylvania - with the exception of the Austrian garrisons from the fortress of Gyulafehervár, the castle of [[Déva]], and the [[Apuseni Mountains
column2: Érchegység]] Mountains in the hands of the Romanian insurrection - was in the hands of the Hungarian troops.<ref name=""auto4""/> For his triumphs Bem was awarded the First Class of the Hungarian Military Order of Merit and the rank of Lieutenant General.<ref name=""auto4""/>

column1: The success was undoubtedly impressive, since Bem had achieved it while the opposing Austrian and Russian troops were outnumbering his troops.<ref name=""auto4""/> It is true, that the imperials could only count on the Russians in defensive battles, but Bem didn’t known this.<ref name=""auto4""/> With his lightning-quick moves he divided and [[Defeat in detail
column2: defeated in detail]] the troops of Puchner, then Kalliány, and after his defeat at Medgyes, he completely turned the tide of the war in less than two weeks.<ref name=""auto4""/> At the same time, the imperial command completely lost its head, and although the troops fought with the tenacity expected of them, they could only ameliorate the disastrous consequences of the commanders' precipitated and contradictory decisions.<ref name=""auto4""/>

column1: The '''Carron Bridge''' is a bridge over the River Carron near [[Ardgay]] in [[Sutherland]], Scotland.
The Carron Bridge is located near the town of Ardgay in Sutherland, Scotland.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=LB71674 - Carron Bridge over River Carron}}</ref>. It is a single span bridge of traditional stone construction. Notable are the placque on the east side outer wall, a cattle and walker tunnel on the bridge south side, nine distinctive metal repair stays, and the unusual supported footpath that runs around the base of the bridge on the north side.

column1: The bridge was constructed in 1818. A placque in the outer wall at the middle of the bridge on the east side has a faint inscription which reads ""This bridge was erected by the Second District of Roads Ross-Shire 1818 Alex (illegible)"".
73697001,Richard_W._Pfeiffer,"'''Richard William Pfeiffer''' was an American LGBT rights activist.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Richard Pfeiffer, Coordinator For Chicago Pride Parade For Decades, Dies
column6: title=Chicago Pride Parade Organizer Richard Pfeiffer Dead At 70

column1: During his career, Pfeiffer coordinated [[Chicago Pride Parade]] from 1974 onwards and was part of the [[Chicago LGBT Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=‘He was a giant’: Chicago gay rights pioneer Richard Pfeiffer ran the city’s iconic Pride Parade for more than 40 years – Chicago Tribune
column6: title=Richard Pfeiffer, longtime Chicago Pride Parade coordinator, has died at 70

column1: Pfeiffer's contributions included serving on the mayor's Advisory Council on [[gay]] and [[lesbian]] issues between 1985 and 1994 under three successive mayors.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Richard Pfeiffer, coordinator of Chicago Pride Parade since 1974, dies at 70
column4: website=ABC7 Chicago}}</ref> As a student, he established Chicago city college's inaugural gay student organization, volunteered at Horizons Community Services (now [[Center on Halsted]]), and presided over the organization in the mid-1970s.<ref name=""auto"">https://www.npr.org/local/309/2019/10/08/768061386/chicago-pride-parade-organizer-richard-pfeiffer-dies-at-70</ref>

column1: Additionally, Pfeiffer founded the Gay Speaker's Bureau, which facilitated discussions on LGBTQ+ topics in educational and religious institutions, with Pfeiffer delivering up to six lectures per week at the organization's peak.<ref name=""auto""/>
[[Category:Inductees of the Chicago LGBT Hall of Fame]]

column1: '''Joseph Ellison Adger Smyth''', known as '''E. A. Smyth''' (October 26, 1847 – August 3, 1942) was an American industrialist.
He was the son of [[Thomas Smyth (minister)
column2: Thomas Smyth]], minister of [[Second Presbyterian Church (Charleston, South Carolina)
column3: Second Presbyterian Church]] in [[Charleston, South Carolina]]. His older brother, [[James Adger Smyth]], later became [[List of mayors of Charleston, South Carolina

column1: Smyth attended [[The Citadel]] until 1864, when he joined the [[Confederate Army]] in the [[American Civil War
column2: Civil War]]. His gallant service in the [[Battle of Honey Hill]] earned him a promotion to [[sergeant]]. After the war he became a Captain in the Washington Artillery Rifle Club, and used that title for the rest of his life.<ref>{{cite news

column1: He started as a junior clerk in the hardware firm his grandfather, [[James Adger]], had established, but later decided to enter the textile industry. He joined forces with Francis J. Pelzer and served as president of the [[Pelzer Manufacturing Company]] in what is now [[Pelzer, South Carolina]] from 1880 to 1923. He was also president of Belton Mills from 1899 to 1920, and owned a controlling interest in ''[[The Greenville News]]'' from 1912 to 1923.<ref name=SCE>{{cite web
[[File:Carl Sandburg house, Flat Rock, NC IMG 4847.JPG
In 1900, Smyth purchased a house in [[Flat Rock, Henderson County, North Carolina
column2: Flat Rock, North Carolina]]. He changed the name from ""Rock Hill"" to ""[[Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
column3: Connemara]]"". He owned it for the rest of his life, and in 1945 it was purchased by [[Carl Sandburg]].

column5: title=Rebel Racing – красивая гоночная игра в Google Play и AppStore

column1: On the platform [[Games@Mail.ru]] the critic rated the game 6.5 out of 10, noting that the tracks in the game are very short – ""Three turns, some kind of springboard, a place where the road surface changes – that's all. Thirty to forty seconds per race is probably the fastest race we've seen. And do not expect that there will be a lot of short tracks – if the authors of the [[Asphalt 9: Legends
column2: Asphalt 9]] spent a lot of time working out different locations, in Rebel Racing the global map was simply divided into regions, in each of which you ride literally four or five repeating tracks. Yes, the complexity of the races is growing, sometimes you have to chase bosses, there are temporary events (in them, by the way, you can try out a car with a higher class) — and that's it. As a result, Rebel Racing quickly turns into a monotonous earning money in order to sometimes see something new. We passed all the races in a circle, improved the car, tried our hand at competing with the boss. It didn't work out — we repeat the procedure described above. A separate holiday comes when you manage to save up for a new car or move to another location.""<ref name="":0"" />

column1: The '''Malamekkara Mulluthara Devi Temple''' is a [[Hindu temple]] located in Malamekkara, [[Pathanamthitta]] district, [[Kerala]], India.<ref name=""manorama-1"">{{Cite web
column8: title=മലമേക്കര മുളളുതറ ദേവീ ക്ഷേത്രത്തിലെ അത്തം മഹോത്സവം
column11: language=ml}}</ref> Throughout history, the temple has been used as a training center for [[Kalari]] and has been home to [[Kaniyar
column12: Kaniyars]] who taught [[Ezhuthu Kalari]], [[Ayurveda]], and [[Astrology]].<ref name=""manorama-1"" /> The main ritual of the temple is [[Kuthiyottam]], a dance form created to commemorate the triumph of the goddess [[Parashakti]] over the demon [[Mahishasura]].<ref name=""manorama-1"" /> The dancers are considered to be the injured soldiers of the goddess. One of the most renowned festivals held at the temple is Jeevitha Ezhunnullippu and Appindi Vilakku, which takes place in the month of [[Kumbha (month)
column13: Kumbha]] (late February to early March).<ref name=""keralakaumudi-2"">{{Cite web
column15: title=ഉദ്ദിഷ്ടകാര്യ സിദ്ധിയ്ക്ക് തൊഴാം മുള്ളുതറയിൽ ശ്രീ ഭദ്രാ കരിംകാളിയമ്മയെ

'''Mustafa Hamarat''' (born 21 July 1972, in [[Akkuş]], [[Ordu]]) is a Lawyer and Turkish politician. He is the deputy secretary general of the [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)]] and AK Party's Ordu candidate for parliament for the 2023 general elections in [[Turkiye]].<ref name=""archive"">{{cite web
column8: work=www.tbmm.gov.tr}}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --></ref><ref name=""autogenerated2"">{{Cite web

column1: Mustafa graduated from [[Ankara University Faculty of Law]], completed his master's degree at [[Kırıkkale University]], Institute of Social Sciences,
Mustafa Hamarat started to work as a  freelance lawyer in Kırıkkale University and was appointed to the [[Istanbul Metropolitan Municipality]] as a corporate lawyer.<ref name=""archive""/>
In 2002, he was nominated as a parliamentary candidate from the [[AK Party]] for Ordu. In
2003, he took office in the Ak Party Istanbul Provincial Administration.<ref name=""autogenerated2""/> He was also the Candidate for mayor of [[Ümraniye]] in 2004 local elections.

He was elected twice as Ordu's representative from Justice and Development Party in 2007 and 2011 Turkey general elections to become a member of the 23rd and 24th [[Grand National Assembly of Turkey]].<ref name=""archive""/><ref name=""gunesgazetesi""/>
In 2017, [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] chose Mustafa Hamarat as the Deputy Secretary General of the Justice and Development Party (AK Party).<ref name=""gunesgazetesi"">{{Cite web
Mustafa Hamarat speaks English, German and Arabic at an intermediate level, He is married and has 5 children.<ref name=""archive""/>

column1: 73697351,List_of_burials_in_the_Valley_of_the_Queens,"The following is a '''list of burials in the [[Valley of the Queens]]''', in [[Thebes, Egypt
[[Image:Valley of the Queens by the Survey of Egypt.jpg

column2: QV1 was originally designated as a Pharaonic tomb, but since been interpreted to be a Coptic hermit shelter.
Nothing remains of QV2 other than a shallow pit which was reburied in 2009 with debris.
QV3 is described as an undecorated shaft tomb which was last cleared from 1984 to 1985.
QV4 consists of a shaft entrance with two chambers that were reburied in 2010.
QV5 consists of a shallow pit leading to a single large chamber that is partly filled with debris.
QV6 is similar to QV5, a recent assessment has not been made as the tomb is largely filled with debris.
QV7 has 3 chambers, the excavation of chamber C was possibly started at a later stage. Flooding continues to be a serious threat to this particular site due to its vulnerable location.

column4: There is also an unnamed King's daughter interred in QV8 along with a person named [[Amenwesekhet]]. QV8 was also reused in the Late Period (25th-26th Dynasties.}}

column2: QV9 is a undecorated shaft tomb constructed during the reign of [[Thutmes I]]. This tomb may have been used by a member of the military as an arrow head and decorated leather fragment that may have been part of a quiver was found.
Finds in this tomb included a ""mirror handle, part of a staff covered in pink leather, and glazed blue Faiencehair beads"". It was also reused in the [[Third Intermediate Period of Egypt
column4: Roman Periods]]. Avian mummies placed in Roman period vases were also discovered in the tomb.

column2: Artifacts recovered from this tomb indicate that it was reused ""extensively"" in the Third Intermediate, Late, and Roman Periods. These finds included Third Intermediate Period sarcophagi, and burial equipment attributed to a 25th Dynasty individual named [[Pariyah]].

Artifacts recovered from this tomb indicate an original owner of an elevated rank. Finds include fragments of three arrows, a golden tip of a scepter, and Sarcophagus fragments inscribed with the name of [[Thutmes II]]. This tomb was also reused in the Third Intermediate and Roman Periods.
This tomb contained 18th Dynasty sarcophagus fragments, pottery, and glazed wig ornaments. This tomb was also reused in the Third Intermediate and Roman Periods based on additional finds.
Not much is known about this tomb other than an 18th dynasty age, it was possibly reused in the Third Intermediate and Roman Periods.
Not much is known about this tomb other than its age, and it's connection to QV16 by a long passage.
Not much is known about this tomb other than its age, and it's connection to QV15 by a long passage.
This tomb may have been constructed during the reign of [[Amenhotep III]], and reused during the Third Intermediate Period.
QV19 has a single shaft leading to a large chamber which is dated to the 18th dynasty.
This has been described as the ""largest"" 18th dynasty shaft tomb, with a probable royal association.
Recovered artifacts indicate that this tomb was reused during the Third Intermediate, Roman, and Coptic periods
Recovered artifacts are similar to QV21, but just date to the Third Intermediate period.
This tomb was reused during the Third Intermediate period.

column3: TMP]] that the location of QV25 was forgotten about until workers constructing QV24 ran into it.

column2: Not much is known about this tomb other than its 18th dynasty age.
Not much is known about this tomb other than its 18th dynasty age.
This 18th dynasty tomb collapsed in antiquity and has been described as ""unstable"".

'''Elena de Laudo''' (''fl.'' 1445), was a Venetian [[glass]] artist.

She belonged to a glass painter family of Murano, and are noted to have painted blanks delivered to her from the workshop of [[Salvatore Barovier]] in 1443-1445.Of fourteen specialist glass painters (''pictori'') documented between 1443 and 1516, she and [[Marietta Barovier]] were the only women.<ref>{{Cite book

column1: The '''1923 St. John's Red and White football team''' was an [[American football]] team that represented [[St. John's University (New York City)
column2: St. John's College]] of [[New York City]] as a member of the [[Metropolitan Conference (1923–1931)
column3: Metropolitan Conference]] during the [[1923 college football season]]. The team compiled a 5–0–1 record and outscored opponents by a total of 111 to 32.<ref>{{cite web
column7: url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906040945/http://www.cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/discontinued/s/saint_johns_ny/yearly_results.php?year=1920}}</ref>  The 1923 season marked a return to intercollegiate football for St. John's after an absence of 16 years.<ref name=Lapse/>

column1: Ray Lynch was the head coach, and Lieutenant J. V. Domminey of West Point was assistant coach. The team was assembled on September 6 and trained for the following month before the first game on October 6.<ref>{{cite news
