column1: 73697508,Schultz_&_Larsen_Legacy,"'''Schultz & Larsen Legacy''' is a [[bolt action]] rifle manufactured by [[Schultz & Larsen]] in Denmark. The [[Receiver (firearms)
column2: receiver]] is blued, and has integrated mounts for Schultz & Larsen's own ""Slide & Lock"" [[Scope mount
column3: sight mounting]] system. The receiver is also drilled and tapped for installation of other [[Scope mount
column4: scope mount bases]] (with 22 mm distance between the screw holes and a 15 mm radius on the receiver bridge<ref>{{Cite web

column2: title=Shultz and Larsen Legacy {{!}} Bolt Action Rifle Reviews
column5: language=en}}</ref> with 0, 3 or 6 [[milliradian]] tilt. The trigger is adjustable,<ref>{{Cite web
column7: title=Schultz & Larsen Legacy .223 rifle on review by expert Bruce Potts
column10: language=en-US}}</ref> has a 3-position safety selector, and can be emptied with the safety on. The Legacy is delivered from the factory chambered for [[.222 Remington
column18: access-date=2023-05-01}}</ref> The barrel has cut rifling, and can be swapped using a [[hex key]]. The barrels are not interchangeable with other Schultz & Larsen rifle models such as the [[Schultz & Larsen Classic
column20: Victory]]. The Legacy was originally launched as a right-hand model only.

column2: occupation         = Matchmaker, relationship coach, author, and podcaster
matchmaker]], relationship coach, author, public speaker, and podcaster. She is prominently featured in the [[Netflix]] series Jewish Matchmaking,<ref>{{Citation
column6: language=en-US}}</ref> which follows her attempts at helping Jewish singles in the [[United States]] and [[Israel]] find [[love]] and get married.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Jewish Matchmaking: Get a First Look at Your New Netflix Obsession

column1: In 2012, Ben Shalom founded ''Marriage Minded Mentor'', a global service that provides matchmaking, dating coaching, matchmaker training, dating courses online and pairs Jewish singles with [[Relationship coaching
column2: relationship coaches]] to help them circumvent the hurdles of modern [[dating]].<ref>{{Cite web
column7: website=LinkedIn}}</ref> The company recently began their ''Mentors Academy'' service, which provides training for matchmakers and relationship coaches.<ref>{{Cite web
column12: language=en-US}}</ref> In 2022, the company expanded their services by partnering with JMatchmaking, the Jewish dating service founded by [[Montreal]]-based rabbi, [[Yisroel Bernath]].<ref>{{Cite web
column17: language=en-US}}</ref>  Over the years, Ben Shalom has successfully paired over 200 Jewish singles get married.<ref>{{Cite web
column20: title=Who Is Aleeza Ben Shalom dating coach on Jewish Matchmaking, bio, Instagram and Twitter

column1: On March 30, 2023, [[Netflix]] announced that, on May 3rd of that year, they would be releasing ''Jewish Matchmaking'' which follows Ben Shalom in her role as matchmaker, meeting Jewish singles in both the United States and Israel to help them find a [[Significant other
column5: title=Be a Mensch and Tune into ‘Jewish Matchmaking’ This May
column9: language=en}}</ref> The show forms part of the Netflix Matchmaking Universe and was produced by the creators of their hit series ''[[Indian Matchmaking]]''.<ref>{{Cite web
column12: title=Netflix Announces Jewish Matchmaking Spinoff After Success of Indian Matchmaking Series

column1: In 2013, Ben Shalom published ''Get Real Get Married'', which focuses on helping singles find their [[soulmate]] through intense [[self-reflection]] and assessment of values.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Aleeza Ben Shalom Books {{!}} List of books by author Aleeza Ben Shalom
column7: language=en}}</ref>  In 2020, she published ''Virtual Dating: Your Guide to a Relationship in a Socially Distanced World'', which grappled with the challenges that singles were facing during the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] in their journey to find love.<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=Books by Aleeza Ben Shalom (Author of Get Real Get Married)

column1: In December 2022, Ben Shalom began a weekly [[podcast]] “Matchmaker, Matchmaker” with Rabbi [[Yisroel Bernath]], where they discuss dating, love, and matchmaking.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: language=en-US}}</ref> She started another podcast in March 2023, called The Yentas, which she co-hosts with fellow [[Shadchan
column7: matchmakers]] Michal Naisteter and Danielle Selber, answering listener questions about dating.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: In 2017, she was featured on season 1, episode 5 of the American Jewish comedy series, ''[[Soon By You]]''.<ref>{{Cite web
She is a featured columnist for [[Aish HaTorah
column3: title=Aleeza Ben Shalom - Author at Aish.com
column7: language=en-US}}</ref>  and has published articles in both the [[HuffPost]] and [[The Times of Israel]]. She has also been featured on [[NPR]] and [[BBC World News]].

column2: title=Jewish Matchmaking Host Aleeza Ben Shalom Interview

column10: title=The challenges of marriage and dating through COVID

column2: Pardes-Hanna]], [[Israel]], with her husband, five children, and family dog, Koda the Kelev.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: The '''Fight League Atlantic''' (FLA) is an Canadian [[mixed martial arts]] (MMA) [[Promoter (entertainment)
column2: promotion company]] based in [[Nova Scotia]]. It was founded in 2022 and is owned by Derek Clarke, most known for operating many grappling circuits across Canada, and being a Black Belt in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu, and Jon Foster who is also a Black Belt in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu and runs the longest running Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu tournament as in the Abhaya Open and both men are experienced businessmen.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: '''Spalangiidae''' is a family of chalcid wasps that are parasitoids of flies. The two subfamilies (Spalangiinae and Erotolepsiinae) were moved from the family [[Pteromalidae]] to creae this family in 2022.<ref name=BurksEtAl>{{Cite Q
column2: Q115923766}}</ref> They are now known to be more closely related to the [[Planidium
column4: chalcid wasps]] than to the core [[Pteromalidae]].<ref name=Cruaud2022>Cruaud A, Rasplus J-Y, Zhang J, Burks R, Delvare G, Fusu L, Gibson GAP, Gumovsky A,

column1: Hanson P, Huber JT, Janšta P, Mitroiu M-D, Noyes JS, van Noort S, Baker A, Böhmová J, Baur H, Blaimer BB, Brady SG, Bubeníková K, Chartois M, Copeland RS, Dale-Skey Papilloud N, Dal Molin A, Darling C, Dominguez C, Fisher N, Gates MW, Gebiola M, Guerrieri E, Haas M, Hansson C, Heydon S, Kresslein RL, Krogmann L, Moriarty Lemmon E, Mottern J, Murray E, Nidelet S, Nieves Aldrey JL, Perry R, Peters RS, Pinto JD, Polaszek A, Sauné L, Schmidt S, Torréns J, Triapitsyn S, Tselikh EV, Ubaidillah R, Yoder M, Lemmon A, Woolley JB, Heraty JM (2022). The Chalcidoidea bush of life–a massive radiation blurred by mutational saturation. bioRxiv, 2022-09. [https://doi.org/10.1101/2022.09.11.507458 DOI] [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/363520242 PDF]</ref>

column4: toruli]] (bases) are placed very low on the head in most species; mandibles usually with 2 or 3 teeth; all legs with 5 [[Arthropod leg
column5: tarsomeres]]; protibial spur stout and curved. ''Eunotopsia'' differs from the other genera in having 11 flagellomeres including 3 clavomeres, toruli placed higher on the head, and having undivided mandibles. In the Spalangiinae the toruli are placed on lobes that overhang the clypeus and labrum. This distinctive antennal placement and the prognathous head (i.e. the head is held with the mouthparts projecting forwards) make it easy to place members of Spalangiinae.<ref name=BurksEtAl/>

column1: A 26-player roster was announced on 30 April.<ref>{{Cite web

'''''Spring''''' is a live album of duets by pianist [[Irène Schweizer]] and saxophonist Jürg Wickihalder. It was recorded on February 6 and 7, 2014, at Loft Köln in Köln, Germany, and was released later that year by [[Intakt Records]]. The album features two compositions by [[Thelonious Monk]], one by Schweizer, five by Wickihalder, three free improvisations, and, as a closer, [[Leonello Casucci]]'s ""[[Just a Gigolo (song)

column6: title=Irene Schweizer and Jurg Wickihalder: Spring

column1: In a review for ''[[All About Jazz]]'', John Sharpe wrote: ""the overwhelming impression is of two sympathetic partners having a ball... Schweizer lays down a playful rhythmic framework calling on older tropes such as ragtime and barrelhouse at times, which lends a cartoon air to proceedings. Wickihalder matches her every inch of the way, deploying a wide range of expressive tonal effects, but fully integrated into the flow rather than as technique for its own sake.""<ref name=""aaj"" />

Marcus O'Dair of ''[[Jazzwise]]'' called the album ""superb,"" and stated: ""The sense is of musicians with nothing to prove... working together to create bracing and beautiful chamber jazz.""<ref name=""jw"" />
''Point of Departure'''s Michael Rosenstein described the album as ""a strong one all around,"" noting the influence of both Monk and [[Steve Lacy (saxophonist)
column2: Steve Lacy]] on the music, and commenting: ""this duo provides the ultimate homage by drawing on Lacy and Monk's vocabulary to create a personal sound all their own.""<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Moment's Notice: Reviews of Recent Recordings

column2: Cadence]]'', Bernie Koenig noted that ""the interplay between the two is excellent,"" and stated that Schweizer's playing is ""two handed but melodic, and she is always harmonically inventive.""<ref>{{cite magazine

column1: * Jürg Wickihalder – tenor saxophone, soprano saxophone

column3: A Theory of ISIS book cover 2018]]

column1: ''A Theory of ISIS'' is a 2017 book by political historian [[Mohamed Mahmoud Ould Mohamedou]] which argues that the [[Islamic State]] constituted an original and hybrid form of political violence that merged post-colonialism, post-modernity, and post-globalisation thus impacting domestic, regional, and global politics and security.<ref>Chakravortty, Dipanwita (19 March 2020). ""Mohammad-Mahmoud Ould Mohamedou (2018). ''A Theory of ISIS: Political Violence and the Transformation of the Global Order''"" (https://dx.doi.org/10.1177/2347798919889789). ''[[Contemporary Review of the Middle East]]''. '''7''' (1): 119–121. [[Doi (identifier)
column5: via SAGE journals.]]</ref> It is the first scholarly attempt at conceptualizing and historicizing the [[Islamic State]] armed group.<ref>{{Cite journal
column9: title=A Theory of ISIS: Political Violence and the Transformation of the Global Order, Mohammad-Mahmoud Ould Mohamedou, 2018, Londres, Pluto Press, 260 p.
column17: issn=0014-2123}}</ref> It was published in hardback and paperback in the United Kingdom by Pluto Press in October 2017, and in the United States by the University of Chicago Press in February 2018, in hardback and paperback.

column1: Highlighting the importance of periodization and spatialization in writing histories of political violence, the book argues that a layered “conceptual geology of IS” holds the key to its understanding, and is to be found in three different but related dimensions: first, a continuation of the earlier armed radical Islamist group [[Al-Qaeda
column2: Al Qaeda]] and that group’s regional context; second, degenerated political developments in Iraq in the aftermath of the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]] by the US and the [[Syrian civil war]] after 2011; and, third, the wider rise of a novel type of political violence linked to resurgent practices of the colonial era and military interventionism. The book concludes that the latter dimension constitutes the most important legacy of the group, and that such post-modern violence is more anchored in the Western metropolis than in the battlefields of [[Afghanistan]], [[Iraq]], and [[Syria]].<ref>{{Cite journal
column6: title=A Theory of ISIS: Political Violence and The Transformation of the Global Order
column13: issn=2156-7689}}</ref><ref>1.  Koussa, Maryanne (28 December 2020). ""Post-Colonial Era that Failed the Middle East"" (http://www.sirjournal.org/book-reviews/2020/12/28/post-colonial-era-that-failed-the-middle-east). ''Sigma Iota Rho Journal of International Relations''. Archived (https://web.archive.org/web/2 0230417101520/http://www.sirjournal.org/book-reviews/2020/12/28/post-colonial-era-that-fai led-the-middle-east) from the original on 28 December 2020. Retrieved 17 April 2023.</ref>

column1: The book is part of a trilogy by Mohamedou on the geopolitical implications of the [[September 11 attacks
column2: September 11]], 2001 terrorist attacks, examining the events and their aftermath on international relations and transnational forms of political violence. The first volume, ''Contre-Croisade – Le 11 Septembre et le Retournement du Monde'' was published by L’Harmattan (Paris) in 2004 (under the title ''Contre-Croisade – Origines et Conséquences du 11 Septembre'') with an expanded edition in 2011.The second volume, ''Understanding Al Qaeda – The Transformation of War'' was published in 2007 by Pluto Press in the United Kingdom and the University of Michigan Press in the United States, with an expanded edition in 2011 under the title ''Understanding Al Qaeda – Changing War and Global Politics''.

column1: The book examines the place the [[Islamic State]] occupies in contemporary international history and politics. It critiques the dominant existing literature on the group, and more generally on radical Islamism as lacking historical contextualization and historical conceptualization – specifically focus on the religiosity of the armed group, which Mohamedou calls “ornamental and theatrical”.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=A Theory of ISIS with Mohammad-Mahmoud Ould Mohamedou
column9: language=en-us}}</ref> In that regard, the book stands in contrast to works on the [[Islamic State]] and on [[Al-Qaeda]] by authors such as [[Gilles Kepel]], [[Lawrence Wright]], and [[Fawaz Gerges]], sharing more ground with the analyses of [[Mahmood Mamdani]], [[Faisal Devji]] and [[François Burgat]].

column1: Available through Open Access<ref>Mohamedou, Mohammad-Mahmoud Ould (2018). ''A Theory of ISIS: Political Violence and the Transformation of the Global Order'' (https://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt1x07z89). Pluto Press. [[ISBN (identifier)

column1: <!-- Note: The following pages were redirects to [[Fractured_(Mini-series)]] before draftification:
'''Fractured''' is an upcoming mini-series produced by [[Dreamscape Entertainment]] together with KreativDen and set to premiere in [[iWantTFC]].<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Francine Diaz, Seth Fedelin, Jennica Garcia cast in upcoming ABS-CBN series ‘Fractured’
column9: title=Francine Diaz, Seth Fedelin to star in a new project 'Fractured'

column1: During the story conference, director Thop Nazareno explained that it's a reflection of a society wherein people are very image-conscious and exposed to social media, and what truly matters in the absence of it.
While sir Deo Endrinal left a statement that makes everyone ponder, ""They are coming to an island broken, are they going to stay fractured or will they come out alive and healed?""<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=They are coming to an island broken, are they going to stay fractured or...

column2: Other cast were revealed through Ethel Espiritu's Instagram posts and stories.

column1: A story conference took place on March 15, 2023 in which the cast were also announced. It was attended by, from [[Dreamscape Entertainment]], head - Deo Endrinal, Head of Creatives - Rondel Lindayag and Business Unit Head - Erick Salud, from [[ABS-CBN]], head of TV Production and [[Star Magic]] - Lauren Dyogi, and head of [[Rise Artists Studio]] - Mico Del Rosario, and from KreativDen - Ethel Espiritu. Director Thop Nazareno and writers, John Bedia and Lawrence Nicodemus were also introduced in the said event.
In April 17, 2023, Director Thop and the cast held a script reading. The following day initial photography was shot in Batangas.
Around third week to end of April 2023 the cast and crew went on lock-in taping in Zambales as shown in the cast, directors and producers' Instagram stories and posts.

column2: children           = Carla Wallenda Guzman, Jenny Wallenda Anderson, Mario Wallenda

column1: '''Helen Kreis Wallenda''' (December 11, 1910 – May 9, 1996) was a German-born [[trapeze]] artist and [[aerialist]], best known as a key member of the original four-member [[The Flying Wallendas
column2: Great Wallendas]] high-wire troupe.<ref name="":0"">{{Cite web
column8: doi=10.1093/anb/9780198606697.article.1803575}}</ref> She was the wife of the high-wire artist, [[Karl Wallenda]], and together they performed daring acts without a [[safety net]]. Kreis was often the pinnacle of the Wallenda pyramid.<ref name="":1"">{{Cite web
column9: title=Helen Kreis Wallenda,85, the last member of... – Baltimore Sun
column16: title=Helen Wallenda, 85, the Last Of the Original High-Wire Team

column1: Kreis was born on December 11, 1910, in [[Germany]].<ref name="":4"">{{Cite web
column5: website=www.encyclopedia.com}}</ref> She joined the Wallenda troupe, led by her future husband, Karl Wallenda, at the age of 16. In 1928, she made her debut as the pinnacle of the Wallenda pyramid during a performance at [[Madison Square Garden]], which earned the troupe a standing ovation that lasted for 11 minutes.<ref name="":0"" />

column1: The Wallendas traced their high-wire heritage back to the 1600s and were known for performing high-wire acts between [[Skyscraper
column2: skyscrapers]], over canyons, and between speeding cars. Kreis and Wallenda married in 1935 and continued to perform together, along with other members of the Wallenda family.<ref name="":3"" />

column1: Kreis retired from performing in 1956.<ref name="":4"" /> In 1962, an accident occurred when a seven-member Wallenda pyramid collapsed in [[Detroit]], resulting in the deaths of two troupe members and the paralysis of her son, [[Mario Wallenda
column2: Mario]]. In 1964, her sister Rietta Grotefent also died in a fall from the high wire.<ref name="":1"" />

column1: Kreis continued to support her family and its high-wire legacy, even assisting her son-in-law, Mike Morgan, in learning the wire act at the age of 72. She lived in [[Sarasota, Florida]], with her family, caring for her grandchildren while the rest of the family was on tour.<ref>{{Cite web

Kreis passed away on May 9, 1996, in Sarasota, Florida, at the age of 85. She is survived by her three children, Carla Wallenda Guzman, Jenny Wallenda Anderson, and Mario Wallenda, as well as several grandchildren and great-grandchildren.<ref name="":2"" />

column3: IWGP Junior Heavyweight Tag Team Champion]] with [[Kushida (wrestler)

column3: title=Matches « Kevin Knight « Wrestlers Database « Cagematch - The Internet Wrestling Database

column2: New Japan Pro-Wrestling LA Dojo]] in 2020 as a [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#young boy
column3: Young Lion]], training under [[Katsuyori Shibata]]. Knight made his NJPW debut on December 12 at [[Super J-Cup (2020)
column4: Super J-Cup]], replacing an injured [[Karl Fredericks]], where he teamed with [[Ren Narita]], losing to [[Bullet Club

column13: title=2020.12.12 Super J-Cup 2020 (11/7発表) {{pipe}} New Japan Pro-Wrestling

column1: In 2021, Knight competed on NJPW's American-based show ''[[NJPW Strong
column2: Strong]]'', commonly teaming with fellow LA Dojo members, such as Karl Fredericks, [[Clark Connors]] and [[Alex Coughlin]], often losing most of his matches, which is common for NJPW Young Lions. In July, Knight entered the Tag Team Turbulence tournament, teaming with The DKC, however, they were defeated in the first round by [[Team Filthy
column3: The West Coast Wrecking Crew]].<ref name=""f4wonline"">{{cite web
column7: access-date=2023-05-01}}</ref> Knight continued to wrestle on ''Strong'' for the remainder of the year. In May 2022, Knight made his debut for [[All Elite Wrestling]] (AEW), teaming with The DKC, in a losing effort to [[Q. T. Marshall#The Factory (2021–2022)
column8: The Factory's]] [[Aaron Solo]] and [[Nick Comoroto]], after the match The Factory attempted to attack the duo, however, they were saved by their LA Dojo stablemates. This led to a match the following week, where NJPW's Knight, Connors, Fredericks, Coughlin and [[Yuya Uemura]], defeated The Factory's [[Q. T. Marshall]], Solo, Comoroto, Blake Li and Brick Aldridge, in a ten-man tag-team match.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=NJPW LA Dojo Members & More AEW Debuts Announced
column12: Capital Collision]], Knight was defeated by Comoroto in a dark-match.<ref name=""njpw1972c"">{{cite web

column16: access-date=2023-05-01}}</ref> In June, Knight competed at [[Forbidden Door (2022)

column19: Austin]] and [[Colten Gunn]]) and [[Max Caster]].<ref name=""prowrestling"">{{cite web
column21: title=AEW-NJPW Forbidden Door Buy-In pre-show results: Swerve Strickland and Keith Lee vs. Yoshinobu Kanemaru and El Desperado, Max Caster, Austin Gunn, Colten Gunn, and Billy Gunn vs. The DKC, Kevin Knight, Alex Coughlin, and Yuya Uemura, and Hirooki Goto and Yoshi-Hashi vs. QT Marshall and Aaron Solo - Pro Wrestling Dot Net

column24: The Night Before Rumble on 44th Street]], Knight and The DKC, defeated [[Forever Hooligans]] ([[Rocky Romero]] and [[Alex Koslov]]), who had reunited for one-night only.<ref name=""njpw1972d"">{{cite web
column26: title=2022.10.27 Night before {{pipe}} New Japan Pro-Wrestling
column28: access-date=2023-05-01}}</ref> The following night at [[Rumble on 44th Street]], Knight and The DKC teamed once more, losing to [[The Motor City Machine Guns]] and [[Aussie Open (professional wrestling)
column29: Aussie Open]] in a three-way tag-team match for the [[Strong Openweight Tag Team Championship]], which The Motor City Machine Guns won.<ref name=""wrestlingheadlines"">{{cite web

column1: On November 20, Knight made his debut in Japan for NJPW, at [[Historic X-Over]], teaming with Connors, Coughlin and Gabriel Kidd on the pre-show, to defeat Kosei Fujita, Oskar Leube, Ryohei Oiwa, and Yuto Nakashima.<ref name=""njpw1972e"">{{cite web
column3: title=2022.11.20 Historic X-over {{pipe}} New Japan Pro-Wrestling

column6: Super Junior Tag League]], teaming with [[Kushida (wrestler)

column9: title=NJPW Announces Lineup For Super Junior Tag League 2022 {{pipe}} Fightful News
column11: access-date=2023-05-01}}</ref> During the tournament, Knight dropped the traditional black trunks worn by NJPW Young Lions, instead wearing bright orange gear and sunglasses, in order to better match his partner Kushida, whilst also signaling his graduation as a Young Lion. The duo ended the tournament with 4 points, failing to advance to the finals.<ref name=""f4wonline2"">{{cite web

column1: Following the tournament, Knight and Kushida continued to team together, with Knight debuting for [[Impact Wrestling]], teaming with Kushida to defeat The Good Hands (Jason Hotch and John Skyler).<ref name=""njpw1972f"">{{cite web
column3: title=KUSHIDA and Kevin Knight make major IMPACT against Good Hands {{pipe}} New Japan Pro-Wrestling
column5: access-date=2023-05-01}}</ref> The following week, the duo lost to Bullet Club's [[Chris Bey]] and [[Ace Austin]]. On February 25, Knight lost to [[Kenny King]].<ref name=""wrestlingheadlines2"">{{cite web
column8: title=SPOILERS: Results From Saturday’s Impact Wrestling Tapings 2/25/23
column9: access-date=2023-05-01}}</ref> On March 30, at [[Multiverse United]], a co-produced show between Impact and NJPW, Knight competed in a Six-way [[Scramble match]] for the [[Impact X Division Championship]], but the title was retained by champion [[Trey Miguel]].<ref name=""impactwrestling"">{{cite web
column11: title=Multiverse United: Only the STRONG Survive 2023 Full Results
column13: access-date=2023-05-01}}</ref> In April, Knight and Kushida began teaming under the name '''Jet Setters'''. On April 27, Knight and Kushida won the [[IWGP Junior Heavyweight Tag Team Championship]]s, from [[United Empire
column14: Catch 2/2]] ([[T. J. Perkins]] and [[Francesco Akira]]), marking Knight's first NJPW championship.<ref name=""f4wonline3"">{{cite web

previous = [[2019 FIBA Basketball World Cup final

column1: The '''2023 FIBA Basketball World Cup Final''' will be the concluding [[basketball]] game which determines the winner of the [[2023 FIBA Basketball World Cup]]. The game will be played on 10 September 2023, at the [[SM Mall of Asia Arena
column2: Mall of Asia Arena]], in [[Pasay]], [[Metro Manila]], Philippines.<ref name=""venuechange"">{{cite web
column4: title=FIBA Statement on venue change at the FIBA Basketball World Cup 2023

column1: The [[Naismith Trophy]] will be awarded to the winning team for the second time since the adoption of its new version in 2017.<ref>[http://www.fiba.com/basketballworldcup/2023/trophy 2023 FIBA Basketball World Cup trophy], FIBA.basketball</ref>

The final will be played at the [[Mall of Asia Arena]] in [[Pasay]], a city within [[Metro Manila]], Philippines. The arena is one of the five proposed venues of the [[Philippine–Japanese–Indonesian bid for the 2023 FIBA Basketball World Cup
column2: joint Philippine–Japanese–Indonesian World Cup bid]], and was named the Final Phase venue on 28 April 2023.<ref name=""venuechange""/> It will host twelve group stage games, four second-round games, four 17–32 classification games, and all final phase games.

column1: The Mall of Asia Arena, owned by SM Lifestyle Entertainment, which is under [[SM Prime Holdings]], was built as part of the master plan for the [[SM Mall of Asia]] complex.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=The Arena elevates viewing to a new level
column8: date=14 April 2012}}</ref> The arena was designed by architecture firm [[Arquitectonica]],<ref>[http://www.malaya.com.ph/index.php/special-features/property/5688-all-eyes-on-the-arena All eyes on the Arena] {{webarchive
column10: date=10 June 2012 }}, Malaya, 7 June 2012</ref> and has a seating capacity of 15,000 but can host as much as 20,000 people in a full-house capacity.<ref>{{cite news
column13: title=Fast Facts: Mall of Asia Arena
column17: date=16 January 2015}}</ref> Construction began in 2010,<ref>{{cite web
column22: access-date=10 May 2019}}</ref> and had its topping-off ceremony in September 2011.<ref>{{cite news
column25: title=SM bares strategy for new arena
column29: date=14 October 2011}}</ref> It hosted its first basketball event, a [[2012 PBA Governors Cup]] semifinals game between the [[B-Meg Llamados]] and the [[Talk 'N Text Tropang Texters]], on 7 July 2012.

column1: The arena is one of the playing venues of the [[Philippine Basketball Association]] (PBA) and the country's major collegiate leagues ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association (Philippines)
column2: NCAA]], [[University Athletic Association of the Philippines
column3: UAAP]]). It has also hosted the [[2013 FIBA Asia Championship]], one of the [[2016 FIBA World Olympic Qualifying Tournaments for Men]], the [[Basketball at the 2019 Southeast Asian Games
column4: basketball]] tournament of the [[2019 Southeast Asian Games]], and several [[2019 FIBA Basketball World Cup qualification (Asia)
column5: 2019]] and [[2023 FIBA Basketball World Cup qualification (Asia)
column6: 2023 FIBA Basketball World Cup Asian Qualifiers]] games of the [[Philippines men's national basketball team

column4: The Philippine Arena was initially set to host the tournament's final phase.]]

column1: The joint bid initially called for the 55,000-seater [[Philippine Arena]] in [[Bocaue]], [[Bulacan]] to host the World Cup's Final Phase, from the quarter-finals to the World Cup Final. However, on 28 April 2023, FIBA announced during its Central Board meeting that the venue would be changed to the Mall of Asia Arena in Pasay, citing logistical and transport issues, which were experienced in various events at the arena, including various concerts and the [[2023 FIBA Basketball World Cup qualification (Asia)
column2: sixth and final window of the 2023 World Cup Asian Qualifiers]].<ref name=""venuechange""/><ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=FIBA Basketball World Cup 2023 final phase to be played at MOA Arena, Gilas to open campaign at Philippine Arena {{!}} SBP
column6: website=sbp.ph}}</ref> Instead, the Philippine Arena will now only host the first two games of [[2023 FIBA Basketball World Cup Group A
column7: Group A]]: Angola vs. Italy and Dominican Republic vs. Philippines.

column2: name          = Enemies of the Enlightenment: The French Counter-Enlightenment and the Making of Modernity

column1: '''''Enemies of the Enlightenment: The French Counter-Enlightenment and the Making of Modernity''''' is a book about the [[Counter-Enlightenment]], which challenged the ideas of the [[Age of Enlightenment
column2: Enlightenment]] at the end of the [[early modern period]]. It was written by the American historian [[Darrin McMahon]] and published by [[Oxford University Press]] in 2001. McMahon rejects interpretations of the Counter-Enlightenment as a merely reactive force, instead presenting it as in possession of its own revolutionary ideology that needs be studied on its own merits.<ref>{{cite journal
column6: title=Enemies of the Enlightenment: The French Counter‐Enlightenment and the Making of Modernity
column15: title=''Enemies of the Enlightenment: The French Counter-Enlightenment and the Making of Modernity''. By Darrin M. McMahon (New York: Oxford University Press, 2001. xii plus 262 pp.)
column22: title=Enemies of the Enlightenment: The French Counter-Enlightenment and the Making of Modernity

column1: Giovanni Querini is first attested in 1204 in Venice.{{sfn
column4: p=71}} In 1225, he was [[ducal councillor]], and in 1226 he took up service under the [[Latin Emperor]], [[Robert of Courtenay]], though not before taking an oath to not do so against Venetian interests.{{sfn
column7: p=71}} He was thus a natural choice to become Venetian [[Podestà of Constantinople]], likely after Emperor Robert died in January 1228.{{sfn
column10: pp=71–72}} His term of office was nevertheless brief, as he was replaced in spring 1229 by [[Romeo Querini]].{{sfn
column13: p=72}} He is finally attested as ducal councillor in Venice in 1231.{{sfn

column1: Hankin's debut novel, ''Happy and You Know It'' (Berkley, 2020), was positive received by ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'': ""Hankin manages to make overused subject matter feel fresh and vibrant. What starts out as a satire of privileged parenting quickly becomes something else entirely—a domestic thriller with twists and turns that are entirely unexpected and incredibly fun"".<ref name="":2"">{{Cite book

Hankin's second novel, ''A Special Place for Women'' (Berkley, 2021), was reviewed by ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' as being ""diverting if far-fetched"". ''Publishers'' also said, ""the narrative has a couple of nice twists, but the ending’s a bit of a stretch"".<ref name="":1"">{{Cite web

column1: * [[Shaukat Khanum Memorial Cancer Hospital and Research Centre]]
The '''Chess World Cup 2023''' is a 206-player single-elimination chess tournament that will take place in Baku, Azerbaijan, from 30 July to 24 August 2023.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: language=en}}</ref> It will be the 10th edition of the Chess World Cup. The top three finishers in the tournament will qualify for the [[Candidates Tournament 2024

column1: In parallel with this open tournament, a [[Women's Chess World Cup 2023
column2: women-only World Cup]] will be held.

column1: The tournament was an 8-round knockout event, with the top 50 seeds given a bye directly into the second round. The losers of the two semi-finals played a match for third place.
The top three finalists will qualify for the [[Candidates Tournament 2024]], which will be a tournament to decide the next challenger for the World Championship.
Each round will consist of classical time limit games on the first two days, plus tie-breaks on the third day if required. The time limits were as follows:
* Two classical time limit games: 90 minutes, plus a 30-minute increment on move 40, plus a 30-second increment per move from move 1, per player.
* If the match is tied after the classical games, players will play two [[rapid chess]] games, with 25 minutes plus a 10-second increment per move, per player.
* If the match is still tied, players then will play two more [[rapid chess]] games, with 10 minutes plus a 10-second increment per move, per player.
* If the match is still tied, players then will play two [[Blitz chess
column2: blitz games]], with 5 minutes plus a 3-second increment per move, per player.

column1: * If the match is still tied, a single blitz game, with 3 minutes plus a 2-second increment per move, will be played to decide the match. A drawing of lots will determine which player plays white. If drawn, the players will switch colors and play again, until a decisive result was obtained.

Each round will last three days: two for classical time limit games and a third, if necessary, for tie-breaks. Rounds 1 to 3 will run from July 30 to August 7; August 8 will be a rest day; Rounds 4 to 6 will run from August 9 to 17; August 18 will be a rest day; and the last two rounds will run from August 19 to 27.
The total prize fund will be US$1,834,000, with the first prize of US$110,000.
The current qualifiers are seeded here by their FIDE rating of May 2023, apart from World Champion [[Ding Liren]], who is seeded first. All players are [[Grandmaster (chess)
The 206 participants will be (paths whose qualifiers are listed above are in bold):
* '''The current women's world chess champion, [[Ju Wenjun]]'''
* '''The top four players in the [[Chess World Cup 2021]]'''
* 80 players qualifying from Continental and [[Geography of chess
column2: Zonal]] events, such as the [[African Chess Championship]] and [[European Individual Chess Championship]]

column1: * The 13 highest-rated players from the June 2023 [[FIDE world rankings
* 100 federations spots selected according to the final standings of the [[Open event at the 44th Chess Olympiad
The participants will be seeded by their FIDE rating of July 2023, apart from World Champion [[Ding Liren]], who will be seeded first.

column2: image     = Shinee at the SHINee World Concert II in Taiwan 02.jpg
caption   = Shinee performing at [[Shinee World II]] in Taiwan in 2012

column1: South Korean boy band [[Shinee]] have headlined eleven concert tours, three concerts and six showcases, and additionally participated in eight company tours and seven joint tours. Debuting in 2008, they made early concert appearances at the [[Dream Concert (South Korea)
column2: 2008 Dream Concert]] and [[SM Town Live '08]]. They embarked on their first concert tour, [[Shinee World (concert)
column3: Shinee World]], in 2010, travelling to various locations across Asia. The following year, they performed at [[Abbey Road Studios]] in London, becoming the first Asian act do so, in anticipation of their Japanese debut.<ref name=""abbeyroad"">{{cite web
column5: title=Korean boy band hits Abbey Road
column12: url-status=live}}</ref> They later became the first Korean idol group to hold an independent concert in London, opening the 6th London Korean Film Festival.<ref name=""london"">{{cite web
column14: title=Shinee Ticket Sales Shut Down Server in England

column1: In 2012, Shinee began their first Japanese arena tour, [[Shinee World 2012]]. The tour attracted 200,000 spectators, setting a new record for the debut Japanese tour of a Korean group.<ref name=""sw2012"">{{cite web
column3: title=200,000 fans flock to see Shinee on first Japan tour
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> They embarked on their first world tour, [[Shinee World III]], in 2014, with tour stops spanning Asia, North America and South America. [[Shinee World 2014]] marked their first time performing at [[Tokyo Dome]], one of the largest concert venues in Japan.<ref name=""td2014"">{{cite web
column13: script-title=ko:샤이니, 10만 관객 앞에서 눈부시게 빛나다 [日 도쿄돔 콘서트]

column25: url-status=live}}</ref> They returned there the following year for Shinee World 2016, adding performances at [[Kyocera Dome Osaka]].<ref name=""domes2016"">{{cite web

column1: [[Category:Lists of concert tours of South Korean artists
'''Zachary E. Muckenhirn''' (born February 27, 1995) is an American professional [[baseball]] [[pitcher]] for the [[New York Mets]] of [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB).
Muckenhirn graduated from Delano High School in [[Delano, Minnesota]], in 2013.<ref>{{Cite web
column2: title=Muckenhirn wanted by top baseball programs in the country
column6: language=en}}</ref> He attended the [[University of North Dakota]] (UND) and played [[college baseball]] for the [[North Dakota Fighting Hawks baseball

column1: The [[Baltimore Orioles]] selected Muckenhirn in the 11th round, with the 331st overall selection, of the [[2016 MLB draft]]. With the selection, he become the highest drafted player in UND history.<ref name=und>{{Cite web
column2: title=UND BASEBALL: Muckenhirn becomes UND’s highest MLB draft pick
column6: language=en}}</ref> He made his professional debut with the Low-A [[Aberdeen IronBirds]], appearing in 12 games and registering a 5-2 record and 2.43 ERA with 34 strikeouts.

column1: In 2017, Muckenhirn made 27 appearances (21 starts) split between Aberdeen and the Single-A [[Delmarva Shorebirds]]. Pitching 124.2 innings, he posted a 5-10 record and 5.13 ERA with 103 strikeouts. The following year, Muckenhirn made 44 relief appearances split between Delmarva, the High-A [[Frederick Keys]], and the Double-A [[Bowie Baysox]], recording a cumulative 3.64 ERA with 79 strikeouts and 8 saves in 64.1 innings pitched.<ref>{{Cite web
Muckenhirn began the 2019 season with Double-A Bowie, receiving a promotion to the Triple-A [[Norfolk Tides]] later in the year.<ref>{{Cite web
column2: title=Baltimore Orioles: Bowie Baysox Feature Several Top Prospects
column6: language=en}}</ref> In 41 appearances split between the two affiliates, he logged a 3-6 record and 4.11 ERA with 73 strikeouts and 5 saves in 57.0 innings pitched. Muckenhirn did not play in a game in 2020 due to the cancellation of the minor league season because of the [[COVID-19 pandemic]].<ref>{{Cite web
column7: title=2020 Minor League Baseball season cancelled
column11: language=en}}</ref> On April 30, 2021, Muckenhirn was released by the Orioles organization.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: On May 1, 2021, Muckenhirn signed a minor league contract with the [[Chicago White Sox]] organization.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: language=en}}</ref> He spent the year with the Double-A [[Birmingham Barons]], appearing in 30 games and posting a 3-1 record and 1.77 ERA with 42 strikeouts in 40.2 innings pitched.

column1: In 2022, Muckenhirn made 47 appearances for the Triple-A [[Charlotte Knights]], registering a 3-1 record and 3.11 ERA with 56 strikeouts and 2 saves in 55.0 innings of work. He elected free agency following the season on November 10, 2022.<ref>{{Cite web
column2: title=2022-23 Minor League Free Agents For All 30 MLB Teams

column1: On November 23, 2022, Muckenhirn signed a minor league contract with the [[New York Mets]] organization.<ref>{{Cite web
column2: title=Mets sign pitchers Zach Muckenhirn and Denyi Reyes to minor league deals
column6: language=en}}</ref> He competed for a bullpen spot in Spring Training,<ref>{{Cite web
column7: title=Mets’ Zach Muckenhirn: Could win bullpen spot
column11: language=en}}</ref> but did not win the job and was assigned to the Triple-A [[Syracuse Mets]] to begin the 2023 season.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=Mets’ Zach Muckenhirn: Reassigned to MiLB camp
column16: language=en}}</ref> In 6 appearances to start the year, he posted a strong 0.77 ERA with 4 strikeouts and 1 save in 11.2 innings of work. On May 1, 2023, the Mets selected Muckenhirn to the 40-man roster and promoted him to the major leagues for the first time in advance of the team’s [[doubleheader (baseball)
column23: title=Seven years after cutting baseball, UND has its first Major League player in Muckenhirn

column3: title=Patna-Ranchi Vande Bharat Express To Start Operations Soon: Check Route, Speed, Launch Date, Timings

column3: title=Train 18, India's Fastest, Named ""Vande Bharat Express"": Piyush Goyal

column1: '''Karen Batchelor''', formerly '''Karen Batchelor Farmer''' is an American lawyer, community activist, and genealogist. In 1977, she became the first-known [[African American]] member of the [[Daughters of the American Revolution]]. As a genealogist, she co-founded the Fred Hart Williams Genealogical Society, which researches and preserves African-American family history. Batchelor is also a member of the [[Winthrop Society]], the [[Associated Daughters of Early American Witches]], the [[National Society of New England Women]], and the [[Association of Professional Genealogists]].

Batchelor was born in [[Detroit]] to Alice Vivian Dickinson, a schoolteacher, and Thomas Melvin Batchelor, a doctor who was the first African-American on staff, and the first African-American to teach, at [[Sinai-Grace Hospital]].<ref name= daughter>{{Cite web
column5: access-date=May 1, 2023}}</ref><ref name= freep/> Batchelor's maternal grandfather, Frederick Dickinson, was from [[Bermuda]].<ref name= daughter/> Her maternal great-grandmother, Jennie Daisy Hood, was white and her materna; great-grandfather, Prince Albert Weaver, was black.<ref name= daughter/><ref name= nytimes/> On her father's side, Batchelor is descended from Isaiah Parker, a landowner who purchased an enslaved woman named Charity Ann from his father's estate and had seventeen children with her.<ref name= daughter/> She is also a descendant from William Wood, an Irishman who emigrated to the American colonies and served as a private 6th class in the Lancaster County Militia during the [[American Revolutionary War]].<ref name= nytimes/><ref>{{Cite web
column9: access-date=May 1, 2023}}</ref> She had ancestors that fought for both the [[Union Army]] and the [[Confederate States Army]] during the [[American Civil War]].<ref name= nytimes/>

column1: Batchelor grew up in a politically active household in the Russell Woods neighborhood, as both of her parents were civil rights activists who kept many books about the history and struggles of African-Americans in their home library.<ref name= daughter/><ref name= freep/> Batchelor grew up attending the [[Detroit Opera]], visiting museums, and taking violin lessons.<ref name= daughter/> She was also a member of the [[Camp Fire (organization)
column2: Camp Fire Girls of America]] in her youth.<ref name= daughter/> Batchelor attended nursery school at Tabernacle Missionary Baptist Church and was educated in [[Detroit Public Schools Community District
column3: Detroit public schools]].<ref name= freep/> As as a teenager, she attended the racially integrated Arthur Junior High School.<ref name= daughter/><ref name= freep>{{Cite web
column5: title=Karen Batchelor's ancestry research helped her make DAR history
column7: access-date=May 1, 2023}}</ref> In 1966, she graduated from [[Cass Technical High School]].<ref name= freep/> As a young woman, she was a [[debutante]] and was presented to society at The Cotillion Club, which was founded by her father.<ref name= daughter/>

column1: She majored in anthropology at [[Fisk University]] before transferring to [[Oakland University]], where she graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree in psychology.<ref name= daughter/><ref name= freep/> She earned a juris doctor from [[Wayne State University Law School]].<ref name= freep/><ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Karen Batchelor: First black DAR member. Somebody has to. - Daughter Dialogues

column1: Batchelor practiced as litigator, worked in corporate law, worked as a lobbyist, and represented plaintiffs in a civil rights firm.<ref name= daughter/> In 1995, she stopped practicing law and founded The MichCon/Think Twice Foundation's Block Club, which worked to bring local businesses, community organizations, and residents together to revitalize neighborhoods in Detroit.<ref name= points>{{Cite web
column4: access-date=May 1, 2023}}</ref> She is also a certified life coach.<ref name= daughter/>

column1: In October 1977, Batchelor became the first-known black member of the [[Daughters of the American Revolution]] when she joined the Ezra Parker chapter in [[Royal Oak, Michigan]].<ref name= daughter/><ref name= nytimes/> Her admission into the society, as the 623,128th member, was reported by ''[[The New York Times]]'', the ''[[Detroit Free Press]]'', and over two-hundred other news publications.<ref name= daughter/><ref name= american>{{Cite web
column5: access-date=May 1, 2023}}</ref> She appeared on ''[[Good Morning America]]'' and ''[[NBC Nightly News]]''.<ref name= daughter/> Batchelor applied to multiple Michigan chapters but was never contacted, until the Ezra Parker chapter responded to her inquiry.<ref name= nytimes/> A chapter in California, upon hearing of her membership, questioned the validity of her genealogical proof and accused the National Society of improper behavior.<ref name= nytimes/><ref name= washpost/> Batchelor's membership was defended by Jeannette O. Baylies, the President General of the Daughters of the American Revolution.<ref name= nytimes/><ref name=washpost>{{cite news

column1: In 1979, Batchelor co-founded the Fred Hart Williams Genealogical Society, which researches and preserves African-American family history.<ref name= freep/><ref>{{Cite web
column8: access-date=May 1, 2023}}</ref> She also served as the National Vice Chair of Lineage Research for African American Patriots and Research.<ref name= daughter/> She is a member of the Women Descendants of the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company, the [[Associated Daughters of Early American Witches]], the [[Winthrop Society]], the [[National Society of New England Women]], and the National Society Daughters of Colonial Wars.<ref name= daughter/> She is also a member of the [[Association of Professional Genealogists]].<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Batchelor was married, but later divorced, and has one son.<ref name= daughter/><ref name= nytimes>{{Cite web
column3: title=A Detroit Black Woman's Roots Lead to a Welcome in the D.A.R.
column4: first=William K. Stevens Special to The New York

column1: 73698625,2013_Pasig_local_elections,"Local elections were held in '''[[Pasig]]''' on May 13, 2013 within the [[2013 Philippine general election
column2: Philippine general election]]. The voters elected for the elective local posts in the city: the mayor, vice mayor, the congressman, and the councilors, six of them in the two districts of the city.

column1: Mayor Roberto ""Bobby"" Eusebio initially ran for third and final term, but later substituted by his wife, Maria Belen ""Maribel"" Andaya-Eusebio. Andaya-Eusebio faced independent candidates Ismael Mejia and Wainwright Rivera<ref>{{Cite web
column2: title=Pasig City Local Candidates and Mock Elections 2013

column1: Vice Mayor Rosalio ""Yoyong"" Martires was term-limited, and he ran for city council. His position were contested by councilors Rodrigo Asilo and Iyo Christian Bernardo. Another candidate for vice mayor were independents Vicente Fabella and Nemencio San Juan.
Rep. [[Roman Romulo]] ran for third and final term. He was challenged by Jun Salatandre.

column1: '''HD 177406''', also known as '''HR 7223''' or rarely ''47 G. Telescopii'', is a solitary [[star]]<ref name = Eggleton2008/> located in the southern [[constellation]] [[Telescopium]]. It is faintly visible to the [[naked eye]] as a white-hued point of light with an [[apparent magnitude]] of 5.95.<ref name = Tycho2000/> [[Gaia DR3]] [[parallax]] measurements imply a distance of 369 [[light year]]s<ref name = GaiaDR3/> and it is currently approaching the [[Solar System]] with a heliocentric [[radial velocity]] of {{val
column3: ul=km/s}}.<ref name = Gontcharov2006/> At its current distance, HD 177406's brightness is diminished by 0.23 [[magnitude (astronomy)
column5: interstellar dust]]<ref name = Gontcharov2017/> and it has an [[absolute magnitude]] of +0.60.<ref name = Anderson2012/>

column1: HD 177406 has a [[stellar classification]] of A0 V,<ref name = Houk1978/> indicating that it is an ordinary [[A-type main-sequence star]] that is generating energy via [[hydrogen]] fusion at its [[stellar core
column2: core]]. It has 2.64 times the [[mass of the Sun]]<ref name = Stassun2019/> and a radius 2.55 times that of the [[Sun]].<ref name = Kervella2004/> It radiates 62.4 times the [[luminosity of the Sun]]<ref name = GaiaDR3/> from its [[photosphere]] at an [[effective temperature]] of {{val
column5: fmt=commas}}.<ref name = Stassun2019/> It has a solar [[metallicity]] at [Fe/H] = +0.00 and it is estimated to be 286 [[million years]] old,<ref name = Gontcharov2012A/> having completed 58.66% of its [[main sequence]] lifetime.<ref name = GaiaDR3/>

Joint venture between STMicroelectronics and NXP Semiconductors}}

column1: '''ST-NXP Wireless''' was a joint venture made up of the wireless operations of [[STMicroelectronics]] and [[NXP Semiconductors]], existing between 2008 to 2009.

Formerly a division of the semiconductor firm [[Royal Philips Electronics]], NXP was established as an independent company in 2006. STMicroelectronics was formed in June 1987 by the merger of semiconductor companies SGS Microelettronica of Italy and Thomson Semiconductors, the semiconductor arm of France's Thomson.<ref>{{cite web

column2: title=STMicroelectronics and NXP Complete Deal to Create New Wireless Semiconductor Company

column1: In April 2008, NXP and STMicroelectronics announced a merger of their wireless chip divisions, to create a joint-venture called ST-NXP Wireless.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=STMicro, NXP merge $3 bln wireless chip operations
column7: date=10 April 2008}}</ref> The merger was intended to combine their wireless operations in 2G, 2.5G, 3G, multimedia, connectivity and future wireless technologies, with both businesses contributing significant portfolios of communication and multimedia patents.

column1: In August 2008, another 50/50 joint-venture was formed between ST-NXP Wireless and [[Ericsson]], and in February 2009, STMicroelectronics purchased NXP's stake in the ST-NXP joint venture, resulting in the formation of [[ST-Ericsson]].<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Ericsson and ST Complete Deal To Create Joint Venture For Semiconductors & Platforms In Mobile Applications

column1: Key products of ST-NXP included the [[Nomadik]] SoC platform designed for smartphones.<ref name=""corporate-ir"">{{cite web
column6: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> The Nomadik STn8820 was announced in February 2008, and featured an [[ARM11]] processor, combined with an ATI [[Imageon]] Z460 3D graphics accelerator.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=ST-NXP Datasheet: STn8820 Mobile multimedia application processor
column9: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> No products are known to have ever used this processor, and the Nomadik name was later retired, with future SoC processors from [[ST-Ericsson]] launching instead under the [[NovaThor]] brand.

column2: neoclassical]] palace in [[Tervuren]], [[Belgium]]. It was intended as summer retreat for prince [[Prince Charles Alexander of Lorraine
column3: Charles of Lorraine]], governor of the [[Austrian Netherlands]]. However, it was soon demolished and nothing remains any more.

column1: Tervuren was one of the main summer retreats of the Dukes of [[Duke of Brabant
column2: Brabant]] and their successors, the [[Burgundian Netherlands
column3: Burgundian]] dukes and the governors of the [[List of governors of the Habsburg Netherlands
column7: title=Le nouveau Château de Charles de Lorraine à tervuren
column9: work=Revue belge d’Archéologie en d’Histoire de l‘Art/ Belgisch Tijdschrift voor Oudheidkunde en Kunstgeschiedenis
column10: publisher= L'Académie royale d'Archéologie de Belgique
column15: title= Het Château Charles in de buurt van Tervuren
column18: publisher=Koninklijke Vereniging der Historische Woonsteden en Tuinen van België
column20: pages=7-14 }} </ref> They primarily used the castle in Tervuren as a basis to hunt in the surrounding [[Sonian Forest]].<ref name="":1"" /><ref name="":2"" /> Although the castle was medieval in origin, it was modernized and redesigned over time up to the 18th century.<ref name="":1"" /><ref name="":2"" /> But as the moated palace became too damp, governor Charles of Lorraine decided to construct a new palace, the Château Charles. He commissioned [[Laurent-Benoît Dewez]] to design the new summer lodge.<ref name="":1"" /><ref name="":2"" /> When Dewez fell out of favour, [[Louis Montoyer]] and [[Antoine Payen the Elder
column21: Antoine Payen]] completed the palace.<ref name="":1"" /><ref name="":2"" />

column1: Construction started in 1778.<ref name="":1"" /><ref name="":2"" /> The main building was already completed in 1779, and furnishing followed soon.<ref name="":1"" /><ref name="":2"" /> With a great feast, the palace was put into use on 1 September 1779.<ref name="":1"" /><ref name="":2"" /> It was barely finished when Charles of Lorraine passed away in 1780.<ref name="":1"" /><ref name="":2"" /> His nephew, emperor [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor
column2: Joseph II]] first intended to sell the country house, but ultimately he made decision to demolish Château Charles as well as the Tervuren castle to recycle its building materials to pay for the debts Charles of Lorraine had left.<ref name="":1"" /><ref name="":2"" /> Charles successors as governors, [[Maria Christina, Duchess of Teschen
column3: Archduchess Maria Christina of Austria]] and her husband [[Albert Casimir, Duke of Teschen
column4: Prince Albrecht of Saxony-Teschen]] commissioned a new palace in [[Palace of Laeken
column5: Laeken]], which was constructed between 1782 and 1784.<ref name="":1"" /><ref name="":2"" />

column1: Nowadays, nothing remains anymore of the Château Charles.<ref name="":1"" /><ref name="":2"" /> The plans made by Dewez can be found back in the [[National Archives of Belgium]].<ref name="":1"" /><ref name="":2"" /><ref>{{cite web
column3: title= Plans Dewez: VIII. Tervueren. Château Charles de Lorraine - numbers 396/397/398/399/400
column5: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> In addition, the [[Archives Nationales (France)
column6: National Archives]] of France have a plan and drawings of how the palace looked like.<ref name="":1"" /><ref name="":2"" /><ref>{{cite web
column8: title= Plan de l’Hermitage de la terre de Charles à Tervuren

column1: [[Olivier Le May]] made two gouaches of the château, which are now in a private collection.<ref name="":1"" />

column1: '''Erika Cuéllar Soto''' (born in [[Santa Cruz de la Sierra]], 1978), is a Bolivian biologist recognized as the guardian of the [[Gran Chaco]] region of South America, where she has worked to promote and conserve this ecosystem that covers regions of Argentina, Bolivia, Paraguay and Brazil. A fundamental axis of her activism is the training of local community members in the conservation of their territory as well as the training of parabiologists to be guardians of nature.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: website=explorer-directory.nationalgeographic.org}}</ref> She has been named a National Geographic explorer.<ref name="":1"">{{Cite web
column7: title=Erika Cuéllar, la exploradora boliviana de Nat Geo

column1: Cuéllar graduated in biology from the [[Gabriel René Moreno Autonomous University]] and then obtained a master's degree in [[Biodiversity]] Conservation from the [[University of Kent]] in England. She earned a PhD in [[Zoology]] at the [[University of Oxford]].<ref name="":1"" /><ref name="":0"">{{Cite web

column3: [[Guanaco]], the wild ancestor of the llama.]]

column1: Cuéllar's work focuses mainly on the conservation and sustainable protection of the Gran Chaco, she is coordinator of the Species Survival Committee of the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]].  A fundamental part of her work consists of training parabiologists, that is, making communities and the local population participate in caring for their environment through comprehensive training so that they can be researchers and custodians of natural resources. In this regard, she has said: “I would like the local people, who know so much about nature, because they were born and lived in it, to stop being (considered) simply cheap labor.”<ref>{{Cite web
She has worked prominently for the protection of juvenile and adult [[Guanaco
column2: guanacos]]. Thanks to Cuéllar's efforts, their hunting has become prohibited, the repopulation of genetically isolated herds is being explored and attempts are being made to recover their habitat, which had been invaded by free-range cattle and invasive plants.<ref name="":0"" /> According to Arrazola, Cuéllar's impact continues,<blockquote>Erika Cuéllar's innovative solutions and great passion bring new hope to wildlife. She trains villagers in the Gran Chaco to be practical conservation managers and parabiologists. Communities nominate participants for the 800-hour course that ranges from basic biology, mathematics, and other sciences to map production, computer and GPS use, research project design, data collection, and presentation of results. Those who pass the final exam take their professional skills to the forests, wetlands and rangelands. They make bird and mammal census reports, display and analyze data from cameras and radio tracking devices.<ref name="":2"">{{Cite web
column6: title=Erika Cuéllar: “La gente tiene el poder de cambiar el rumbo del medioambiente”
column10: language=es}}In 2016, Cuéllar was part of the team that made the first recorded sightings of the [[Bushy-tailed jird
column11: Sekeetamys calurus]] rodent (Bushy-tailed Jird) in the territory of southern [[Oman]], in western Asia.<ref>{{Cite journal
column17: title=First record of the bushy-tailed jird, Sekeetamys calurus (Thomas, 1892) (Rodentia: Muridae) in Oman

column1: '''Bongani Mohosana''' (born June 9, 1987) known professionally as '''Mörda''' or '''Murdah Bongz''', is a South African DJ, record producer, singer and dancer. He is best known for being a former member of the musical band [[Black Motion]].
Bongani Mohosana was born on the 9th of June 1987 in [[Pretoria]], [[South Africa]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title= Murdah Bongz celebrates birthday, his age stuns Mzansi
column5: accessdate=1 May 2023}}</ref> He developed a passion and interest in music at a young age. He joined the church choir, where he learnt how to play musical instruments and was also involved in singing. He then developed his skills as a music composer, dancer and vocalist.<ref name="":1"">{{cite web
column7: title= MASSIVE TALENT IN ESWATINI - MURDAH BONGZ

column1: In 2009, Bongani Mohosana along with Thabo Mabogwane aka Smol launched a band named [[Black Motion]] and he adopted the stage name Murdah Bongz. The duo started making music and became popular in the year 2011 after releasing their studio album ''Talking to the Drums''.<ref name="":1""/> Several years after the band’s founding, though, both decided to pursue solo careers. Murdah Bongz then changed his stage name to Mörda.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title= 'Thank you to everyone who embraced the change': Mörda celebrates a year going solo

column1: In 2022, he released his first solo debut album, ''Asante'', which was named after his daughter.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title= Murdah Bongz drops his first project as solo act Mörda

column1: In December 2022, it was alleged that Mörda had took recording studio equipment from the Black Motion business premises in December 2022. He was also accused of violently damaging a door at the recording studio, among other properties.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title= Spirit Motion vs Bongani 'Murdah Bongz' Mohosana: Everything you need to know about the legal battle

column1: Following the accusations, Mörda’s legal representatives issued a statement stating that the equipment belongs to Spirit Motion which both Morda and Thabo Smol proportionately owned.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title= ‘They want an apology’: Morda returns Black Motion equipment

column1: Bongani Mohosana married [[DJ]] and producer [[DJ Zinhle]] in 2022. The couple went public with their relationship in 2021, after reports revealed that they had been dating for quite some time in private before going public. The couple had their first baby daughter, Asante in September 2021.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title= DJ Zinhle confirms she is married to Murdah Bongz

column1: '''''Protoplasma''''' is a bimonthly [[peer-reviewed]] [[scientific journal]] covering various aspects of [[protoplasm]] research. It is published by [[Springer Science+Business Media]] and was established in 1926. The [[editor-in-chief]] is P. Nick ([[University of Karlsruhe]]).<ref>{{Cite web
The journal publishes research articles, reviews, and commentaries related to protoplasm, including its [[cell structure]], [[signal transduction]], [[biotechnology]], and [[genetic engineering]].
The journal is abstracted and indexed in:

column3: title=Web of Science Master Journal List

column1: According to the ''[[Journal Citation Reports]]'', the journal has a 2021 [[impact factor]] of 3.186.<ref name=""WoS"">{{cite book

column4: FRAM}} (born 1923) is a [[New Zealand]] pianist and professor of music.

column1: Anderson attended the [[Royal Academy of Music]]. In 1947, she was awarded the Prize for Pianoforte Accompaniment by [[Princess Alice, Duchess of Gloucester]].<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=1947 Prize List Royal Academy of Music
column7: page=8}}</ref> In 1948, she was awarded the Elsie Horne Gift and Albanesi Prize.<ref>{{cite book

column12: via=[[Internet Archive]]}}</ref> In 1949, she was awarded the Chappell Pianoforte Prize and Rae Leeming Memorial Prize.<ref>{{cite book
column15: title=1949 July, Prize List, Royal Academy of Music

column1: Anderson was, for a long time, professor of piano at the [[Royal Academy of Music]]. She adjudicated the Louise Band Prizes in 1978,<ref>{{cite book

column9: title=1979 July, Prize List Royal Academy of Music
column15: title=1980 July, Prize List Royal Academy of Music
column18: page=18}}</ref> and 1985, the Albanesi Prize in 1981,<ref>{{cite book

column27: title=1982 July, List Of Prizes, Scholarships And Other Awards Royal Academy of Music
column32: title=1983 July, List Of Prizes, Scholarships And Other Awards Royal Academy of Music
column34: via=[[Internet Archive]]}}</ref> and 1986,<ref name=""RAM 1986 Prizes"">{{cite book
column37: title=1986 Graduation And Prizegiving Royal Academy of Music
column39: via=[[Internet Archive]]}}</ref> and the Eric Brough Prize in 1982,<ref name=""RAM 1982 Prizes""/> 1983,<ref name=""RAM 1983 Prizes""/> and 1986.<ref name=""RAM 1986 Prizes""/> In 1985 and 1987, she adjudicated the Claude Beddington Prize, the Vivian Langrish Prize, the Frederick Westlake Prize, and the Cuthbert Whitemore Prize.<ref>{{cite book
column42: title=1985 Graduation And Prizegiving Royal Academy of Music
column47: title=1987 Graduation And Prizegiving Royal Academy of Music

column1: Anderson was awarded the [[British Empire Medal]] in the [[2017 New Year Honours]] for ""services to music"".<ref>{{London Gazette

column5: title=Neil Cowley: A Rock and Roll Take on Jazz

column19: title=Lucy Parham in conversation with Melanie Spanswick

column1: In ''Notes from a Small Soprano'', Anderson's former pupil [[Lesley Garrett]] describes the influence of her professorship.

column2: She was the most spirited and lively professor on the entire staff and she understood me better than anyone. Tiny, raven-haired and feisty, she attacked life with the same passionate, electrifying energy that she used when she played the piano and she played wonderfully. She became my unofficial tutor and confidante and is still, to this day, a great friend.""<ref>{{cite book

column1: Sarah Balfour, another of Anderson's pupils, describes her lasting impact.

column2: Jean not only taught me how to play and perform, but I also learnt from her, vital life lessons. All of her teachings will stay with me forever. She towers with strength and wisdom, and is truly inspirational. She handles the turbulence and challenges of life with dignity, poise and composure. She has given me the confidence to succeed and I am indebted to her.""<ref>{{cite web

column1: '''Collin Mocyunas''' (born September 18, 1998) is an American [[association football
column2: soccer]] player who plays as a [[Defender (association football)
column4: South Georgia Tormenta]] in the [[USL League One]].

column2: University High School]], where he was named West Virginia Midfielder of the Year, First Team All-State and helped the team to runner-up in the state tournament. He also played club soccer for Arsenal FC of Pittsburgh for three seasons and was named Player of the Year.<ref name=""auto"">{{Cite web

column1: In 2017, Mocyunas attended [[Marshall University]] to play [[college soccer]]. Here he stayed until 2022 due to a redshirted freshman season and the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] that delayed the 2020 season. Over his college career, Mocyunas made 92 appearances for the Thundering Herd and scored a single goal. In his junior year, he helped the team to be College Cup National Champions, also earning United Soccer Coaches Scholar All-Region honors and Second Team All-Conference USA honors.<ref name=""auto""/><ref>{{Cite web

column3: Michael Armstrong]] and [[Stanley A. Long]] (dually credited as Al Beresford), and written by Armstrong. The film opens with a pair of young men stealing three videotapes, which happen to each contain a tale of terror. The first story is about an evil puppeteer, the second is a haunted house story, and the third is about a caretaker in a haunted garden.<ref name=""Bloody"">{{cite web
column5: title=Low-Budget British Anthology 'Screamtime' Is Rich in Charm

column1: The films second segment, ""Dreamhouse"", was remade and expanded to a feature-length film in 2010 as ''[[Psychosis (film)

Two young men enter a video store and steal three videotapes, which they take to a friend's house to watch. The three stories include ""Killer Punch"", about a puppeteer slowly drawn to homicidal insanity by his nagging wife and stepson, ""Dreamhouse"", about a young newlywed couple whose lives are turned upside down when the wife begins having increasingly disturbing premonitions, and ""Garden of Blood"", the tale of young man who becomes the caretaker of a house with a haunted garden. The wrap-around story sees the men change the videotapes out for each segment, with a twist ending.

[[AllMovie]] stated that ""The real gem here, though, is ""Scream House"" [Dreamhouse], a truly unsettling tale that unfolds at a perfectly creepy pace and boasts a simple but surprising twist ending."" But felt ""the American sequences that glue the three stories together could have been tossed off in an afternoon, but they do offer some entirely unnecessary nudity and boneheaded Brooklynese that should amuse slumming horror fans who give ''Screamtime'' a chance.<ref name=AllMovie/>
The film was originally released on [[VHS]] in 1985 by Lightning Video in the United States.<ref>{{cite web
column8: url-status=live}}</ref> As of 2023, it has yet to be released on [[DVD]] or [[Blu-ray]].

column2: caption            = Portrait of Thomas D. Stimson

column1: '''Thomas Douglas Stimson''' (1828-1898) was an American entrepreneur and businessman who played a significant role in the [[timber industry]] of the [[Pacific Northwest]]. He is best known as the founder and owner of the [[Stimson Lumber Company]], which became one of the largest and most successful lumber companies in the region.

column5: website=www.familysearch.org}}</ref> He left his childhood home in New York at the age of fourteen<ref name="":0"">{{Cite web
column8: access-date=2023-05-01}}</ref> He started his career in the lumber industry working a logging claim in Michigan in the 1850s.<ref>{{Cite web
column13: title=Thomas Douglas Stimson (1828-1898) - Find a Grave...
column18: title=PCAD - Stimson, Thomas Douglas and Achsah J. Spencer, House, University Park, Los Angeles, CA
column21: website=pcad.lib.washington.edu}}</ref> In 1853 he married Achsah Spencer in Grand Rapids.<ref>{{Cite web
column25: website=Familysearch}}</ref> Together they had six children. He then moved his family to Chicago for a number of years before eventually retiring to Los Angeles in 1890.<ref name="":0"" />

column1: In 1873, Stimson founded the Stimson Clark Manufacturing Company. This would later become the Stimson Mill Company, and eventually would be incorporated into the Stimson Lumber Company. This became one of the most prominent lumber companies in the Pacific Northwest. The company specialized in the production of high-quality lumber and timber products, which were in high demand as the region experienced rapid growth and development.

Under Stimson's leadership, the company grew rapidly and expanded its operations throughout the region. By the late 1880s, the Stimson Lumber Company had become one of the largest employers in the Pacific Northwest, with several sawmills, logging camps, and other facilities throughout the region.

Stimson's contributions to the timber industry of the Pacific Northwest were significant and long-lasting. His company played a major role in the economic development of the region and helped to establish the timber industry as one of the key sectors of the regional economy.

Today, the Stimson Lumber Company is still in operation, and it remains one of the largest and most successful lumber companies in the Pacific Northwest. Stimson's legacy as an entrepreneur and business leader continues to be celebrated by historians and industry experts alike, and his contributions to the region's economy and history are still remembered and honored to this day.

column2: Stimson's house]], built in 1891 in [[Los Angeles]], California, is on the [[National Register of Historic Places]].<ref>{{Cite web

column2: title=The obituary notice of Raymond Louis BEURLE
column8: English]] [[electrical engineer]]. In 1963 he became the first professor of electrical engineering at [[University of Nottingham]].

column1: He gained an honours degree in engineering before engaging in experimental work for the [[Royal Navy]] during the [[Second World War]].<ref name=""Nature 4877"">{{cite journal
column7: url=https://www.nature.com/articles/198245c0.pdf}}</ref> He then went on to work on the application of new techniques to aid blind people, completing his PhD thesis  ""Electronic Aids for Blind People"". He then started working for the [[Royal Radar Establishment]] in [[Malvern]] before moving onto [[Imperial College]], [[London]] in 1955. In 1957 he moved on to [[English Electric Valve Company]] (EEV), where he was manager of the Camera Tube and Image Tube Research Department.<ref name=""Nature 4877""/>

column1: While he was living in [[Great Baddow]], he had a patent registered for an image production invention which he assigned to EEV.<ref name=""US3038959A"">{{cite web

He participated in the [[Symposium on Principles of Self-Organization]] organised by [[Heinz von Foerster]] in 1960, delivering a paper on ""Functional Organization in Random Networks"".<ref name =""ITCSTTA"">{{cite journal
column2: journal=International Tracts in Computer Science and Technology and Their Application

column1: '''Christina Wing''' is a senior lecturer in the Technology and Operations Management Unit at [[Harvard Business School]]. She is also co-founder of Wingspan Legacy Partners, an advisory firm for family and founder-owned businesses and family offices.

Wing, a Harvard Business School graduate, joined the faculty in 2016, teaching in the Technology and Operations Management Unit. She is the creator of the ""Demystifying Families in Business"" course and chairs Harvard Business School's Families in Business executive education program, as well as co-chairing the Family Office and Rising Generation programs. Wing is also a frequent instructor in the HBS/Young Presidents’ Organization programs.

As the co-founder of Wingspan Legacy Partners, Wing and her team assist founders and families in building and maintaining their legacies while enhancing family harmony, business prosperity, and societal impact. She began her career in [[Equity (finance)
column2: equity]] and energy investment banking at [[Goldman Sachs]] and [[Kidder, Peabody & Company

column1: Wing is an advisor on various boards, including Crestview Partners, F3 Partners, Northrim Horizon, and Corvias, and she serves on the Board of Ambassadors of The Steppingstone Foundation.
Wing, originally from [[The Woodlands, Texas]], obtained her [[Master of Business Administration
column2: MBA]] from Harvard Business School following her graduation from [[Southern Methodist University]]. She currently resides near [[Boston]] with her husband and three children.

column1: Wing's research covers all facets of family businesses and family offices with a focus on governance structures, succession planning, family dynamics, operating companies, next-generation education, family philanthropy, and legacy building.

column2: Un roman français}}) is a 2009 novel by the French writer [[Frédéric Beigbeder]]. It was awarded the [[Prix Renaudot]].

column1: An [[autobiographical novel]], the starting point of ''A French Novel'' is an incident on 28 January 2008, when [[Frédéric Beigbeder]] was arrested for snorting [[cocaine]] outside a nightclub in Paris. As he is incarcerated by the police for two days, he reflects on his childhood, his grandfather, the divorce of his parents, the characters of his father and brother, his early infatuations, and the France of the 1960s and 1970s he grew up in.
''A French Novel'' received the [[Prix Renaudot]] in 2009.<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Le prix Renaudot attribué à Frédéric Beigbeder

column1: [[Sylvia Brownrigg]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' said the book is amusing and Beigbeder entertains the reader with a mix of highbrow and lowbrow cultural references, including [[Gustave Flaubert]], [[Louis-Ferdinand Céline]], [[foie gras]], [[Jack Bauer]], ''[[Absolutely Fabulous]]'' and [[Carambar]], and walks ""a fine line between self-pity and self-awareness"".<ref>{{cite news
column7: title=A French Novel by Frédéric Beigbeder – review
column9: access-date=1 May 2023 }}</ref> Ivan Juritz of ''[[The Independent]]'' called it ""striking in its lack of bravado"" and said it can be read as a commentary on Beigbeder's other novels.<ref>{{cite news
column14: title=Review: A French Novel, By Frédéric Beigbeder

73699199,Karl_Deeter,"'''Karl Deeter''' is an [[American-Irish]] financial commentator, [[media pundit]] and [[business journalist]] based in Ireland, who regularly appears for outlets such as [[TodayFM]] and the ''[[Business Post]]''.<ref name=""World according to""/> He also is also a musician.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Karl Deeter: Far Far Away review – Gorgeous and smart-shaped songs

column1: Born {{birth based on age as of date
column13: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> in [[Los Angeles]] in the [[United States]], Deeter immigrated to Ireland as a child with his family.<ref name=""World according to""/> He attended [[Gormanston College]] as a teenager before immigrated to [[Chicago]] in his early 20s. He returned to Ireland in his mid-20s and setup the company Irish Mortgage Brokers.<ref name=""Times Jan 2018""/>

column1: In April 2015, Deeter described himself as an ""espouser of old-style liberal economic [[laissez-faire]]"", although acknowledged the need for the state to intervene in instances of [[market failure]].<ref name=""World according to"">{{cite news
column5: title=The world according to... Karl Deeter

column1: In the Spring of 2015, Deeter became the ""Ethics Officer"" of the newly created political party [[Renua]], which had just split off from [[Fine Gael]].<ref name=""Journal 13 March 2015"">{{cite news
column5: title=Here's everything we know about Renua Ireland (and its policies)
column9: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> Although an official with the party, Deeter stated he was not a member of the party.<ref name=""Journal 13 March 2015""/> In June 2016 Deeter resigned as Renua's Ethics Officer; Deeter quit after he ""encountered obstacles"" while investigating claims that businessman and founder of the conservative anti-EU party [[Libertas.eu]] [[Declan Ganley]] had loaned Renua money.<ref>{{cite news
column13: title=Renua’s ethics officer quits over Ganley loan
