column2: Commercial building in Hertford, Hertfordshire, England}}
designation1_offname = Former Corn Exchange and Public Hall

column1: The '''Corn Exchange''' is a commercial building on Fore Street in [[Hertford]], [[Hertfordshire]], England. The building, which is currently used as an events venue, is a Grade II [[listed building]].<ref name=listed>{{NHLE
column3: desc= Former Corn Exchange and Public Hall

column1: The site currently occupied by the corn exchange on the north side of Fore Street originally accommodated a gaol which dated from around 1702 and which had been demolished in 1777 to make way for a butchers' market.<ref>{{cite web
column11: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> Corn merchants traded in corn behind the [[Shire Hall, Hertford
column12: Shire Hall]] until the first purpose-built corn exchange was erected immediately to the west of the Cross Keys Inn on Fore Street in the 1840s.<ref>{{cite web

column1: In the mid-19th century, civic leaders decided that the original structure was inadequate and should be replaced with a new structure. The new building was designed by [[William Hill (architect)
column2: William Hill]] of [[Leeds]] in the [[Neoclassical architecture
column3: neoclassical style]], built in [[ashlar]] stone and was completed in 1859. The design involved a symmetrical main frontage of three bays facing onto Fore Street. On the ground floor, the central bay contained a panelled doorway while the outer bays contained tri-partite windows where the parts were separated by [[Anta (architecture)
column4: antae]]. The first floor was fenestrated by three round headed windows with [[architrave]]s and [[Keystone (architecture)
column5: keystone]]s, each with an inner window, where the parts were also separated by antae. The bays were flanked by [[Corinthian order]] [[pilaster]]s which supported an [[entablature]] and a [[pediment]]. The entablature was inscribed with the words ""Corn Exchange and Public Hall"", while the pediment containing a circular panel bearing a carving of a [[Hart (deer)
column7: tympanum]]. Internally, the principal room was the main hall which was intended to serve as a library when not in use for corn trading.<ref>{{cite book
column9: title=The British Almanac of the Society for the Diffusion of Natural Knowledge
column11: page=248}}</ref> The architectural historian, [[Nikolaus Pevsner]], described the design as ""like that of an ambitious methodist chapel"".<ref>{{cite book

column1: In August 1914, at the start of the [[World War I
column2: First World War]], recruits for the [[Bedfordshire and Hertfordshire Regiment
column3: 4th (Militia) battalion, The Bedfordshire Regiment]] were billeted in the building.<ref>{{cite web
column11: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> At the apex of the pediment there was originally a statue of the Roman goddess of agriculture, [[Ceres (mythology)
column12: Ceres]], but this was removed during the [[World War II
column13: Second World War]] to prevent it causing injury to passers-by during German bombing.<ref name=listed/>

column1: The use of the building as a corn exchange declined significantly in the wake of the [[Great Depression of British Agriculture]] in the late 19th century.<ref>{{cite book
column5: title= 'The Great Depression of English Agriculture 1873-1896' in ''British Agriculture 1875-1914''
column10: page= 31}}</ref> However, the use of the building as a public events venue continued and performers who hosted vents in the corn hall included the [[Rock music
column11: rock band]], ''[[The Who]]'', in March 1965 and the rock band, ''[[The Kinks]]'', in June 1966.<ref>{{cite news
column13: title=The legendary The Who and The Kinks gigs played at Hertford Corn Exchange over the years
column16: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref>  In May 1979, [[East Hertfordshire District Council]] gave planning consent to convert the ground floor of the building, on the Market Street elevation, into shops while retaining the first floor for use as a public hall.<ref>{{cite news
column21: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> The building was acquired by the concert promoter, Chris Addison, in 2008.<ref>{{cite news
column23: title= Hertford to the Fore – meet the ambitious people of Fore Street in our county town
column28: title= Chart-toppers to play new Enfield music festival

column2: alt                = A white woman wearing glasses and a traditional nun's habit, with wimple headwear and a cross on her chest
caption            = Sister Joan Margaret, from a 1957 publication of the President's Committee on Employment of the Physically Handicapped
occupation         = Anglican missionary and school administrator
title=St. Vincent’s Center For Children With Disabilities in Haiti
column5: website=St. Vincent’s Center For Children With Disabilities in Haiti: Leadership
column6: language=en-US}}</ref>, usually known as '''Sister Joan Margaret''', was a member of the Anglican [[Society of Saint Margaret]] and a missionary in Haiti. She founded St. Vincent's School for Handicapped Children in [[Port-au-Prince]] in the 1940s, and was the school's principal for decades.

column1: Elizabeth Burke was born in [[Merrimac, Massachusetts]], the daughter of David W. Gardner and Adeline B. Hemmenway.<ref>U.S. Social Security Applications and Claims Index, via Ancestry.</ref> She was raised [[Newburyport, Massachusetts]] by her adoptive parents, Robert Burke and Mabel Wood Simpson Burke. Robert Burke was an attorney, and mayor of Newburyport when Elizabeth was young.<ref name="":1"">{{Cite web
column5: title=Haiti quake brought death to school founded by a local nun
column9: language=en}}</ref> She trained as a physical therapist. She joined the [[Anglican religious order]], the Society of Saint Margaret, in 1937.<ref name="":2"">{{Cite web
column13: title=Sister Joan Margaret, a savior to Haiti's disabled
column21: journal=Performance: The Story of the Handicapped
column25: title=History of the Society of St. Margaret

column1: Sister Joan Margaret did parish work in [[Utica, New York]] and at a mission in [[Bracebridge, Ontario]]. She arrived in Haiti in 1944 as a parish visitor, and opened a day nursery. Her work developed into the St. Vincent's School for Handicapped Children in the capital city, opened in 1945<ref>{{Cite web
column6: website=Diocesan Press Service}}</ref> and licensed in 1950.<ref name="":3"" /> The school included dormitories, medical and dental clinics, and an orthopedics shop.<ref name="":4"">{{Cite web
column13: language=en-US}}</ref> She especially encouraged musical training, and led the school's orchestra and [[Handbell
column14: handbell choir]] on international tours. One of her students was violinist [[Romel Joseph]].<ref name="":2"" />

column1: Sister Joan Margaret accompanied students to the United States for medical treatment when needed.<ref name="":5"">{{Cite news
column8: via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> She toured in the United States, especially in Florida, speaking about her work at [[Episcopal Church (United States)
column9: Episcopal Church]] events, to raise funds and awareness.<ref>{{Cite news
column11: title=Episcopal Group Hears of Work With Handicapped
column16: via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> ""It's a life to live, not a work to be done,"" she explained of her vocation.<ref>{{Cite news
column18: title=Noted Nun Credits Works to Corporate Prayer Life
column23: via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> In 1980, she and [[Harold Russell]] were honored by the [[Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation]], for their work on behalf of disabled people.<ref name="":5"" />

column1: Sister Joan Margaret had [[arthritis]] that required the use of crutches by the late 1970s,<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=She Makes Sun Rise for Kids
column10: via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> and she used a wheelchair by the mid-1980s.<ref name="":4"" /> She retired from Haiti in 2003; she died in [[Brookline, Massachusetts]] in 2005, at the age of 99.<ref name="":2"" /> Her school, now known as St. Vincent's Center for Children with Disabilities in Haiti, remains in operation,<ref name="":0"" /> but at a new, more accessible site<ref>{{Cite web
column12: title=New Site, New Life for St. Vincent’s Center in Haiti
column16: language=en}}</ref> after the former buildings were destroyed, and several students died, in the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]].<ref name="":1"" /><ref>{{Cite web
column20: title=All heart: Armless Haitian artists serve neighbors

column1: As of May 2023 he was the #8 ranked bantamweight in the world by Beyond Kick.<ref>{{cite web

Yamada made his professional debut against Chihiro Sugiyama at SHOOT BOXING Hanayashiki Extreme.2 on August 24, 2019. column2: title=シュートボクシング 8.24 浅草花やしき：村田義光、CAZ JANJIRAに延長逆転勝ち。増井侑輝がKO勝ち

column2: title=シュートボクシング 10.27 浅草花やしき：山田彪太朗＆虎矢太兄弟の相手決定。全カード揃う

column6: title=GSBグラップリングシュートボクサーズ　寝技打撃師ブログ

column1: Yamada faced Kanta Tabuchi at SHOOT BOXING 2020 act.2 on November 28, 2020.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=シュートボクシング 11.28 後楽園ホール：全選手計量クリア。喜多村誠「70kgの壁を見せ付けて勝ちたい」×海人「70kgの壁だろうと突き破って僕が勝つ」
column5: access-date=30 April 2023}}</ref> The fight was ruled a no-contest at the 1:45 minute mark of the first round, due to an accidental clash of heads.

column1: Yamada faced Takuya Kudo at Shoot Boxing 2021 act.1 on February 7, 2021. He won the fight by a first-round knockout.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=【シュートボクシング】笠原弘希がスアレックを完全KO、笠原友希も栗秋祥梧に勝利

column6: title=シュートボクシング 4.10 後楽園ホール：海人、モハン・ドラゴンからダウン奪い判定勝ち「これから世界の強豪と70kgで殴り合う」

column1: Yamada faced the third-ranked [[Shootboxing]] champion Genki at Shoot Boxing 2021 act.3 on June 20, 2021. He won the fight by unanimous decision, with two scorecards of 30–29 and one scorecard of 29–29.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=【シュートボクシング】海人がZST王者・小金翔の投げを封じて6連勝、笠原弘希は古村匡平との接戦を制す、村田聖明がモハン・ドラゴンに勝利

column1: Yamada rematched Kanta Tabuchi at Shoot Boxing 2021 act.4 on September 4, 2021, having fought to a no-contest with him a year prior. The fight was ruled a draw after the first three rounds of the bout were contested, with all three ringside officials handing in a 28–28 scorecard. Yamada was declared the winner after an extra fourth round, with two of the judges scoring the fight 10–9 in his favor.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=シュートボクシング 9.4 後楽園ホール：「今後はサウスポーに変えていきたい」海人、チャンスックを切り裂き判定勝ち

column1: Yamada faced Aoshi at Shoot Boxing 2022 act.3 on June 26, 2022.<ref>{{cite web

column1: '''Lucy Helen Yates''' (1863 – 1935) was a British suffragist and writer on cookery and finance. She left the Pankhursts' [[Women's Social and Political Union]] (WSPU) to join the [[Women's Freedom League]].

column2: Basford]] near Nottingham in 1863. Some of her early writing was for the [[Girl's Own Paper]].<ref name=""perse"">{{Cite web
column6: website=Persephone Books}}</ref> She started in 1892 writing about cookery.<ref name=""girlsown"">{{Cite web

column1: Her first book ''The Profession of Cookery from a French Point of View'' was about cookery and so was her second. In 1903 she turned to finance in 1903 writing a book for businesswomen titled   ''Management of Money A Handbook of Finance for Women''.

In November 1907 she joined the mass exodus from the WSPU to join the Women's Freedom League and as a writer it was her job to explain the difference between the two organisations. She wrote that the WFL was democratic and they did not interupt cabinet ministers as the WSPU were known to do. She was an assistant organising secretary of the WFL and she write articles for the WFL's paper ""The Vote"".<ref name=""simkin"">{{Cite web
In 1911 she was working for the [[Daily Mail]] and she did make a census return<ref name=""simkin""/> (when some suffragists refused to cooperate).

She also gave talks at WFL events talking about finance at [[Caxton Hall]]. She noted how money was frequently put out of the reach of women. She believed that ""the Suffrage movement has developed in women a true appreciation of the importance of the financial side of their Cause, and the desire to get the best possible result from the contents of their war chest"".<ref name=""simkin"" />
She returned to cookery writing in 1912 with  ''In Camp and Kitchen: A Handy Guide for Emigrants and Settlers''.<ref>{{Cite web
column2: title=In camp and kitchen : a handy guide for emigrants and settlers / by the author of ""The successful home cook,"" etc.

column1: She continued to write for Girls Own Paper on cookery, finance and fiction.<ref name=""girlsown""/> In 1929, the year after women gained the vote in Britain, she wrote a series of stories about ""Margaret"" in ''Girls Own'' titled, ''Margaret's Adventures in Search of a Career; Margaret Turns Pathfinder; Margaret Launches a Canteen; Margaret Becomes a Co Partner'' and ''Margaret as the People's Representative''.<ref name=""girlsown""/>

Her last publication was in 1934 and it was a cookery book that also included wider advice on growing the produce. It was illustrated by Mary Gardiner and titled ''The Country Housewife’s Book'' or ''How to Make the Most of Country Produce and Country Fare''.<ref name=buk34>{{Cite web
column5: website=Persephone Books}}</ref> Yates died in 1935.<ref name=""perse""/>

column1: '''''Until the Last One''''' (French: '''''Jusqu'au dernier''''', Italian: '''''Fino all'ultimo''''') is a 1957 French-Italian [[thriller film]] directed by [[Pierre Billon (director)
column2: Pierre Billon]] and starring [[Raymond Pellegrin]], [[Jeanne Moreau]] and [[Paul Meurisse]].<ref>Goble p.141</ref> It was shot at the Photosonor Studios in [[Paris]] and [[location shooting
column3: on location]] around the [[River Somme]]. The film's sets were designed by the [[art director]] [[Jean d'Eaubonne]]. A [[film noir]], it attracted around a million and a quarter spectators at the French box office.<ref>Walker-Morrison p.225</ref>

column1: Criminal Fernand Bastia rats on the rest of his gang, betraying them to the police and escaping with the proceeds of the [[robbery
column2: heist]]. He goes to hide out with a travelling [[circus]] where his sister works, but is traced by his former associates.

column5: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> is an under construction RRTS station in [[Ghaziabad district]], Uttar Pradesh, India which will serves mainly [[higher-speed rail
column6: higher-speed]] trains. It will serve as a elevated station for higher-speed trains on the [[Delhi–Meerut Regional Rapid Transit System]] that can reach speeds of up to 180 km/h.

column1: Ghaziabad RRTS station is likely to be commissioned in 2023 along with the 17 km long Sahibad-Duhaiyya section of [[Delhi–Meerut Regional Rapid Transit System
column4: title=RRTS section nears launch, but links to metro, bus stand will take longer
column10: title=Delhi-Meerut RRTS corridor: Duhai-Sahibabad section likely to open for public by April – Details inside

column1: The [[National Capital Region Transport Corporation]] (NCRTC) had invited tenders for the construction of the Ghaziabad RRTS station along with the 7.3 km long Sahibabad ramp–Ghaziabad section of the 82.15 km [[Delhi–Meerut Regional Rapid Transit System
column2: Delhi–Meerut RRTS line]]. [[KEC International]] and [[China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation]] emerged as the lowest bidder for construction work. As a result, KEC International and China Civil Engineering Construction Corp has been awarded a Rs 579.76 crore contract responsible for Package 1 (Sahibabad ramp–Ghaziabad) in August 2019. Under the agreement, companies started construction of Ghaziabad RRTS station.

column1: The Ghaziabad RRTS station will have 4 elevated station platforms, With the under constructed station building will be located underneath of platform level. The RRTS station will have 2 [[Side platform
column2: side platforms]] and one [[island platform]], which will serve 4 rail tracks for regular service.

column1: It will have 4 levels - platform, mezzanine, concourse and street level. Ghaziabad RRTS station will be 215 meters long and 42 meters wide. The RRTS Station will be the tallest station in Delhi-NCR, its high is 26 meters from the ground level.<ref name=""msn"">{{cite web
column2: title=Delhi-Meerut RRTS update: Ghaziabad station to have 5 exits, to be linked with Naya Bus Stand Metro Station

column1: 73699463,Jennifer_Nogueras,"'''Jennifer Nogueras Seilhamer''' ( born 1 August 1991 ) is a Puerto Rican volleyball player. She played as a setter for [[Criollas de Caguas]] .

She was part of the Puerto Rican Under-18 national team , winning the bronze medal at the [[2006 Girls' Youth NORCECA Volleyball Championship]] , where she is awarded the best setter, and participated in the [[2007 FIVB Volleyball Girls' U18 World Championship]]. With the U-20 national team she competed at the 2008 U-20 NORCECA Volleyball Championship.

She made her [[Puerto Rico women's national volleyball team]] debut in 2014, winning the bronze medal at the [[2014 Women's Pan-American Volleyball Cup]] . She later won the bronze medal at the [[2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's Challenger Cup]] and the [[2018 Central American and Caribbean Games]] , followed by silver at the [[2021 Women's NORCECA Volleyball Championship]],<ref>{{Cite web
column5: website=www.norceca.net}}</ref> and bronze at the 2022 Norceca Pan American Cup Final Six.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: title=NORCECA Panamerican Women Volleyball Cup 2022- Final Six

column1: She competed at the [[2022 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship squads
column2: 2022 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship]],<ref>{{Cite web

column1: She played for [[University of Washington]].<ref>{{Cite web
column7: title=Mom’s Surprise In Memory of Dad Inspires UW’s Nogueras {{!}} Pac-12
column11: language=en}}</ref> She plays for [[Apollon Limassol FC

column1: 73699476,Opinion_polling_for_the_2007_Greek_legislative_election,"In the run up to the [[2007 Greek legislative election]], various organizations carried out [[opinion polling]] to gauge voting intention in [[Greece]] during the term of the [[List of members of the Hellenic Parliament, 2004–2007
column2: 12th]] [[Hellenic Parliament]]. Results of such polls are displayed in this article. The date range for these opinion polls is from the [[2004 Greek legislative election
column3: previous legislative election]], held on 7 March 2004, to the day the next election was held, on 16 September 2007.

column1: Polls are listed in reverse chronological order, showing the most recent first and using the dates when the survey fieldwork was done, as opposed to the date of publication. Where the fieldwork dates are unknown, the date of publication is given instead. The highest percentage figure in each polling survey is displayed with its background shaded in the leading party's colour. If a tie ensues, this is applied to the figures with the highest percentages. The ""Lead"" columns on the right shows the percentage-point difference between the parties with the highest percentages in a given poll.

The table below lists nationwide voting intention estimates. Refusals are generally excluded from the party vote percentages, while question wording and the treatment of ""don't know"" responses and those not intending to vote may vary between polling organisations. Polls that show their results without disregarding those respondents who were undecided or said they would abstain from voting (either physically or by voting blank) have been re-calculated by disregarding these numbers from the totals offered through a [[WP:CALC
column3: rule of three]] in order to obtain results comparable to other polls and the official election results. When available, seat projections are displayed below the percentages in a smaller font. 151 seats are required for an [[absolute majority]] in the [[Hellenic Parliament]].<ref>[http://www.ethnos.gr/article.asp?catid=5347&subid=2&pubid=132809 Exit poll results] {{Webarchive
column5: date=2007-09-29 }} from the [http://www.ethnos.gr Ethnos] daily newspaper</ref><ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Opinion polling - Legislative election 2007 - by chronological order

column11: title=চলে গেলেন পঞ্চাশ দশকের ফুটবলার কবির আহমেদ

column2: কবির আহমেদ}}; 2 February 1935 – 3 January 2019) was a Bangladeshi [[association football
column3: footballer]] who played as a [[Winger (association football)
column4: left-winger]]. He is one of the few [[East Pakistani]] players to have reprsented the [[Pakistan national football team
column5: Pakistan national team]]. He was also part of the legendary East Pakistani attacking trio of Kabir, [[Chinghla Mong Chowdhury Mari
column6: Mari Chowdhury]] and Ashraf Chowdhury.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Kabir began his career with Town Club in the ''Barishal First Division'', in 1951. When he was 17, Kabir moved to Bengal Government Press and won the [[Dhaka League]]. In 1953, Kabir he represented Governors XI in a friendly match against [[Kolkata Mohammedan]], and in 1955 he moved to [[Dhaka Wanderers Club
column2: Dhaka Wanderers]]. Kabir became league champions with ''The Wanderers'' in his lone season there, and the following year, alongside many of his teammates, he moved to [[Dhaka Mohammedan
column3: Mohammedan SC]], after a falling out with the clubs authorities. At Mohammedan, Kabir became league champions six times and also won the prestigious [[Aga Khan Gold Cup]] twice. In 1958, the ''The Black and Whites'' led by their attacking trio of [[Chinghla Mong Chowdhury Mari
column4: Mari Chowdhury]], Ashraf Chowdhury and Kabir; reached the quarter-finals of [[India]]'s [[IFA Shield]]. Kabir represented East Pakistan White's at the National Football Championship between 1955 and 1960. He captained the team in 1959, when they finished runners-up and was also present during their title triumph the following year. He retired in 1967, following a serious knee injury.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Kabir was among the six [[East Pakistani]] footballers in the [[Pakistan national football team
column2: Pakistan national team]] at the [[Football at the 1958 Asian Games
column3: 1958 Asian Games]] in [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]] and was also appointed as vice-captain. Before the tournament he played practice matches in [[Singapore]] and [[Malaysia]]. In 1959, he toured [[Burma]] and later that year also participated in the [[1960 AFC Asian Cup qualification
column4: 1960 AFC Asian Cup qualifiers]], in [[Kochi]], [[India]]. During the qualifiers he scored his first and only international goal in a 2–2 draw against [[Israel national football team
column5: Israel]]. His last international tour came the following year, under a fellow East Pakistani, head coach [[Sheikh Shaheb Ali]], as Pakistan finished fourth place in the [[Merdeka Tournament
column8: title=Former football legend Kabir passes away
column9: website=Former football legend Kabir passes away | theindependentbd.com}}</ref>

column2: + List of international goals scored by Kabir Ahmed

column1: In 1966, Kabir joined the East Pakistan Sports Federation. Kabir alongside coaches [[Sheikh Shaheb Ali]] and Chunna Rashid were in-charge of recruiting players for the East Pakistan football team from different [[Districts of Bangladesh
In 1979, he joined the [[Bangladesh Football Federation]] and in the same he was the general manager of the national team under head coach Anwar Hossain during the [[1980 AFC Asian Cup qualification
In 2001, he recieved the [[National Sports Awards (Bangladesh)
column2: National Sports Awards]], for his contribution to the country's football.

column1: Kabir died on 3 January 2019, at the age of 83. Following a [[Stroke]] in 2001, he had been paralyzed for 17 years prior to his death.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: website=দেশ রূপান্তর}}</ref> He was buried in the Azimpur graveyard, in [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]].<ref>{{Cite web

column2: Ruined church and burial ground in Trumpan, Scotland}}

column1: '''Trumpan Church''' is a ruined medieval church located on the [[Isle of Skye]] in [[Scotland]]. In 1578, the church was the site of a brutal massacre of the [[Clan MacLeod]] by [[Clanranald
column2: Clan Macdonald]], (also known as Clan Ranald) of [[South Uist]]. The attack was in retaliation for the massacre of hundreds of members of Clan Macdonald in the village of [[Eigg]] the previous year. The church and village of Trumpan were abandoned after the attack. The roofless church and surrounding graveyard contain  late medieval carved gravestones. [[Historic Environment Scotland]] designated the church and surrounding burial ground a [[scheduled monument]] in 1936.

column1: Situated on the northern end of the [[Waternish
column2: Waternish peninsula]] on the Isle of Skye, is the 13th century ruined village church of [[Trumpan]].<ref name=""Britain Express"">{{cite web
column6: access-date=12 March 2023}}</ref> Also known as ""Cille Conain"", the building dates from the medieval era and was in use until the 16th century.<ref name=""Canmore"">{{cite web
column9: website=Canmore: National Record of the Historic Environment

column1: The layout of the church is rectangular, measuring {{convert
column7: abbr=on}} wide. The structure's north wall with arched doorway and east gable have survived undamaged. The north wall is {{convert
column10: abbr=on}} in height, while little remains of the south wall. Inside the church are late medieval gravestones and the remnants of a stone basin that is believed to be the holy water font. One of the graves is inscribed with a [[claymore]] (sword) surrounded by animals and foliage.<ref name=""Britain Express"" /><ref name=""Canmore"" /><ref name=""HE church"" />

column1: The burial ground surrounding the church contains a rough standing stone, {{convert
column4: abbr=on}} in height, and known as the ""Priest's Stone"". A second medieval grave slab, southwest of the church, is engraved with the image of a tonsured priest with the placement of the hands  as if in prayer. In the upper part of the stone, is an interlaced  cross within a circle, and in the lower part of the stone is the image of a chalice. The church and surrounding burial ground were designated a scheduled monument in 1936.<ref name=""HE church"" />

column1: Trumpan church dates from the medieval era, possibly the 13th century. It is believed to have been dedicated to St Connan. It is the site of the mid-16th century massacre of Clan Macleod by Clan Macdonald of South Uist. The Macdonald party landed on the island on a Sunday morning in May, 1578 and set fire to the church and prevented the villagers inside from escaping. The massacre was in retaliation for the slaughter of over 350 members of Clan Macdonald on the island of [[Eigg]] the previous year <ref name=""Britain Express"" /><ref name=""HE church"" /> <ref name=""Undiscovered Scotland"">{{cite web

A battle ensued when MacLeod clan members from Dunvegan rushed to the scene and attacked the murderers as they sought to leave the island and were stopped by a receding tide. Very few of the Macdonald clan survived the battle.<ref name=""Britain Express"" />
The victims were buried near a [[dyke (embankment)
column2: dyke]] which was pulled down over the corpses, giving the name to the battle as the ""[[Battle of the Spoiling Dyke]]"". The church and village were abandoned after the massacre.<ref name=""Canmore"" />

column1: The church's burial ground is also thought to be where [[Rachel Chiesley, Lady Grange
column2: Lady Grange]], a famous 18th century kidnap victim, is buried.<ref name=""HE church"">{{cite web
column3: title=Trumpan Church, burial ground and 'Priest's Stone', Hallin

'''Jeremiah Moon''' (born August 18, 1998) is an American football [[linebacker]] for the [[Baltimore Ravens]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL). He played college football at [[Florida Gators football
Moon's freshman season was cut short after two games due to a season ending injury, leading him to [[redshirt (college sports)
column2: redshirt]] for the rest of his season. After recovering, he started in give games in 2017 and 13 games in 2018. However, more injuries caused him to sit out for both the 2019 and 2020 season.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title= Jeremiah Moon Keeps Improving for Gators Defense
column7: date=October 14, 2021}}</ref> Thanks to his three injury-shortended season and the extra year of eligibility, due to [[COVID-19]], he returned for a sixth year in 2021.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title= eremiah Moon looks to make his sixth year his best

column1: Moon went undrafted in the [[2022 NFL Draft]]. He eventually signed with the [[Baltimore Ravens]] as an [[undrafted free agent]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title= Jeremiah Moon passed over in 2022 NFL draft, signs as UDFA
column6: date=May 1, 2022}}</ref> He played in a few preseason games before being assigned to the practice squad for the 2022 season.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title= Ravens Set Initial Practice Squad
column11: date=August 31, 2022}}</ref> He was signed to a future/reserve contract on January 17, 2023.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Ravens Sign Young Players to Reserve/Future Contracts

column1: '''''Ocypode madagascariensis''''' is a medium-sized species of [[Ocypode]] found in [[Madagascar]] and the southeastern coast of Africa (from [[Mozambique]] to [[KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa]]). Its carapace is covered densely with rough tubercles on the upper surface and wider than it is long. The outer edges of the eye orbits are broadly triangular and project forward. Their stridulating ridge has 20 to 30 tubercles.<ref>{{Cite journal
column7: title=Revision of the genus Ocypode with the description of a new genus, Hoplocypode (Crustacea: Decapoda: Brachyura)

'''''Legendrea loyezae''''' is a rare species of [[freshwater]] [[Anaerobic organism
column2: anaerobic]] [[ciliate]]. Only six accounts of ''L. loyezae'' specimens have been published as of 2022.<ref name=""Legendrea"">{{cite journal
column4: title=The Extraordinarily Rare Ciliate Legendrea loyezae Fauré-Fremiet, 1908 (Haptoria, Ciliophora)

column1: [[Phylogenetic analysis]] of a partial ''L. loyezae'' [[18S ribosomal RNA]] sequence indicate it is a member of the Family [[Spathidiidae]] and Order [[Haptorida]]. It is also more closely related to the species ''[[Apertospathula oktemae]]'' of the family Apertospathulidae and ''[[Arcuospathidium]]'' sp. than other Spathidiidae. The sequence is also a [[sister group]] to a clade of three ''[[Epispathidium]]'' sequences.<ref name=""Legendrea"" />

column11: in}} wide, and are [[ovoid]] and slightly flattened in shape. It has uniform [[cilia]] on its body and a complete [[oral bulge]] (bulge located at its [[Cytostome
column12: mouth]]) with dense rows of [[extrusome]]s. It possesses one elongated, horseshoe-shaped [[macronucleus]] and a [[contractile vacuole]] at its posterior end.<ref name=""Legendrea"" />

column1: ''L. loyezae'' possesses 15–30 tentacles protruding from an indentation in its posterior, with 5–8 cilia in a ring and densely-packed, curved, needle-shaped extrusomes protruding from a vacuole on each tentacle tip. When swimming, these tentacles retract and trail behind the cell, which is heart-shaped due to the indentation; when stationary, the cell flattens against a surface such that it takes on a rounder shape and the tentacles fully extend, becoming narrower and reaching up to twice the length of the body. The vacuole also expands when the tentacles extend.<ref name=""Legendrea"" />

''L. loyezae'' occurs in freshwater [[anoxic]] (oxygen-free) sediments, such as that found in freshwater ponds.<ref name=""Legendrea"" /> Fauré-Fremiet's first account of their existence states they were first found in a pond near Paris, France.<ref>{{cite journal
column6: title=Sur deux Infusoires nouveaux de la famille des Trachelidae
column14: language=fr}}</ref> In the second account of their existence, published by [[Eugene Penard]], they were discovered in a marsh in [[Rouelbeau, Geneva]].<ref>{{cite journal
column27: language=fr}}</ref> In 2014, specimens were found in freshwater ponds in Germany. In 2021 and 2022, specimens were found in woodland freshwater lakes in [[Warsaw, Poland]].<ref name=""Legendrea"" />

column1: When feeding, ''L. loyezae'' assumes its stationary form for days at a time to wait for prey. The cilia at the tip of the extended tentacles perform a ""beating"" motion, while the tip with extrusomes moved like ""fish bait"". In their 2022 article, Weiss et al. theorized that the tentacles capture prey in the extrusomes, then move it to the cytostome (mouth) to be ingested.<ref name=""Legendrea"" />

During the feeding phase, ''L. loyezae'' were observed as not reacting to tapping or short bursts of UV light on the microscope slides they were residing on. However, it did move in response to the nearby presence of ''[[Monomorphina]]'' sp., a [[photosynthetic]] organism, likely in reaction to its production of oxygen. In such an event, ''L. loyezae'' can contract its tentacles in about 30 seconds, changing from its stationary form to its swimming form as it moves to an anoxic location where it may resume its feeding phase.<ref name=""Legendrea"" />
''L. loyezae'' is a free-living, non-parasitic organism. [[Endosymbiotic]] [[prokaryote]]s are present inside its [[cytoplasm]].<ref name=""Legendrea"" />
*[https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1434461022000578-mmc1.mp4 Video of ''L. loyezae'' contracting its tentacles (Weiss et al., 2022)]

column1: '''Vita spericolata'''"" (transl. ""Reckless life"") is a 1983 song composed by [[Vasco Rossi]] (lyrics) and  {{Interlanguage link
column3: it}} (music) and performed by Vasco Rossi.

column1: The song had a gestation of about an year; it was initially presented by composer Ferro with English lyrics,<ref name=""Rizzoli"" /> and in an early draft it was a love song about a girl named Licia.<ref name=music/> Eventually, Rossi chose to reprise the same theme already explored in previous singles ""Siamo solo noi"" and ""Vado al massimo"", namely a celebration of [[anticonformism]] and of freedom from all schemes and conventions.<ref name=""Rizzoli"" />
The song premiered at the [[Sanremo Music Festival 1983
column2: 33rd edition]] of the [[Sanremo Music Festival]], where it ranked penultimate.<ref name=""Rizzoli"" /><ref name=music>{{cite book
column4: title=Festival di Sanremo: almanacco illustrato della canzone italiana
column9: pages=339}}</ref> It eventually turned out to be a long-selling hit and Rossi's consacration.<ref name=Rizzoli>{{cite book
column11: title=1000 canzoni che ci hanno cambiato la vita
column23: year=2001}}</ref>  It has been described as a ""manifesto of human individualism taken to the extreme between transgression, boredom, melancholy and the determination to live without limits or schedules"".<ref name=music/>

column1: Cover versions of the song include those recorded by [[Francesco De Gregori]], [[Massimo Ranieri]] and [[Thelma Houston]] with an English-language version titled ""My Life Is Mine"".<ref name=""dizcanzone"" /> [[Gino Paoli]] reprised its refrain in his hit ""Quattro amici"".<ref name=music/><ref name=dizcanzone/>

column1: '''Kettla Ness''' is a [[tied island]] and headland in [[Shetland]].<ref name=""Gazetteer"">{{cite web
column5: accessdate=1 May 2023}}</ref>  It is connected by the [[tombolo]] Minn beach (Banna Minn), to the south end of [[West Burra]], part of the [[Scalloway Islands]]. <ref name=""Shetland"">{{cite web
column10: title=Dynamic Coast - National Coastal Change Assessment: Cell 11 - Shetland CRW2014/2
column15: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> The headland itself is conspicious and circa 160 feet high.<ref name=""Coastal"">{{Citation
column20: title = Shetland Coastal Zone Assessment Survey
column21: publisher = Historic Scotland and Shetland Amenity Trust

column2: title = British Islands Pilot: Faroes, Shetlands, and Orkney Islands and north and east coasts of Scotland

url = https://www.google.co.uk/books/edition/British_Islands_Pilot_Faroes_Shetlands_a/NaYuAAAAYAAJ?hl=en&gbpv=1}}</ref> The island is accessible to walkers via Minn beach and is now uninhabitated.<ref name=""Coastal""/> It is principally used for [[Sheep farming]] and pasture.<ref name=""Dynamic Coast""/>

column1: The former settlements of Minn,<ref name=""CanmoreMinn"">{{Canmore
column7: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> and Point of Guide<ref name=""CanmorePointofG"">{{Canmore
column10: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> lie on the north-west part of the island. The ruined village was principally abandoned following the [[Highland Clearances]] in the 19th century although some occupation continued into the early 20th century.<ref name=""Coastal""/> There are several other instances of prehistoric activity on the island, primarily at Minn, including several a 3rd-1st millenium BC house, cairns, burnt mounds, cists, crop marks and other structures.<ref name=""Coastal""/><ref name=""CanmoreGossigarthMound"">{{Canmore
column31: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> Several of these are located in the Bight of the Sandy Geoes, an area on the eastern side of Kettla Ness.<ref name=""Coastal""/><ref name=""CanmoreBight"">{{Canmore
column33: desc=West Burra, Bight Of The Sandy Geos
column36: desc=West Burra, Bight Of The Sandy Geos, House
column37: access-date=1 May 2023}}</ref> Iron-age pottery fragments have also been found around Sandy Geos.<ref name=""CanmoreSandyGeos"">{{Canmore
column39: desc=West Burra, Bight Of The Sandy Geos
column42: desc=West Burra, Bight Of The Sandy Geos

column1: On the south side of Kettla Ness is a stream flowing from the Outra Loch. Along the stream there are numerous examples of ruined historic horizontal [[watermills]] that extend down to Groot Ness on the south coast.<ref name=""CanmoreGrootNess"">{{Canmore
column6: desc=West Burra, Groot Ness, Horizontal Mill
column9: desc=West Burra, Groot Ness, Horizontal Mill
column12: desc=West Burra, Groot Ness, Horizontal Mill

column1: In 1959, a triangulation pillar was erected on the island.
To the west of the island is the wreck of the boat 'Saint Kentigern' which ran aground in November 1979.<ref name=""CanmoreKentigern"">{{Canmore

column4: Inlet at Kettla Ness. Much of the rocky coast is formed from micaceous psammites of the Colla Firth Group - a suite of rocks which have been equated with the Dalradian succession of the Scottish Highlands]]

column1: There are four small lochs on the island: Virda Vatn, Loch of Annyeruss , Outra Loch and Croo Loch.
Flora on Kettla Ness includes [[Armeria maritima]] which is extensive on the south-west coast opposite the Rod Skerries.<ref name=""Coastal""/>

To the west of Kettla Ness is Fugla Stack, a geologocial [[stack]] landform that consists of vertical volumns of rock. There is a wreck, the 'MV Castor' dating to 1910 beside the stack.<ref name=""CanmoreFugla"">{{Canmore
column3: desc=Castor: Fugla Stack, West Burra, Atlantic

column1: '''Arpan Kumar Chandel''' (born 10 Oct 1998) who's better known by his stage name King, and has become a household name with his rap number, 'Sahi Galat', in the Ajay Devgn-starrer hit movie 'Drishyam 2'. King is an Indian rapper singer, music composer. He has been described in the media as one of the most popular rappers.
Arpan Kumar Chandel was born on 10 Oct 1998 to Ashok Chandel and Rani Chandel in the city of [[New Delhi]].

King had thought of making career in rapping while studying in school. He used YouTube to show his talent and got immense popularity and huge fan following. Later, he got a chance to participate in the television rap reality show MTV Hustle. In this show, he was seen performing in front of Raftaar, Raja Kumari and Nucleya. Nucleya offered him to work on his album after the first performance on MTV Hustle.
In 2022, he made Bollywood debut through Hindi film Drishyam 2 where he voiced the song Sahi Galat with Devi Sri Prasad and Amitabh Bhattacharya.

column2: title=Playlist Top Hits of Arpan Kumar Chandel on Hungama.com

column1: '''Jeremy Hammond''' (born January 8, 1985) is an American activist and former computer hacker from [[Chicago]]. He founded the computer security training website [[HackThisSite]] in 2003. He was first imprisoned over the [[Protest Warrior]] hack in 2005 and was later convicted of [[computer fraud]] in 2013 for [[2012–13 Stratfor email leak
column2: hacking the private intelligence firm Stratfor]] and releasing data to [[WikiLeaks]], and sentenced to 10 years in prison.

column1: In 2019, he was summoned before a Virginia [[federal grand jury]] which was investigating [[WikiLeaks]]<nowiki/>and its founder [[Julian Assange]]. He was held in [[Civil contempt
column2: civil contempt of court]] after refusing to testify on the principle of grand jury resistance.

column1: He was released from prison in November 2020.

Hammond was raised in the [[Chicago]] suburb of [[Glendale Heights, Illinois]], with his twin brother Jason. Hammond became interested in computers at an early age, programming video games in [[QBasic]] by age eight, and building databases by age thirteen. As a student at [[Glenbard East High School]] in the nearby suburb of [[Lombard, Illinois
column2: Lombard]], Hammond won first place in a district-wide science competition for a computer program he designed. While in [[high school]], he became a peace activist, organizing a student walkout on the day of the [[2003 invasion of Iraq
column3: Iraq invasion]] and starting a student newspaper to oppose the [[Iraq War]]. His high school principal described Hammond as ""old beyond his years"".

column1: Hammond attended the [[University of Illinois at Chicago]]. In the spring of 2004, during his freshman year, he exploited a security flaw on the computer science department's website and went to department administrators, offering to help fix the security flaws on the site and looking to get a job. For inserting the [[Backdoor (computing)
column2: backdoor]], Hammond was called before the department chair and ultimately banned from returning for his sophomore year.

column1: Jeremy, along with his brother Jason, has had a lifelong interest in music, performing in numerous bands through the years. Before Jeremy's arrests, they were both actively performing in the Chicago [[ska]] band Dirty Surgeon Insurgency.
Hammond worked as a [[Apple certification programs
column2: Mac technician]] in [[Villa Park, Illinois]]. He also worked as a web developer for Chicago-based Rome & Company. His boss at Rome & Company wrote in 2010 that Hammond is ""friendly, courteous and polite and while we suspect he has a low tolerance for corporate posturing, he has never demonstrated any contempt for business in the workplace"".

column1: Hammond founded the computer security training website HackThisSite at age 18, during the summer after his high school graduation. The website describes itself as ""a non-profit organization that strives to protect a good security culture and learning atmosphere"". In its first two years the site received 2.5 million hits and acquired 110,000 members and a volunteer staff of 34.

During the 2004 [[DEF CON]] event in [[Las Vegas]], Hammond delivered a talk that encouraged ""[[electronic civil disobedience]]"" as a means of protest against the [[2004 Republican National Convention]] and its supporters.
In February 2005, Hammond, with others, hacked the website of pro-war [[Counterprotest
column2: counterprotesting]] group [[Protest Warrior]] and accessed thousands of credit card numbers, intending to use them to donate to left-wing groups. Although no charges were ever made against the cards, Hammond confessed and was sentenced to two years in federal prison for the crime. Freed after 18 months, Hammond was radicalized by the experience, although the terms of his probation prohibited him from associating with HackThisSite or anarchist groups for another three years.

column1: On March 5, 2012, Hammond was arrested by [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) agents in the [[Bridgeport, Chicago
column2: Bridgeport]] neighborhood of [[Chicago]] for his involvement in the [[2012–13 Stratfor email leak
column3: December 2011 cyberattack on Stratfor]], a private intelligence firm. The intrusion compromised 60,000 credit card numbers, $700,000 in fraudulent charges, and involved the download of 5 million emails, some of which were subsequently published by [[WikiLeaks]]. The indictment was unsealed the following day in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York
column4: Manhattan federal district court]]. He was one of six individuals from the United States, England and Ireland indicted. Hammond faced a total of nine charges, including conspiracy to commit computer hacking, and conspiracy to commit access device fraud [37, 33].

column1: The FBI was led to Hammond through information given by computer hacker [[Hector Xavier Monsegur]] (""Sabu""), who became a government informant immediately after his arrest in early 2011, and subsequently pleaded guilty in August 2011 to twelve counts of hacking, fraud, and [[identity theft]]. Although Monsegur could have received a sentence of more than 20 years in prison, prosecutors asked that he be sentenced to time served, which was seven months in prison. Information from Monsegur helped lead the authorities to at least eight co-conspirators, including Hammond, and helped to disrupt at least 300 cyberattacks.
The case was prosecuted by the office of [[Preet Bharara]], the [[United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York]]. Hammond was represented by [[Elizabeth Fink]].

column2: detained pending trial]]; in denying bail, Judge [[Loretta A. Preska]] described Hammond as ""a very substantial danger to the community.""In February 2013, the defense filed a motion asking presiding Judge Preska to recuse herself from the case on the basis that Preska's husband, Thomas Kavaler, had an email address released in the Stratfor disclosure and worked with Stratfor clients that were affected by the hack. Hammond's legal team argued that this created ""appearance of partiality too strong to be disregarded"". Preska denied the motion, claiming that the connections were inconsequential or unimportant.

column1: In May 2013, Hammond pleaded guilty to one count of violating the [[Computer Fraud and Abuse Act]] (CFAA). Upon his guilty plea, Hammond issued a statement saying, ""I did work with [[Anonymous (group)
column2: Anonymous]] to hack Stratfor, among other websites"" and ""I did what I believe is right."" He maintained that he had no profit motive for the cyberattack. Hammond has insisted that he would not have carried out the breach of Stratfor's systems without the involvement of Sabu. Hammond was sentenced on November 15, 2013, to the maximum of ten years in prison, followed by three years of supervised release. He described his prosecution and sentence as a ""vengeful, spiteful act."" On November 17, 2020, Hammond was released from the [[Federal Correctional Institution, Memphis
column3: Memphis Federal Correctional Institution]] and was transferred to a recovery house to serve the rest of his sentence.

column1: In October 2019, Hammond was summoned before a Virginia [[federal grand jury]] which was investigating [[WikiLeaks]] and its founder [[Julian Assange]]. He was held in [[Civil contempt
column2: civil contempt of court]] by Judge [[Anthony Trenga]] after refusing to testify. Prosecutors granted Hammond [[immunity from prosecution]] based on any grand jury testimony, so Hammond could not refuse to testify on the ground of his [[right against self-incrimination]]. Like [[Chelsea Manning]] (who was also held in contempt for refusing to testify), Hammond said he was ideologically opposed to any grand jury probe which was not being conducted in ""good faith"" as the government already had the information it needed. In making his contempt ruling, Trenga stated that Hammond's arguments against testifying were ""self-serving assertions … without support."" Trenga ordered Hammond released in March 2020 after the conclusion of the grand jury, saying that prosecutors no longer required his testimony. Hammond was returned to federal prison to serve the balance of his 10 year sentence. Hammond may have received an early release in December 2019 had the grand jury not intervened.

column1: He frequently identifies as an [[anarchist]] and has a shoulder tattoo of the [[anarchy symbol]] with the words: ""Freedom, equality, anarchy."" Writing after his arrest, Hammond said, ""I have always made it clear that I am an [[anarchist-communist]] – as in I believe we need to abolish capitalism and the state in its entirety to realize a free, egalitarian society. I'm not into watering down or selling out the message or making it more marketable for the masses.""

Hammond has been involved in various political causes and movements throughout his life, including environmentalism, animal rights, and anti-capitalism. In addition to his hacking activities, he has participated in protests, direct action, and community organizing [32].

Jeremy Hammond's actions, convictions, and imprisonment have made him a prominent figure in the world of hacktivism and cybersecurity. His work with Anonymous and his involvement in high-profile hacks like the Stratfor case has drawn attention to the potential power and influence of hacktivism as a form of protest and civil disobedience. Hammond's case has also raised questions about the ethics of hacking, the role of government informants like Sabu, and the potential for prosecutorial overreach in cases involving cybersecurity [36].

Supporters argue that Hammond's actions exposed important information about corporate and government surveillance, as well as highlighting the need for greater transparency and accountability. On the other hand, critics contend that his methods were illegal and potentially harmful to innocent individuals whose personal information was exposed in the hacks.

Since his release from prison, Hammond has continued to advocate for transparency, digital privacy, and civil liberties. His experiences have also inspired others in the hacktivist community to continue fighting for their causes and to use their technical skills for social and political change [34].

Jeremy Hammond's story has been the subject of significant media coverage and interest, particularly within the realms of cybersecurity, hacktivism, and digital rights activism. In 2014, a documentary titled ""The Hacker Wars"" was released, which explores the world of hacktivists and prominently features Hammond's story, along with the stories of other notable hacktivists such as Barrett Brown and Weev. The documentary delves into the motivations, ethics, and consequences of hacktivism, as well as the legal battles and controversies that have surrounded these individuals [34].

Hammond's actions and the Stratfor hack have also been covered by various news outlets, investigative reports, and academic studies. His case has been used to examine the larger implications of hacktivism on society, the role of technology in activism, and the balance between national security and individual privacy in the digital age.

While Hammond's story continues to generate debate and discussion, his case has undoubtedly left a lasting impact on the world of hacktivism and cybersecurity. As concerns about digital privacy, surveillance, and the role of technology in activism continue to evolve, the legacy of Hammond and his fellow hacktivists will remain an important part of the conversation surrounding these issues [36].

Two human polls and a committee's selections comprise the [[2023 NCAA Division I FBS football season
column3: Division I]] [[Football Bowl Subdivision]] (FBS) football rankings, in addition to various publications' preseason polls. Unlike most sports, college football's governing body, the NCAA, does not bestow a [[national championship]] at the FBS level.<!--it does for FCS and lower levels--> Instead, that title is bestowed by one or more different polling agencies. There are two main weekly polls that begin in the preseason—the [[AP Poll]] and the [[Coaches Poll]]. One additional poll, the [[College Football Playoff]] (CFP) ranking, is usually released starting midway through the season. The CFP rankings determine who makes the four-team playoff that determines the College Football Playoff National Champion.

'''''Killer Kid''''' is a 1994 French drama film directed by [[Gilles de Maistre]], starring [[Tewfik Jallab]] and [[Younesse Boudache]].

Two 11-year-old Arab boys become acquainted in France. One was raised in Lebanon where he was trained to kill efficiently and sent on a mission to commit a murder. The other was raised in France by an immigrant family and lives a life dominated by pop culture. The former comes to regard the latter as his role model.<ref name="":1"">{{cite news
''Killer Kid'' is based on the 1989 novel with the same name by [[Patrick Cauvin

column1: '''''Ocypode mortoni''''' is a small-sized species of [[Ocypode]] found in South [[China]] and southern [[Japan]]. It is closely related to ''O. stimpsoni'' which is also found in the same regions, but can be distinguished by the presence of styles on their eyestalks. They also share the same range with ''O. ceratophthalmus'' (which also possess styles), but ''O. mortoni'' have 35 to 71 striae on their stridulating ridges and their smaller claws have broadly rounded to flattened tips.<ref>{{Cite journal

column1: The '''2023 Salvadoran protests''' occurred on 1 May 2023 in [[San Salvador]], [[El Salvador]]. Protestors marched from the Cuscatlán Park to the [[Plaza Gerardo Barrios
column2: Gerardo Barrios Plaza]] in protest of the [[Salvadoran gang crackdown (2022–present)
column3: 2022–23 gang crackdown]] and President [[Nayib Bukele]]'s re-election campaign. They also demanded an increase in minimum wage and the that the government respects the rights of syndicates and respects the [[Constitution of El Salvador

column1: In mid-April 2023, seven Salvadoran leftist organizations announced that they would hold a protest march in San Salvador on 1 May 2023 in commemoration of the [[International Workers' Day]]. The protest's organizers stated that they were protesting against the country's [[Salvadoran gang crackdown (2022–present)
column2: gang crackdown]], which had up to that point led to the arrests of over 67,000 people, and against the re-election campaign of President [[Nayib Bukele]]; re-election is prohibited by the [[constitution of El Salvador]].<ref name=""7LO"">{{cite web
column4: title=Siete Organizaciones de Izquierda Anuncian Marcha Contra Régimen y Reelección

column1: On 20 April 2023, Rodrigo Cerritos, a member of the [[Farabundo Martí National Liberation Front]]'s (FMLN) national council, confirmed that the FMLN would participate in the 1 May 2023 protest and asked the [[National Civil Police of El Salvador
column2: National Civil Police]] (PNC) to not block or prevent the protest.<ref name=""FMLNpro"">{{cite web
column4: title=FMLN Anuncia que Participará en Marcha del 1 de Mayo
column5: trans-title=FMLN Announces that It Will Participate in the 1 May March

column1: The protest gathered at 8 a.m. at the Cuscatlán Park. Protestors traveled for three hours to the [[Plaza Gerardo Barrios
column2: Gerardo Barrios Plaza]]. During the march, protestors demanded an increase in [[minimum wage]] from US$365 to US$500, the respect of syndical liberties, the respect of the constitution, and opposed the capture of innocent people in the gang crackdown and presidential re-election. In total, 34 organizations and the FMLN and Nuestro Tiempo political parties participated in the protest.<ref name=""1Mayprotest1"">{{cite web

column6: title=These 'how to' videos on YouTube won't teach you how to be a better adult. But they’re not supposed to.
column10: language=en-US}}</ref> The videos sometimes receive questioning for their narration, which is criticized for sounding unnatural.<ref name="":3"" /><ref name="":0"" /> In addition, some consider the videos to be unsuitable for kids, and to be encouraging dangerous behavior.<ref name="":2"" /> Troom Troom videos are sometimes considered to be ""content farms"" for their vibrant thumbnails and ""[[clickbait]] titles"".<ref name="":0"" /><ref name="":2"" /><ref name="":7"" /> Although Troom Troom's videos are popular with their target audience and often go viral, they are generally negatively received by others.<ref name="":3"" /><ref name="":1"" /> The channel has over 22 million subscribers and over 9 billion views, making it one of the most popular on the platform.<ref name="":6"" />

column1: '''Yafang Cheng''' is a Chinese geoscientist at the [[Max Planck Institute for Chemistry]], in Mainz, Germany. She specialises in atmospheric chemistry and physics.
She was born and grew up in [[Wuhan]], China. She received a [[Bachelor of Science
column2: BSc]] in environmental science from [[Wuhan University]] and a PhD in environmental science from [[Peking University]]. In 2011, she became an assistant professor of atmospheric science at [[Peking University]]. In 2014, she was appointed as head of Minerva Independent Research Group ""Aerosols, Air Quality & Climate"" at the [[Max Planck Institute for Chemistry]]. She is also a guest professor at the Peking University and [[University of Science and Technology of China]].
aerosols]] and their impact on air quality, public health and climate. She has published in highly regarded scientific journals including [[Science (journal)
column3: Science]], [[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
column4: PNAS]] etc., and has been recognized as ""[[Highly cited researcher]]"" by [[Web of Science]] & [[Clarivate]].<ref>Highly cited researcher, Web of Science & Clarivate, [https://www.webofscience.com/wos/author/record/783932 2021 Recipients & 2022 Recipients]. </ref>

column1: Cheng has been co-editor and senior editor of the [[Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics]] of [[European Geosciences Union]].<ref>[https://www.atmospheric-chemistry-and-physics.net/editorial_board.html Editorial board, Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics, EGU], retrieved 2023-01-17.</ref> In January 2023, she was appointed editor-in-chief of ''[[Journal of Geophysical Research]]: [[Atmosphere (journal)
column2: Atmospheres]]'' of the [[American Geophysical Union]].<ref>[https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/hub/journal/21698996/editorial-board Editorial board, Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres, AGU], retrieved 2023-01-27.</ref>

column1: In 2021, Cheng was elected a member of [[Academia Europaea]]<ref>[https://www.ae-info.org/ae/Member/Cheng_Yafang Member information: Yafang Cheng, Academia Europaea (The Academy of Europe)], retrieved 2023-01-27.</ref>, and in 2022, she became a fellow of the [[American Geophysical Union]].<ref>[https://www.agu.org/SearchResults?searchterm=Yafang%20Cheng&searchtype=pages&searchboxid=247B77AE-E2D7-4B83-9656-609C7344460D&pageSize=12 American Geophysical Union], retrieved 2023-01-27.</ref>

* 2022 Joanne Simpson Medal, American Geophysical Union (AGU)<ref>[https://www.agu.org/Award-Showcase/Pages/Medalists Medalists, AGU Honors 2022], retrieved 2023-01-27.</ref><ref>[https://eos.org/agu-news/congratulations-to-the-2022-agu-union-medal-award-and-prize-recipients Joanne Simpson Medal for Mid-Career Scientists 2022 of the AGU, EoS], eos.org, retrieved 2023-01-27.</ref>

* 2021 Science Breakthroughs of the Year 2021 in Physical Sciences, Falling Walls Foundation<ref>[https://falling-walls.com/people/yafang-cheng/ Yafang Cheng, 2021 Winner in Physical Sciences, Falling Walls], retrieved 2023-01-27</ref>

* 2020 Atmospheric Science Ascent Award, American Geophysical Union (AGU)<ref>[https://www.agu.org/Honor-and-Recognize/Honors/Section-Awards/Ascent-Award Recipients, Atmospheric Sciences Ascent Award, American Geophysical Union], retrieved 2023-01-27</ref>

* 2020 Schmauss Award, German Association for Aerosol Research (GAef)<ref>[https://www.info.gaef.de/schmauss-award Winners of the Schmauss Award, The Gesellschaft für Aerosolforschung (GAeF, German Association for Aerosol Research)], retrieved 2023-01-27</ref>
'''More Than Scientists''' is a United States-based [[nonprofit]] [[environmental organization
column2: environmental advocacy group]]. It provides a service for [[climatology
column3: climate scientists]] to speak publicly about their personal views on [[climate change]]<ref name=""WEF"">{{cite web
column4: title=The scientists making climate change personal
column8: title=Who's That Person Behind the Lab Coat?
column14: title=More Than Scientists, Mauna Loa, and Better Climate Communication
column18: title=Watch climate scientists give global warming elevator pitches
column22: title=Speaking From the Heart, Climate Scientists Launch Personal Campaign
column26: title=Shocking video footage shows scientists having feelings

column1: More than 80 climate scientists from leading climate science departments including [[MIT]]<ref>{{cite web
column13: access-date=7 February 2022}}</ref>, and [[University of Colorado Boulder]]<ref>{{cite web
column17: access-date=7 February 2022}}</ref> have participated and recorded More Than Scientists videos.  Participants include [[Kerry Emanuel]]<ref>{{cite web

column1: The objective of More Than Scientists is to support climate scientists speaking as concerned citizens, parents, and community members<ref name=""WEF"" /><ref name=""CRP"" /><ref name=""Mashable"" /><ref name=""Grist"" />.  Their purpose in their videos isn't to report on the science, but to say what they expect climate change will mean for society – the effect it will have on future generations, and to urge that society take it seriously and act<ref name=""WEF"" /><ref name=""CRP"" /><ref name=""Mashable"" /><ref name=""ICN"" /><ref name=""Grist"" />.
More Than Scientists focuses on the personal and societal effects of climate change with these primary topics:
* Impacts on the water supply<ref>{{cite web
* Impacts on storms and natural disasters<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Impacts on Storms and Natural Disasters videos

column1: In addition, many of the videos provide personal introductions to the scientists themselves.

More Than Scientists was founded in 2015 by [[Eric Michelman]], its Director, and Dargan Frierson, an associate professor of Atmospheric Sciences at the University of Washington<ref name=""WEF"" /><ref name=""Mashable"" /><ref name=""ICN"" />. [[Free Range Studios]] led the campaign strategy, website development, and the introduction.",7645,false
